The Committee of the Privy Council have had before
them a report, dated 26th August, 1924, from the Superinten-
dent of Indian Affairs, submitting that, it having been
decided to erect a new Indian residential school at Onion
Lake in the province of Saskatchewan, tenders were called for,
receivable up to noon of the 25th day of August, 1924, and
the following were received,-

Permanent Construction Co., Edmonton, $73,900.00
A. W. Cassidy & Co. Ltd., Saskatoon, 70,457.00
S. Brown, Winnipeg, 66,900.00
Smith Bros. & Wilson, Regina, 65,440.00
William Wilson, Regina, 64,900.00
Poole Construction Co., Regina, 64,900.00
Maird Construction Co. Ltd., Calgary, 64,517.00
The Bennett & White Const. Co. Calgary, 64,149.00
Olney Co. Ltd., Winnipeg, 63,927.00
James Priel, Saskatoon, 58,500.00

The Minister recommends that, pursuant of Sub-section 2
of Section 36 of the Public Works Act, the contract be awarded
to the lowest tenderer, Mr. James Priel, for the amount of
his tender as above cited, namely, $58,500.00, the same being
reported by the architect of the Department as a fair and
reasonable price for the work, and money having been provided
therefor in the vote for Indian Education, No.266.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation
and submit the same for approval.

The Honourable
the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Ottawa.

Re Onion Lake Indian Residential School

Dear Sir:-

I thank you for your letter of 4th Inst., in which you advise me that my tender for the above proposed School is the lowest received by your Department.

I also note that the Department is not entering into a Contract until a satisfactory Water supply at Site is assured.

As there may be some delay in commencing this work, there is one matter especially which might be given your kind consideration; that is the matter of the Heating for the Building. I am advised that it will take a matter of approximately two months after placing order, before the Boiler could be delivered. If this be the case, and I have no reason to doubt my informant, it will probably mean that the Boiler would not be there before Freeze-up, which would mean considerable delay in the completion of the work.

I shall be glad if your Department will give this important matter the necessary consideration, and advise me, if so disposed, as to your decision.

Again thanking you.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Sir,

I have the honour to report with respect to the well drilling on the new school site at this Agency, that the drill is now down to a depth of about 260 feet and water has not yet been secured. However, the formation of the soil is now showing indications of changing (the last 130 feet has been through soapstone) and the driller, Mr. J. B. Frederiksen, is hopeful of striking water shortly.

Mr. Frederiksen has been very unfortunate with this drilling; he has had many breakages to his machinery and has been put to considerable expense. He has requested me to apply for an advance for him, and I would ask that a cheque for $200.00 may be forwarded him in my care.

Dear Sir:

In further reference to your kind letter of August 12th, in which you advised us that we would be afforded an opportunity of figuring on the desks, etc., required for the Onion Lake Indian School. We know that this contract has been let, and when you are ready for figures on school equipment, would be glad to have your specification.

We understand from the Contractors that the Duck Lake Indian School will be completed about January 1st, and we would esteem it a kindness to be permitted to figure on school equipment required for this Institution also.

We respectfully wish to bring to the notice of your Institution a blackboard product which is taking the place of all composition and quarry slate boards. In the matter of durability, safety from breakage in transit, cutting surface for chalk and uniformity of thickness and appearance, this board is vastly superior to even the genuine quarry slate. In this connection and for a matter of reference we might state that the Toronto Public Schools are adopting this board. In addition it has gone into every Saskatchewan school of the better type that has been erected this year.

We are mailing you sample under separate cover and would esteem it a kindness if you would place same in the hands of your Constructional Department.
Sir,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, requesting on behalf of the Principal of the Onion Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School that authority be granted for the purchase of 6 refills for the chemical fire extinguishers and a leather belt for the wood cutting engine.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the refills required for the fire extinguishers. The department is not prepared to authorize the supplying of the leather belt, as it is considered that equipment of this nature should be provided by the school from the per capita grant or other receipts. Nov. 15, 1924.

Dear Sir:

The Honourable the Superintendent General has brought to my attention your request to proceed with the erection of the new Onion Lake School.

I regret to say that it is impossible to commence the building of this school at present. Every effort was made to secure an adequate supply of water on the site selected, but all attempts have failed, which makes it necessary to negotiate and secure a new site for the building, where an adequate supply of water can be obtained. This matter is now receiving immediate attention, and if a suitable site is secured this fall that will enable us to go ahead with the building program I will immediately advise you.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General

James Priel, Esq.,
Contractor,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Dear Mr. Scott,

With reference to the well drilling on the new site at Onion Lake, I have to inform you that up to the 5th of this month the drillers had gone down to a depth of 185 feet, and no water had yet been struck; the formation now being much the same as that which we went through on the original site.

I doubt the wisdom of continuing drilling, unless we are prepared to go a great deal deeper. The well drillers can go to a depth of 425 feet, but if we are going to go that deep we might as well move back to the original site.

There is absolutely nothing in the way of a precedent to go upon in drilling in this district and it may be that there is no water sheet underlying this land, and if there is that it is at a great depth. If there is no sheet of water it would be a matter of pure luck to strike a spring of sufficient volume to supply an institution of the kind contemplated.

Kindly let me know if you think we should keep on drilling.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Re water supply for the New Onion Lake School

Owing to the failure to secure an adequate supply of water for our Society's new Residential School here after boring to a depth of over 360 ft., on the site chosen last June by the shore of Long Lake, and the necessity which this has created of selecting another site, I arranged to visit this centre on my way from the Mackay School at The Pas to the Schools in S. Alberta, and arrived here yesterday. As Mr. Commissioner Graham had instructed the local Indian Agent Mr. Turner to select another site not less than one mile away from the site first chosen, and have boring operations commenced there, I visited this new site yesterday afternoon with Mr. Turner, and Mr. Ellis, the School's Principal. Boring operations had begun on this site which is fully half a mile from the Lake shore, and a hole had been sunk to a depth of 200 ft. without finding water. As the strata penetrated appeared to be practically identical with that encountered in sinking the hole on the first site, both the Well-borer and Mr. Turner were doubtful as to finding there the supply of water required.

This site, although situated on the section of land set apart by the Indians for the use of the School is not so suitable as the one first chosen.

From this site we proceeded not without difficulty, owing to the deep snow, to the east-end of the Lake where there is a spring of good water yielding about two gallons to the minute. While it might be possible to construct and conserve this water for the use of the School if built there, Mr. Turner, Mr. Ellis, and I were agreed that there were two very serious objections to this locality as a suitable place for erecting a school. These were:
1. The absence of a level site large enough to accommodate the buildings within a distance of fully a quarter of a mile, and

2. The sandy and consequently barren nature of the soil. No Indians live on it and none of them have ever attempted to farm it.

After carefully considering the whole situation Mr. Turner and I came to the conclusion that the best solution to the problem of an adequate supply of water for the new School would be to have the School erected on the shore of the Lake, about 200 yards to the east of the site selected in June, and to have arrangements made for the water supply to be secured from the Lake itself.

As there is a more gradual slope from this site to the water's edge than at the one chosen in June, we thought that this would facilitate the arrangements necessary for constructing a reservoir, and for the laying down of the necessary piping. We also estimated that the cost of installing this system of water supply would be fully as economical, if not more so, than to continue the boring operations at other centres, with the possibility of not securing an adequate or suitable supply even after much labour and expense. I myself am the more impressed with this view of the situation, as I have learned that no other deep well ever sunk on the Onion Lake Reserve has found water.

To build therefore the new School for our Society on the site recommended above on the shore of Long Lake, within the section of land already set apart, and to arrange for the water supply to be drawn from the Lake itself, appears to Mr. Turner and me to be the most satisfactory, if not the only arrangement possible under the present circumstances, and I beg to recommend that action be taken by your Department in keeping with this recommendation.

The site itself, although level, affords excellent drainage facilities to a depression which would be on the rear or north side of the main building and away from the lake. As it stands at the centre of the bend on the north-side of the lake, it commands a full and picturesque view of practically the whole of the lake's surface.

The height about the lake level is about 100 feet. From the main school building to the water's edge would be about 150 yards, and deep water, I am informed would be reached at not more than 100 yards from the shore. In winter the average thickness of the ice is said to be about 3 feet.

I commend the recommendation set forth above to your early and sympathetic consideration and beg to remain

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Scott:

Referring to my letter of the 12th inst., I beg to inform you that I am in receipt of another letter from Mr. Agent Turner, in which he informs me that well drilling operations have been practically suspended for the last few days. As we are now down to a depth of 185 ft. and as yet there are no indications of water, it seems to me that we should abandon this site.

The agent suggests that we move back to the first site chosen, which is near the lake, and make arrangements to use the lake water, as we do on Gordon's reserve. This lake is of considerable size and it looks to me as if the water is as good as any to be found in the lakes in this country. I had a sample of this water taken and tested and the opinion from the Laboratory is as follows:

"Although this water is suitable for drinking purposes from a chemical point of view, the bacteriological examination and the test for nitrites shows that the sample was subject to marked pollution. This is to be expected in a lake water. All surface waters in Saskatchewan must be considered as dangerous for domestic consumption, unless they are treated by some approved process before reaching the consumer."

As the sample was not taken in accordance with Departmental instructions, or, in a sterilized container, conclusions should not be drawn from the bacteriological examination.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant with reference to Doctor Westgate's request that the Department consider the advisability of substituting galvanized iron shingles in place of wooden shingles specified for the Onion Lake School.

In reply I beg to say that I do not agree with Dr. Westgate's recommendation. In the first place, the cedar shingles, according to experts whom I have consulted, will last considerably longer than will the galvanized iron shingles; although I believe if I went to the firm who sell the latter kind of shingles they would say the opposite. I have taken up this matter with several architects, as well as dealers, and they all strongly advise me to stay with the cedar shingles. From the standpoint of economy it will cost just twice as much money to put on the galvanized iron shingles as it would the cedar. I would therefore request that Dr. Westgate be informed that we do not intend to use them.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir,

I am today in receipt of a letter from the Reverend Dr. Westgate, in which he tells me that he has received a letter from the Department saying that I have strongly recommended that wooden shingles be used as specified on the Onion Lake School.

Dr. Westgate has asked me to re-consider and advise the Department that the metal roofing be adopted. This I cannot do. Would it not be a good plan for the Department to express an opinion in this matter? I am of the opinion that Dr. Westgate thinks the matter is entirely up to me.

My instructions from the Department are to curtail expenses and to adhere to the principles that are most generally followed in putting up buildings of this kind. I have taken a great deal of trouble to ascertain to what extent metal roofing is used on buildings such as the one we are putting up and find that it is used on very few.

It places me in an awkward position if this man and others have the opinion that the Department are indifferent in the matter. It would make matters a great deal better if the Department would say they concurred in what I say, or otherwise. Of course I do not know what has actually been said to Dr. Westgate; I am merely judging from the letter that I have received that he was given to understand that the matter was left entirely in my hands, which it was not.

The Secretary,

Sir:

I enclose herewith a rough sketch of a plan for a septic tank and drainage system in connection with the new Onion Lake Residential School.

It is proposed to build this tank along the same line as the tank which was installed at the Round Lake School three years ago, and which has given splendid satisfaction and complied with the regulations of the Provincial Government. The length of the tank is 20 feet, the depth 12 feet and the width 4½ feet. The receiving chamber will be 4½' x 12', and the discharge chamber 4½' x 8'.

A re-inforced concrete wall 5' high will separate the receiving from the discharge chamber. The tank will be lined with re-inforced concrete and is to be water proof. A horizontal table of re-inforced concrete is to be placed in the tank at a depth of 5' below the surface and a concrete table on the ground surface level forming a roof for the tank. Both the receiving and discharge chambers are to be provided with metal man holes. The tank will be equipped with an Amathes Syphon with long bend.

The sewage pipe line from the school building to the septic tank, a distance of 230 ft., will be composed of 6" glazed tile pipe laid at a depth of not less than 7 ft. from the surface of the ground. The discharge drain from the tank will be 200 ft. long with 4" field tile laid in a valley with open joints not more than 1" apart, and the whole covered in a proper manner. The nature of the soil that this discharge pipe will pass through is a porous sand and I am told that this length of pipe should take care of the discharge, but if it is found not to be sufficient, it will be a simple and inexpensive matter to add to this field.

I submitted this plan to Mr. James Friel, the Contractor, who is on the ground with a staff of workmen and who is in a position to do the work cheaper than anyone else, and he offers to supply the material and complete the work in connection with this system for the sum of $1082.00. I have gone carefully into the figures in connection with the tank at Round Lake, and comparing them with Mr. Friel's figures (taking into consideration also the distance from the railway) I consider his offer a reasonable one, and would recommend that it be accepted.

I would be glad to have your approval to proceed with this work as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Re: Onion Lake School

In compliance with your instructions, we have made a survey of the site for the above school and, at the same time, we laid out the basement for the contractor and gave him a grade line.

We are forwarding to you, under separate registered cover, the original tracings which shows the lay out at this point. You will notice that we have shown contour lines, each line representing a rise or fall of five feet in the ground. We have assumed the elevation of the water level in the lake as 100 feet as a basis for our work. The pipe line leading from the lake to the building was staked on the ground for 50 feet and the position of the proposed well is marked by stake No. 16. It appears that there would be good seepage from the lake to the well. However, without a test hole, it would be impossible to determine this, and if sufficient water does not seep through, it will be necessary to dig a trench out to the lake and fill in with coarse gravel.

From the profile of this pipeline we have indicated the grade for the pipe, giving it 9 feet of cover. This can be altered one way or the other. However, as the digging is fairly easy, with the possible exception of the lower 150 feet, we would suggest giving it, at least, 9 feet and 10 feet would be safe. We have the pipe line laid out to enter the building 14 feet west of the centre line of the building and this would bring it in along the passage way, as shown on our plan, and in a direct line with the boiler room and machinery room.

We have staked out the proposed location for the sewer line and septic tank. There is excellent fall from the building towards the west terminating in a slough, as indicated on the plan. We do not know what system you favour for disposing of the liquid from the septic tanks, but if you wish to put in farm tile on the slope below the tanks and let it seep away into the ground, there is a good location, as shown by the contours. The pipeline is staked every 50 feet and the pipe line goes from 30 inches to 3 feet south of the staked line. We have made the grade of the pipe sufficiently low at the building to take care of the boiler room, if that is necessary, or if you wish to put another pipe line to take care of the wash water, that could be done in the same trench.

If there is any additional information which you require, we would be glad to hear from you.

We are enclosing herewith statement of our account, covering the field work and also the office work in connection with the preparation of the plans.

We might say that in proceeding to Onion Lake we accompanied Mr. Marison by way of St. Walburg, but upon returning we saved a day going by way of Lloydminster. However, as the ferry was not running, it was necessary for us to have a livery meet us at the south side of the river.

Your obedient servants,

J. E. Underwood & Associates.

I have gone into the matter of water supply for the Onion Lake Boarding School very thoroughly, and have decided that it would be better to install two pressure tanks in the basement, of the capacity of 1500 gallons each; also a storage reservoir alongside of the school, 12 x 12 and perhaps 10 ft. deep, into which the water from the lake will be pumped, and from there with an electric engine into the pressure tanks. This system is used at other institutions in the country with great satisfaction, and is strongly recommended by Messrs. Paulin and Swayze, in whom I have great confidence.

The installation of these tanks in the basement will lessen the work of the pump at the lake, which means that the pump will last longer, and if the reservoir outside the school is kept full of water there is always a reserve supply on hand, which is a great advantage in case anything goes wrong with the pump. It also means increased protection in the case of fire.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
If this system is installed I believe it would cost in the neighbourhood of from $1600 to $1800; this is outside of the piping from the lake and the well that will have to be dug at the lake, which latter items might cost another $800.00. Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM:

Commissioner Graham has submitted sketch plans of a sewage disposal system for the Onion Lake Indian Residential School, Sask. The scheme will consist in the erection of a two compartment septic tank, located a distance of 230 feet in the rear of the building. The outlet from the siphon chamber which will be 200 feet, will provide by itself a means of disposing of the sewage on account of the absorbing nature of the soil. Mr. James Friel, the contractor who is on the ground with a staff of workmen has offered to carry out this work for the sum of $1,060.00, which, according to Mr. Graham is a reasonable price. I have, myself, made an approximate estimate of the cost of the work, and concur with Mr. Graham's recommendation that this offer be accepted.

The question of the water supply system is now under consideration, and it is expected that the Department will be furnished with a proposal within the course of a few days.

Sir:

I have your 309-11A of the 5th instant, with reference to a request from the Rev. Principal of the Onion Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School. I note that requisition is made for certain agricultural implements.

Please make enquiries as to what agricultural equipment is already owned by the institution and then make a recommendation as to what the Department should purchase to supplement this.

Sir:

I have received a letter from the Rev. Principal of the Church of England, Onion Lake Indian Residential School suggesting that a folding door be placed in the middle of the passage-way on the first floor of the new school building to separate the Boys' and Girls' Dormitories. This door could be closed while the dormitories are in occupation and thrown open if necessary during the day time. I think the proposal a good one and would recommend its adoption.

The Field Secretary of the M.S.C.C. has written to me pointing out that no provision is made in the plans and specifications for eave troughs or a cement cistern to hold soft water, which can be conserved for laundry purposes. I do not appear to have any report as to whether the lake water would be sufficiently soft to take the place of rain water, and would suggest that the eave troughs and cistern be provided. He also draws my attention to the provision for attaching the storm windows on the outside and suggests that this should be changed, and the storm sashes be placed on the inside. I have just received a letter from the Inspector of Construction who informs me he has looked into the matter and thinks the storm sashes could be put on the inside without very much trouble. It would be as well therefore to have this done.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
There is a further matter to which Dr. Westgate has referred, that is, that a Drying Tumbler is not included in the items of laundry equipment. It is not the practice of the Department to supply a Drying Tumbler for other Residential Schools and last fall when laundry appliances were furnished at the Cowesses and File Hills Boarding Schools this article was not included. At Hobbs I recently recommended the installation of a washer and dryer, meaning by the latter an extractor, and it was probably therefore not an omission in the specifications when the Drying Tumbler was not included for Onion Lake. If the Department desires to furnish this in addition to what is being provided for please advise me.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham
Indian Commissioner,
Sir:

I have just received a letter from Mr. W. A. Hamilton the Inspector of Construction at Onion Lake who reports that the progress on the school is going on satisfactorily. He advises me that no switch was provided for the night lights in the Boys' and Girls' Dormitories, and no lights shown for the coal and wood room, as I think these desirable I have told him that the necessary provision for these may be made.

There are one or two other matters which he takes up upon which I should be glad to receive your instructions by telegram, as follows:-

1. If folding doors are provided to partition off the passage-way on the dormitory floor, two fire songs should be supplied. One each on the boys' and girls' side.

2. The Heating Contractor wishes to know where the high pressure boiler is to be located.

3. No floor-drain is shown in the engine room and this should be provided.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
4. The return pipes for the heating system are specified to be carried back to the boiler in a trench, but there is nothing specified about the trench, and the contractor claims that he did not figure for covering it, and of course it cannot be left open.

5. There are no specifications covering the ceiling for the boiler room and as the walls are to be of cement it might probably be advisable to have re-enforced cement slab ceiling which would make the room fire proof.

I should like to have instructions about these matters as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham
Indian Commissioner.
6th July, 1925.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 2nd instant with reference to the new Church of England School on Onion Lake, I beg to say that the Department approves of the placing of folding doors in the middle of the corridors on the first floor of the new building.

With reference to sawe troughs and a concrete drain I think before consideration is given to the installing of the soft water tank that it would be well to make sure that the water in the lake is unsatisfactory for laundry purposes.

The storm wash may be placed on the inside as recommended.

Regarding the drying tumbler asked for by Dr. Westgate, I would ask you to please make a recommendation as to the mode of drying the clothes in the laundry after they are removed from the ejector.

Your obedient servant,

(A. F. MacKenzie)
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Genl. of Indians,
Regina, Sask.
6th July, 1925.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 2nd instant with reference to Mr. Hamilton's report on the progress of work at Onion Lake School; I beg to reply to the items mentioned in your letter in the order submitted:

1. Approve two floor gongs.

2. High pressure boiler be located in boiler room.

3. Approve floor drain in engine room.

4. With reference to the placing return pipes in a trench, the Department will expect the contractor to fill in this trench, and finish over with the same material as specified for the floors.

5. It is not thought necessary to provide a reinforced concrete ceiling in the boiler room and there will be less chance of fire if the rafters are left exposed as shown.

I am very glad to learn that good progress is being made on this contract.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Orr:

This morning I forwarded the following telegram to the Secretary of your Department:

"Principal Onion Lake School wires stating Contractor assures him water system of new School will freeze before midwinter. Have also heard no barn or stable built yet. Please issue necessary instructions both above matters."

Mr. Ellis the Principal seems very anxious that I should come and inspect the whole building before we enter on occupation, and this I will do if at all possible. I am surprised to learn that nothing has been done towards building a barn and stable and that the main school is without eaves troughs. I have just wired to Mr. Ellis telling him that our Society decline to enter occupation until all equipment has been installed, heating, lighting and water systems supplied, and sufficient stable accommodation provided. In a letter to me dated Oct. 23rd he writes with regard to the water system as follows:

1. The pipe laid down where it meets the water's edge can only be laid below the surface about 2 ft. because of the deep slope to the lake shore. I am of the opinion that in severe weather it will
freeze unless the Contractor banks it up on top.

2. The screening at the mouth of the pipe in the lake which has been placed about 200 ft. from the shore is not small enough to prevent the storage tank which is made of cement from being filled with small minnows.

3. He desires to know if the report on the lake water by the Regina Analyst was found satisfactory. In this connection he states that he was informed that the men working on the building would not use the lake water but got their supply from a spring about ½ mile away.

You will see from the above that a careful examination of the whole water system should be made by a competent representative of your Department before the Contractor has been awarded payment. I am disinclined to believe that the workmen could not drink the water from the lake but am asking Commissioner Graham for a copy of the Analyst's report in this connection.

Trusting that the above information may be of service to you and that the buildings will be complete and ready for occupation before the end of this year.

Believe me,

Dear Sir:

We wish to tender you our report upon the completion of the water installation at Onion Lake Boarding School, Saskatchewan.

The whole of the work has been executed in a first class workmanlike manner, and has been left in the care of your Inspector, Mr. Hamilton, in good working order in so far as we were able to make a final test.

The 2½" galvanized pipe has been run 95 ft. from the pump house to shore line, and 200 ft. from shore line into lake. There is a probability that later in the season the frost may reach this intake pipe at the shore line, owing to the fact that we were prevented from going deep enough at this point on account of the early freeze-up. In the event of a freeze-up, water can be hauled to concrete supply tank for the balance of the winter. I might state that we had teams hauling earth to cover over the pipe at shore line to a depth of approximately
approximately 5 ft. This will require to be deepened at this point early next summer, in order to have a frost proof water intake.

In trying out the engine and pump we pumped direct into the pressure tanks from the lake, and raised 50 lbs. pressure in the tanks, which means, when you add for elevation, a pressure of 85 lbs. The storage supply tank was not ready to receive the water, hence the reason for pumping direct into pressure tanks.

In conclusion, after having noted the very complete and up-to-date heating, plumbing, lighting and water supply equipment in this building, it would seem to us nothing short of gross carelessness to intrust a plant of this description to the present staff.

As a suggestion, would recommend that a competent man be placed in charge for a sufficient time to allow the staff appointed to become thoroughly competent to carry on.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Scott:

In preparation for our interview on Saturday morning next, I have thought that you would like to have copies of the following correspondence which has passed between Dr. Westgate and Mr. Commissioner Graham with regard to the Principal's residence and barns for the new Union Lake School, and also with regard to the report of the chemical analysis of the water taken from the Lake from which the supply for the new school is to be drawn.

With regard to the former matter I beg permission to draw your attention to my letter to the Honourable, the Superintendent General, dated Feb. 11th, 1925, of which copy was duly forwarded to you. Paragraph (4) of this letter states one of the points of agreement reached at that time, in the following words:

"That, in future, the Architect's plans for new Residential Schools to be administered by the Society shall include provision for....at least the main barns and associated buildings thus avoiding a repetition of the delays and losses to the Society which have occurred, and are now occurring, in connection with the occupancy of the new school on the Blood Reserve."

The statement of Mr. Commissioner Graham contained in his letter, copy enclosed, dated Oct. 31st, is in direct conflict with the agreement reached with the Honourable the Superintendent General. The Rev. Henry Ellis, who has done such valuable work as Principal of the Union Lake School has tendered his resignation to the Society rather than contemplate carrying out the proposal that, in lieu of having a proper residence provided for him in connection with the new School, he and his family should be cramped into narrow and unsatisfactory quarters which are designed as part of the ordinary accommodation of the new building and which were never intended to be occupied by the Principal and his family. It appears to me, further, to be quite impossible for us to enter into occupancy of the new school while, as Mr. Commissioner Graham states, no barns or associated outbuildings have been erected, or are likely to be erected before next Spring at the earliest. Under these circumstances, from the standpoint of the uncompleted...
Chemical and bacteriological examinations of the sample of water provided from the Lake, appears to me to have even more serious implications. No report was furnished the Church Authorities of the same, in fact no notice was apparently taken of the serious character of the bacteriological examination in reporting the presence of "B. Coli" (Bacillus Coli Communis, or the bacillus which is the recognized cause of typhoid). The analyst notes that the sample was not taken in accordance with the conditions necessary to a correct and proper examination. Making all allowances, however, for possible contamination from this source it seems clear that the water supply, in its present state, is so thoroughly open to suspicion and grave source of danger to health that, in my opinion, neither the Department nor the Church would be justified in placing the pupils and the staff of a large Indian Residential School in residence in the building before a further careful and competent examination has been carried out by the recognized Provincial Authorities who shall be held responsible not only for the actual chemical and bacteriological examination but for the actual securing, under all necessary precautionary methods, of the sample of the water from the part and depth of the Lake where the intake for the proposed water supply is located.

These matters are so important that I thought you would like to have this statement of my information concerning them for consideration before our interview on Saturday morning.

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have received your telegram today with reference to the Onion Lake School water supply asking if I had carried out the instructions contained in your letter of the 19th November, 1924. I did not have another analysis made of the lake water because I had spoken to the Department of Public Health here, and received the assurance that the water was of a quality suitable for institutional uses, and equal to any used by other country schools in the Province. It was the intention, however, to sink a well close to the edge of the lake and procure a supply by the process of filtration. This project, however, had to be abandoned as quick sand was found where it was proposed to sink this well. I do not think there is any cause for apprehension as to the nature of the water which will be used at the Onion Lake School.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant 195-1-5, informing me that you do not think it will be practicable, under present conditions, to have the staff and pupils moved into the new Onion Lake School this Fall, and it will, therefore, be necessary to employ a man for the winter months to act as caretaker and fireman, to say nothing of the expense of supplying fuel.

I am indeed surprised that you think it necessary to take this course of action. This building is completed in every detail, after a good deal of rushing of the work towards the end. The water system is in good shape. I have had the water from the lake tested the second time and it is reported to me by the Government Analyst as being excellent water. The lighting plant is installed and ready for use. In fact any work that I had anything to do with was rushed along to completion and as I say, the school is ready for occupancy now, and to get a letter at this late date, saying that it is proposed not to open the school until Spring is very disappointing. You wired me a short time ago to have temporary barns erected at this school; this I did, and the barns are now complete.

In speaking to the Building Inspector, who returned from Onion Lake a few days ago, he tells me that the Principal has already started to move some of the furniture into the building, and that he fully expects to go ahead and occupy the new school at once, and what could have happened I do not know. It is hard to believe that the school authorities would rather continue to occupy the old building they are now in, and have a new building six miles over that they could move into and carry on their work under very much improved conditions. I think myself that the Department have not been fully advised of the exact conditions existing. There has been no holdup of any work to its end that I can see. The furnishings that I had anything to do with were ordered and are possibly at Onion Lake by now.

If this building is not occupied this fall, the Department are going to be called upon to pay out over a thousand dollars which I consider will be an absolutely unnecessary expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

33.79.- This was for providing double doors on the dormitory floor authorized by the Department in their letter of the 6th of July.

25.80.- The contractor who installed the lighting plant insisted on a partition being built to keep the batteries separate from the rest of the plant and avoid the possibility of damage to the plant by fumes arising from the battery during the process of recharging it.

4.99.- This item covers the building of shelves to hold the battery.

30.04.- This represents an extra for providing tables in the lavatories, these items not having been provided for in the original specifications.

4.85.- No cover was allowed in the plans or specifications to carry the outlet for the ash hoist and this item represents the cost of providing one.

7.40.- This wood tank was let into the ground outside the building by the contractor who furnished the lighting plant and is provided to receive the metal gasoline containers as they are purchased from time to time.

15.30.- This is the contractor's charge for hauling the batteries in his own vehicle from Lloydminster to the school site a distance of 43 miles and which I have allowed as a fair charge.

61.15.- Is for providing material for and setting up the engine base including cement, sand, bolts etc., and the freighting of the engine from Lloydminster.

3.16.- This represents the cost of providing cement, etc., for bases for two pumps.

16.90.- This represents the charge for two concrete cradles to support the pressure tanks.

4.50.- It was necessary to provide an air pipe from the water cistern to the side of the building and to the top of it and this item covers the contract charge for digging the trench for the pipe.
After boilers had been installed by the sub-contractor, the water supply to the building had not been completed, as a test of the boilers was desirable before the sub-contractor left the premises and the weather at that time was cold and uncertain. The original specifications for the piping for the water line called for the installation of 1½" pipe. $14.00 - The plan provided for one switch which turned on all the lights on in the ground floor corridor. Dear Mr. Graham:

I am surprised to learn that there has been a question raised regarding the water system at the new Onion Lake School, which was installed under my personal supervision.

You will recall when I returned from Onion Lake I said there might be a possibility of the system freezing at the entrance of the pipes to the lake, owing to the heavy early frost, but this is only a possibility, and if we have a good fall of snow, as I think we will, there will be no chance whatever of this happening. Since I left there, your Mr. Hamilton covered this pipe with about five feet of earth, according to my instructions, and to me there is only a bare possibility of it freezing in any event.

If it is a question of not opening the school, on a chance of this system not working, all I can say is that to my mind this is absolutely absurd, and the man who gave this information cannot be very anxious to see the school opened. If your informant is of the same calibre as the Principal of this school, who is to be left in charge of this plant, I am not surprised at any reports you will get. As I stated to you before, this man is utterly incompetent to handle machinery of any kind, and these remarks will be borne out, I am sure, by Mr. Hamilton your own Inspector, who is familiar with the situation. A practical man would never have put these imaginary obstacles in the way of opening the school.

With regard to the well that is suggested. This is not necessary, and I do not consider it practical. The system you now have installed will work, and work well, and will give you better water because the pipes have been run out to the deep portion of the lake and take the water from where I imagine this lake is being fed by springs, and I understand from you that the Government Analyst reports this water as perfect.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

I may say
I may say that I will guarantee if this system should freeze up this winter, I will go back to Onion Lake in the spring or summer and take the responsibility of putting it in so that it will not freeze, and if after that it should freeze, I will refund to you the cost of the work.

If the present system should freeze by any chance, owing to the fact that we do not get a heavy fall of snow, which I look for to further protect the pipes, there is, as you know, a storage tank at the school which holds about 8000 gallons of water - three or four days supply - in addition to two steel storage tanks in the school, which possibly hold another 2500 gallons, and it would be a simple matter to have a threshing tank haul water and empty it into this storage tank at the school, as the lake is only about 200 yards away from the building and you have an automatic pump attached to the tank to draw the water into the pressure tank. It might take four trips a day to do this, and even if it cost $1.00 or $1.50 a day to keep this supply of water there it would not be very much.

E. P. Paulin,
PAULIN & SWAYZE

Dear Mr. Scotts-

Mr. Hamilton, the Building Inspector at the new Onion Lake Indian Residential School, whose services terminated a week ago, brought me in a letter this morning that he received from Mr. Walter Street, the man to whom he gave the job of putting shelving in all the existing clothes closets, six in number. In this letter Mr. Street states that Dr. Westgate had arrived at the school, and that he is making the shelves to suit Dr. Westgate. This is after authority had been given and the bargain made with Mr. Street. He also states that Dr. Westgate said he would have to build wardrobes, with drawers underneath, in the dormitories for each child to put his clothes in, and he asks for instructions as to whether he should do this or not.

Dr. Westgate has no right whatever to go on to a Government job and interfere with the work of the men who take their instructions from the proper source, and he should be told so. As to the necessity of building wardrobes in the dormitories, I cannot see this. We have had individual shelves put up for each boy's outfit and each girl's outfit in the clothes closets provided for this purpose, one for the boys' and one for the girls'. On the next flat we have put shelves for goods not in use in four closets, and in my opinion it is absurd to go to the expense of spending another $1000.00 or more to put shelving in the dormitories, to say nothing of the fact that it will more or less disfigure the rooms.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

It is rather
It is rather difficult for me to carry on work and to have Dr. Westgate going through the country as he has been doing, not on one occasion, but on several, and finding fault with the way things were done, and trying to make changes. It is not in the interests of good work or discipline, and while I have no desire to have any controversy with Dr. Westgate or his superior officers, I must insist that he does not interfere as he is doing.

While dealing with this subject I might say that if this school is not to be opened this winter it is hard for me to understand. Everything is in first-class shape, and if there is delay, Dr. Westgate I think is responsible for it. With regard to the water system, I am enclosing herewith the report of the Analytical Chemist, and the Bacteriologist of the Provincial Laboratory, Dept. of Health, as well as the opinion of Mr. R.H. Murray, Director, Division of Sanitation. The first report indicated that we were perfectly safe in going ahead and using this water, but Dr. Westgate saw fit some time ago to take this matter up with you, and you wired me for a second report.

It is not very satisfactory trying to carry on business in this way. I do my very best to meet the Department's wishes in everything, and in this case there were no grounds whatever for criticising anything that was done by the Department in connection with getting this school into order. I learn from the Inspector that Mr. Hamilton received a letter from the man who built the temporary stables to the effect that Dr. Westgate had instructed him to do some banking around this building. It was not my intention to incur any expenditure in having this banking done. Straw was to be used for this purpose and covered over with snow after the buildings were occupied. Why should the Department pay for anything that Dr. Westgate orders? I never feel sure when I give an order that somebody will not come along and alter it. This should cease.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Scott:

On the 15th of July last I forwarded to the Secretary a list of electric light fixtures prepared by the Principal for use in the new Onion Lake Residential School, but find on reference to the file here that I received no acknowledgement or any advice as to what arrangements the Department proposed to make in regard to the selection of these fixtures. I presume that after the receipt of my letter and enclosure the matter was taken up direct with the contractor, and I am not aware of what arrangements the Department made to check the fixtures ordered and used for the purpose of ascertaining whether they were of the proper type and standard and came within or exceeded the allowance of $500.00 which the contractor was to include in his estimates of the total cost of the building. I understand from Mr. W.A. Hamilton that he had no instructions, and did not check the material supplied, and that invoices were not submitted to him for scrutiny or approval.

It is important that the Department should have access to the contractor's invoices and the assurance that the material supplied was up to standard and satisfactory to the Department. In the list of extras submitted with other documents under cover of my letter to you of the 30th ultimo is a schedule of allowances for extras in connection with the lighting arrangements and this includes an item of $55.00 for

D.C. Scott, Esq.,

for a five light fixture for the Chapel. This the Inspector of Construction informs me was included by him in the list of extras on the ground that a five light fixture was used in place of a three light, as provided for in the estimates, and this change he further informs me was made at the instigation of the Principal. If the Department will give me the particulars of the arrangements made I can arrange for a proper check of the contractor's charges under the head of "Electric Light Installation". It would have been better if the Department had allowed the selection of the fixtures to be made in this office when the Inspector would have received instructions to check the work of the electrician. As it stands all the information he can give me is that fixtures were installed where required, but cannot inform me whether they were up to standard.

I note that in all specifications issued by the Department a lump sum is allowed for electric light fixtures. I do not think this is the best or most economical method of dealing with the subject. Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant 115-1-5 with reference to the electric lighting fixtures for the new Onion Lake Indian Residential School. You point out that a letter was written to me on the 23rd of June, advising me of a letter received by the Department from Mr. Priel, and asking me to arrange for the selection of lighting fixtures required for this building. I may say that I received the letter referred to, and on receipt of it I took the matter up as to the requirements in the way of fixtures at this school, and submitted a list to you on the 16th of July, asking you to check it over very carefully. I expected that I would get the Department's approval on this list, after which I would obtain competitive prices and either cut the list down or add to it, so long as I kept the cost within the $500.00 allowed. I have no acknowledgement of this letter. I do not know whether it was ever received or not, and what I would like to know now is who placed the order for the fixtures, and were they bought at a reasonable rate. I think I was entitled to a reply to my letter of the 16th of July, and I am of the opinion that this matter could have been handled in a more satisfactory manner than it was.

You will note on the final estimate forwarded for the contractor that an item of $65.00 is shown as an extra for providing a five-light fixture, and the Department should be satisfied that the remaining fixtures purchased, exhausted the appropriation of $500.00 before this item is paid.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Graham:

When visiting the new Onion Lake School today, Mr. Street, the Carpenter informed me that he was authorized to place shelves in the kitchen, the two clothing rooms, the two linen rooms and the two store rooms only. As clothes cupboards are very necessary in each of the four dormitories I beg to suggest that Mr. Street be authorized to have these built as well. They should be modelled after those built in the dormitories of the Old Sun School. On reading over Mr. Ellis' copy of the Department's letter to you dated Oct. 20th, No. 115-1-12 I find that you have been empowered to supply whatever shelving and cupboards are necessary.

With regards to the hauling of the equipment from Lloydminster to the school, I regret to have to inform you that the school management will be unable to render any assistance in this connection. The delay in completing the school ready for occupation is placing so heavy a burden upon the staff that they are quite unable to spare a man or the team from the school premises when wood and hay have to be hauled from the new site in addition to the multifarious other duties. I shall be obliged therefore, if you will make other arrangements for the transportation of the equipment.

I should mention also that in order to keep the batteries from going to utter ruin the engineer on our staff has been charging them from time to time. As gasoline is required for this and the Principal has been paying for the same, I shall be obliged if you will instruct your Agent Mr. Turner, to reimburse him for what he has already spent and purchase a sufficient quantity to enable the batteries to be charged regularly until such time as the water system is corrected, and the whole plant made ready for occupation.

Believe me,
Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:-

I enclose for your information a copy of a letter which I addressed to Mr. Commissioner Graham during my visit to the Onion Lake School last month. As I have not received any acknowledgement of the receipt of this letter I am uncertain as to what action, if any, has been taken with regard to the cupboards mentioned in the first paragraph, and will be obliged if you will undertake to see that these are provided.

In addition to the clothes cupboards mentioned above I beg to state that the following requirements had not been provided at the time of my visit:

1. A guard or railing to be built around the dynamo, belts, pulleys, switch-board, etc. in the engine room.
2. An ash lift from the furnace room (can, rope, crank, pulleys).
3. Lockers with clothes hooks built, in each recreation room.
4. Hooks for towels in the wash rooms, also brackets for tooth-brushes, mugs, combs, etc.
5. Paper holders in toilets.
6. Ventilator in the engine house on the lake shore to carry off gas fumes.
7. Eave-troughs (and down pipes) all around main building, also cement soft-water tank.
8. Erection of a railing along both sides of the open ditch leading from the septic tank.
9. Have the verandah on the west end of the main building screened so as to be mosquito proof.

If you will issue instructions to have 1 to 6 of the above provided immediately, and the others, not later than the end of April I shall be very deeply obliged.

Sir:

With reference to Department #115-1-5 dated the 19th ultimo with reference to the installation of the water system at the new Onion Lake Church of England School, I find that on the 22nd and 26th of May last I wrote you on this subject. At that time it had been proposed and it was the intention to sink a well close to the lake shore which would be supplied with water by the means of filtration; difficulties arose, however, which necessitated the abandoning of this part of the scheme. It was then decided to sink a well near the lake which was to be fed by intake from the lake. From the well an engine will pump the water into a storage tank near the building and inside the building an automatic electric pump will force the water from the storage tank into the twin distributing tanks within the building. I find, however, that I did not further communicate with the Department on the subject of securing formal sanction, and I beg to request that you will take the necessary steps to secure the authority for the work, which has already been done.

I considered it more advantageous to have this work done on a 10% basis by Messrs. Paulin & Swayne, and I beg now to enclose Regina voucher #3586 in their favor amounting to $2,586.53, which I recommend for payment.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

I have today received a letter from Mr. Graham inclosing an account amounting to $2,538.53 for the installation of a water-supply system in connection with the New Onion Lake Church of England Indian Residential School.

Dear Commissioner Graham:

I have to inform you that I am of the opinion that the engine now running the lighting plant at the Onion Lake new school is not powerful enough to carry the load. When charging the batteries between 25 and 30 amperes, the engine gets so hot that the exhaust valve chips off, and besides the heavy knock in the engine, the charge has to be reduced to 10 amperes which means that we are unable to get the batteries over a half charge.

To run continuously as we are now will mean that the exhaust valve will have to be changed at least every two weeks. Even when charging the batteries in the evening, carrying only the lights that are required at 110 volts, we have to further reduce the amperes to 5 which means that we are taking more out of the storage batteries than can be put in, and to continue doing this it will be impossible to prevent the batteries from becoming completely discharged.

To overcome this difficulty of constantly changing the valves, which are in such a state that they are too badly chipped to be reground, I would recommend that the present engine be replaced with a 20 h.p. new engine, or the same make, which to my mind is the best engine on the market.

Further, to prevent our plant from being at a standstill while the above change is being made, would you kindly order by telegram to the Fairbanks-Morse Co., Winnipeg or Regina to be forwarded to us by Express the following repair parts, viz:-

1. Exhaust Valve - ZRA-10
2. Cylinder Gaskets - ZRA-190B

Yours very truly,

Principal.
17th February, 1926.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir:

I have to acknowledge your letter of the 9th instant with regard to the lighting plant and for your information I have to inform you that we are charging the batteries in series, which means that only half the charge is going into each of them, therefore it is necessary to charge them at a higher rate than if we were charging them in parallel.

I am of the opinion that the engine is worn out, for though we have changed the exhaust valve three times in nearly two months, it does not seem to retain the compression. When pumping the water from the storage tank into the compression tanks when starting up the one h.p. motor at the pump, the engine is killed, which proves I think that the engine cannot take care of the smallest load. Since we have occupied the school we have consumed five hundred and thirty gallons of gasoline.

We have recently had an inspection from Mr. Lightcap of the Globeite Battery Company of Winnipeg, and I have thoroughly explained the situation to him, who will be able to give you full details of our position.

Mr. Lightcap loaned and installed an ampere hour meter for a short time, which is a great help, for it indicates and registers the amount of electricity taken out of the batteries when not charging, also it registers the amount put in when charging, which will now eliminate any guess work.

The first day's reading showed that 50 ampere hours were taken from the battery during the evening and it registered 65 at breakfast time the next morning. After reducing the cutting off certain lights that we could do without, the second day's reading showed 35 at night and 47½ in the morning after breakfast. It took seven and a half hours running the engine to bring the batteries again to full charge.
Mr. Lightcap rescued a new exhaust valve while he was here, and I am hoping that it will stand up better than the ones that we have put in ourselves. This, however, remains to be seen.

I would like very much to retain the ampere hour meter if you can at all make it possible for us to retain it.

Yours very sincerely,

Principal
Winnipeg, March 4, 1926.

Dear Sir:

In the same way, expenditure which is incurred through the installation of defective or unsuitable mechanical appliances, could hardly be attributed to unsatisfactory supervision on the part of the staff. To illustrate what I mean in this connection, I enclose herewith copies of letters dated February 4th and February 17th addressed by the principal of the Onion Lake School to Mr. Indian Commissioner Graham in connection with the difficulty he was experiencing with the engine installed. This is one instance amongst others which might be mentioned where the installation of an unsuitable instrument is costing not your Department but our Society a very considerable sum of money as no less than 300 gallons of gasoline had been consumed by this engine up to the 3rd of February of this year.

The engine, the Principal writes, though running well is not heavy enough to carry a full load, and I shall be obliged if you will give this matter your careful consideration and arrange for a sufficiently powerful engine to be installed to take its place.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith an account in favour of The Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company, Limited, amounting to $113.80, and to make the following remarks in connection therewith.

On the 4th of February, last, I received a letter from Mr. Ellis, Principal of the Onion Lake School, stating that he was of the opinion that the engine which was operating the lighting plant had not power enough to carry the load. He stated "When charging the batteries between 25 and 30 amperes, the engine gets so hot that the exhaust valve chips off, and besides the heavy knock in the engine, the charge has to be reduced to 10 amperes which means that we are unable to get the batteries over half a charge." He goes on to state a lot of other difficulties which he was having. I replied to this letter saying that there was something radically wrong, and that I was taking the matter up with the Company, which I did, informing them of the contents of Mr. Ellis's letter. I received a reply from them saying that they hardly thought the trouble could be along the lines suggested by Mr. Ellis, and that they were of the opinion that something else was wrong. A lot of detailed information was given to me, which I passed on to Mr. Ellis. After considerable correspondence on the matter I decided that Mr. Ellis could not begin to adjust the difficulty and called upon the Company to send a man up. This was really the only thing that I could do and this bill is the result.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I may point out that in installing the lighting fixtures in this building a number of very large lamps were used, which were quite unnecessary, and when the whole load is on, the plant is naturally carrying a peak load which it was never intended to do.

You will recall that this engine was sent to Duck Lake School where it was thought it would supply power for the lighting of a school at least twice as big as the Onion Lake School. It was found that it could not do this, however, and I transferred it to Onion Lake, thinking that it would answer the purpose there quite well, and I am still of the opinion that if properly handled it can do this.

You would be surprised to see the amount of correspondence I have in this office in connection with lighting plants and other details. It takes up a great deal of my time and I believe that if the Department would insist upon having competent men to run our lighting plants they would save the salaries of these men over and over again. The report on this engine at Onion Lake shows clearly that it was not properly handled.

Dear Mr. Graham:

From information which has been presented to me by the Principal of our Society's School at Onion Lake, as well as through other sources, I am fully convinced that the engine and generator supplied to this institution are incapable of meeting its requirements, and I beg to request that steps be taken at your earliest convenience to have them removed and others installed in their place.

With regard to the kind which would best meet the requirements of this institution I have been advised that a Fairbanks-Morse oil-burning engine of not less than 15 h.p. and a Fairbanks-Morse generator of 7½ K.W. would probably do so with the greatest satisfaction, and I beg to lay this suggestion before you for your favourable consideration.

Inability with the present engine and generator to keep the batteries charged will produce deterioration in the latter and necessitate their renewal at very considerable cost. For this reason I beg to suggest the change of engine and generator at the earliest date possible.

Further, as bills for 828 gallons of gasoline have been presented to our Society since the beginning of this year, I am of the opinion that, under the circumstances,
your Department should help to meet the cost of the same. As the gasoline consumed is fully double what it would have been had the engine and generator been in order, I am of the opinion that 50% of the cost should be borne by your Department and will in due course make application for the same.

Believe me,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 15th inst., number 115-1-5, with regard to the shelving at the new Onion Lake school, Mr. Morrison has been at Onion Lake and knows the situation thoroughly with regard to shelving for the school, and he is of the opinion that ample shelving is provided. I may say that on the 26th of October, I wrote to the Principal of the school, asking him if shelving and cupboards were necessary other than those indicated in the plans, to inform me what he desired to have in addition. He replied to this letter on November 5th, 1925, as follows:

"With regard to shelving it is important that pigeon-hole spaces are made in both clothing rooms on the first floor, for both boys and girls, where the children's clean clothing may be kept after leaving the laundry. The size of each square should be about 12 to 18 inches. Shelving ought to be placed on the ground floor of the linen and bedding rooms. This could be straight shelving without partitions. This would also apply to the kitchen and store-rooms, only far less in number."

On receipt of this information from the Principal stating just what his requirements were, I took steps immediately to have the shelving asked for, placed in the school.

This school which is supposed to have a capacity for one hundred children is better equipped than

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
the File Hills school with an equal number of children, and the Qu'Appelle Industrial School with almost three times the children, for which no demand has been made, and nearly any other school. Dr. Westgate came along after this shelving had been done, and because wardrobes had been put in the dormitories at the Blood school, and possibly one other school, he has called upon us to put in these unnecessary cupboards. Had I known that he was going to insist on having cupboards in the dormitories, I certainly would not have had this shelving done.

I am quite satisfied when the architect drew these plans, he did not consider it necessary to have wardrobes put around these beautiful rooms, disfiguring them, or he would have had the windows placed differently.

I cannot conscientiously recommend that these additional cupboards be placed in the school. Our Inspector is of the same opinion, and I am satisfied that Mr. Ellis never expected them and it is merely because Dr. Westgate came along and stated that he should have them, that he is asking for them. The question now is whether Dr. Westgate's recommendation shall be carried out over the heads of our own officers. Personally I think the matter should end here.

Yours truly,

W. M. Graham,

Sir:

I am now having plans and specifications, also bill of material prepared for the Principal's house and out-buildings at the Onion Lake Boarding School. The amount of money authorized for this purpose, namely $11,000, is small but still I think what is required can be built for this money. We will have to provide accommodation for at least twenty-four head of cattle and ten horses. I am of the opinion that Dr. Westgate expects more than we are prepared to give him in the way of a residence for the Principal. However, I am going to provide a house with four bedrooms, living room, dining room, kitchen and hall and full size basement. This ought to be quite sufficient for Mr. Ellis. I believe he has quite a number of children. His house will cost perhaps twice as much as the house we are building for the Principal at the Gordon School.

While we are forced almost to build a house of this size for Mr. Ellis, I doubt very much if it is a wise policy as there is no telling how long he will be at this Institution as Principal and he might be followed by a man who had no children at all and the house would be far too big for him.

Dr. Westgate has asked me to submit the plans for the house to Mr. Ellis for his approval. I do not think this is necessary. When the plans are on the ground with our Inspector he will listen to any suggestion that Mr. Ellis might want to make for any minor changes, but on the whole I think the general plan is a matter for the Department to decide upon. He is still pressing to have individual lockers established in this school which I cannot see at all necessary, but there is no use discussing this matter with him because I think when we are through with Onion Lake that they will have a pretty complete outfit of buildings, including a good residence for the Principal.

Your obedient servant,

W.McGraham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir:

Re the Onion Lake Water Supply

With reference to the intake pipe from the lake which was not completed last fall, would write that we were pleased to find that there had been no freeze up or any serious interruption of water supply to the school during last winter.

The intake pipe extends into the lake some 200 feet - 75 feet of this is now well protected and precludes any possibility of damage by freezing. We extended the cribbing 30 feet farther out than it was last fall. The intake pipe has a depth of 6 feet of earth over the pipe at the lowest point.

Outside the cribbing here is a row of 5" Tamarack posts driven in and securely spiked to the cribbing. The earth has been well tramped down. Approaching the shore we hauled stone and piled them up the bank to break the wash. The only improvement that might be offered would be to extend the intake pipe 400 ft. farther out which would allow the pipe to rest on land some distance. The depth in the same place is 6 ft. on either side; it is about 12 ft. deep. The above is offered as an alternative in event of any contamination at the present point.

Mr. R. H. Murray, C.E. of the Public Health Dept. supplied me with a sealed container for the purpose of definitely ascertaining the condition of the water. His report is very satisfactory, a copy of which you will find enclosed. For the ten days that we were up there, August 2nd to 12th, we could not detect anything at all peculiar in the test or effects of the taste and effect the water was boiled. They have started to use Chloride of Lime for the purpose of destroying a slight vegetable taste; the results have been very satisfactory indeed. Mr. Murray reports the hardness as a little harder than the Regina water. There are great quantities of water going to waste as there are no eaves troughing on the building. The building would also be better preserved by keeping the splash away from the walls.

You have a first class boarding school with the Dunham heating system, electric lighting, electric pumping unit and gas pumping engine at the lake as well as laundry equipment.

It is my opinion that some person, capable of handling this plant, should be put in charge and made responsible for its maintenance and operation. The principal of the school should not have authority over the appointments, other than to require efficient service. Mr. Ellis is not a mechanic and his interference with a competent man would only result/
only result in disaster.

In conclusion it is a pleasure for me to state that I was very pleased with the general appearance of the school inside and out.

Thanking you, we are,

Yours truly,

BAULIN & SWAYZE.

Per. . . ."E.P. Paulin" (Sgd)

Regina, Sask., Sept. 17th, 1926.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report of an inspection at the Onion Lake Agency:

I left Regina on the morning of Friday, 27th ult. and arrived in Lloydminster on the morning of the 28th. I at once proceeded to get competitive prices in Lloydminster on material required for the erection of the Principal's residence and outbuildings at the Onion Lake Church of England Residential school and drove to Onion Lake late the same evening. On Monday the 30th I went to the school and marked out the site for the buildings and arranged for the excavation of the basement and the freighting of gravel and other material. A heavy rain commenced that evening and continued until Friday, the 3rd instant. As it was impossible to do any driving I checked up the Cash Book, Stores Ledger, Inventories and other records in the office.

Mr. Mayoh arrived on the evening of the 3rd instant. I proceeded with him on Saturday the 4th to examine the local lumber purchased and instructed him regarding the location of the buildings to be erected at the school. On Monday morning I went to Frog Lake Reserve, visited the Day school and went to Cold Lake Reserve for the night. I inspected both reserves at Cold Lake as well as the Day school on Tuesday. On Wednesday morning I interviewed some Indians at Cold Lake and then drove to Keeheewins reserve where we have a new Farming Instructor and left there the same evening, arriving at Onion Lake Agency after midnight. On the 9th and 10th I completed my inspection and gave final instructions in connection with the erection of the buildings and proceeded to Lloydminster Saturday evening, the 11th; where I got final competitive prices on the plumbing, heating etc.

W. Murison,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Murison, on his return from a visit to the Onion Lake Anglican Residential School, reports that eaves troughing has not been provided for the building. This, I fear, is a mistake inasmuch as the water shed from the roof has the effect, in time, of impairing the foundation of the building. I would recommend that authority be granted as soon as possible to have the necessary eaves troughing provided.

He further reports that the furnace chimney is built on a cement footing and extends up the outside of the building and into the wall of the building as far as the interior plaster work. This method of construction weakens the building and the result is that through the settling of either the chimney or the building, the plaster work has cracked so badly that daylight can be seen through the cracks. Men who have had practical experience in the construction of buildings in this cold western country inform me that it is not considered good practice to place chimneys in the walls of buildings. It is considered much more satisfactory to have the chimney built inside the wall as it is conducive to obtaining a better draft. Another point is that if a chimney is built on a solid heavy cement foundation, it remains rigid while the natural settling of the building causes the walls to crack. On the other hand if the chimney is not on a solid footing, the settling of the chimney will have the same effect on the walls. It appears to me that it would be sound practice if, in the preparation of future plans, this factor were taken into consideration and provision made so that the chimney would not project into the walls of the building; in other words, the chimney to be a separate unit, so placed that the cutting of the walls would be avoided.

Another matter the Inspector reports is in connection with the discharge drain from the septic tank. The sewer is discharged into an open trench 120 ft. long; this trench, owing to the sandy nature of the soil, has settled in and does not permit of a free flow of the fluid. Field tile should be provided and this trench filled in. The work of laying this tile is not difficult and could be done by the School Staff. I think that this matter should be attended to before freeze up.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:
