Dear Mr. Scott:

I enclose herewith a copy of my letter addressed to Mr. Commissioner Graham on the 25th ultimo relative to the abnormal amount of gasoline consumed by the engine operating the lighting system at our Onion Lake School, and requested that as an abnormal consumption was due to the installation of an unsuitable plant, fifty percent of the cost be borne by your Department. In reply to this letter Mr. Graham wrote on Oct. 28th stating that he had forwarded a copy of my letter to your Department. I have now received from him another letter dated Nov. 16th in which he informs me that he is in receipt of a letter from the Department stating that they can see no reason why the usual practice should be departed from with regard to meeting the cost of the gasoline for the lighting and pumping plant at Onion Lake. This means that my request has not been granted, and I am writing again for the specific purpose of having it reconsidered. The difficulty which the lighting plant installed at the Onion Lake School has caused the School management has been the subject of correspondence with Mr. Indian Commissioner Graham for sometime. On the 14th of April the Rev. H. Ellis, Principal of the School, submitted to him a statement in this connection and received an acknowledgment of the same in a letter written by the Commissioner on April 21st, who stated, in part, as follows:

"I regret very much that you have had so much trouble and difficulty with the engine and I am getting in touch with the manufacturers with a view to having the engine definitely put into proper working order or changed".

About that time two engine experts visited the School but nothing was done then—or has anything been done since to remedy the defects.
One of the above experts called on me in Winnipeg after his return and informed me that the plant would never give satisfaction or meet the requirements of the School. I then wrote to the Commissioner on May 6th and forwarded a copy of my letter to you for your information. The Commissioner replied to my letter on May 10th. His letter reads as follows:

"I have your letter of the 6th, with reference to the engine and generator at present in use at the Onion Lake School. I appreciate the difficulties that have been encountered and this has also been a source of considerable trouble and anxiety to me. The equipment was first bought for use in a school twice as large as that at Onion Lake and there are those who state that it would have met requirements at that school. However, the Department decided to make use of it at Onion Lake. There are those again who claim that it should be also efficient for the work it is required to perform at the Onion Lake School. However, I am daily expecting a report from the Company who made the installation and in view of the conflicting opinions which I have received, I feel I should not make any recommendation to the Department until I receive this report. The matter will be dealt with promptly on receipt of this."

I wrote to him again on the 4th of Oct., urging that steps be taken as soon as possible to have both the engine and dynamo replaced by those of greater power and better quality and stated as I had done in my letter of May 6th, that a bill for the extra gasoline consumed would be presented in due course. The plant is not satisfactory and I doubt very much whether it can ever be made to do the work it is expected to do at this institution. It has already been a very great expense to our Society and a very great worry and inconvenience to the School management and staff. They have been left at times for days without light while repairs have been effected, and subjected to annoyances which should not be laid upon them.

I respectfully submit, therefore, that my request for reimbursement of at least half of the cost of the gasoline consumed is but fair and reasonable, and I beg to request that you will give it your sympathetic consideration.

I also beg to request that the engine and dynamo be replaced by others which are capable of meeting the requirements of the School. In my letter of May 6th addressed to Mr. Commissioner Graham, and a copy of which was forwarded to you, I suggested that a Fairbanks-Morse Oil Burning engine of not less than 15 h.p. and a Fairbanks-Morse Generator of 7½ k.w. would probably give the greatest satisfaction, and I am still of the same opinion."
I commend these two matters to your prompt and sympathetic consideration and beg to remain,

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Scott:

In reply to your letter of Nov. 24th (115-1-5), requesting information with regard to the qualifications of the engineer at the Onion Lake School, I beg to state that the Principal of this School in a letter dated Nov. 18th, 1925, writes in part, as follows:

"In reply to your letter of Nov. 12th, in which you include a copy of the telegram received from the Department with reference to the appointment of a competent man to operate and run the mechanical part of the new School, I have to inform you that I am of the opinion Mr. Mitchell is quite competent to handle this work. He has operated gas engines for the past 16 years. He has run a gas tractor for 2 years. He has owned and operated a steam boiler at Mulvihill, Manitoba, in connection with a milling business there. He has had a fair experience in electrical work. He is a good mechanic. Since the contractors left he and I have operated the plant, filling the storage and compression tanks, and charging the batteries to the satisfaction of the building inspector, Mr. Hamilton of Regina, Sask. He has a thorough knowledge of the system........."

In addition to the above I may state that Mr. Mitchell the engineer who is a man of 37 years of age, was educated in England at the College of Preceptors and studied science for one year at St. Lawrence College, Ramsgate. He is well educated, more than ordinarily efficient as a mechanic, and thoroughly trustworthy. He is severing his connection with the Onion Lake School at the end of this month as he has a wife and four children and we are unable to accommodate so large a family. When I spoke to one of
The experts referred to in my letter of Nov. 17th about the competency of Mr. Mitchell to handle all the mechanical appliances at the School, he gave it as his opinion that Mr. Mitchell was fully competent, but that no engineer no matter how competent, could make the engine and dynamo at the Onion Lake School render the service required. Our Society has another fully qualified engineer (unmarried) ready to take his place.

With regard to Mr. Commissioner Graham's reference to the extra load placed on the engine because of the water connection with the barn, I beg to state that so far as I have been informed no extra load has yet been placed on the engine in the way suggested. That the water system has been extended to the barn I am well aware, but the extension having been made as late as October, I have not yet learned that it has been utilized. In a letter dated Oct. 2nd and addressed by the Principal to the local Indian Agent, I find the following remarks in this connection:

"As the cost of laying the water on at the new barn now being erected at the new Onion Lake C.E. Indian Residential School only means the expense of digging a trench 250 ft. and the purchasing of a few reducing nipples and elbows and a galvanized iron trough, there being sufficient piping on hand to run the entire length of the water line from the main school building to the new barn, I herewith ask the Department to permit and authorize this work to be done.... The cost of laying on the water while the barn is being built is so small as compared to that after the building is completed, I trust that the Department will give this favourable consideration and approve of the work being done now".

As the complaints with regard to the engine date from the beginning of this year and have been coming in almost continuously ever since, I am unable to see that the extension of the water system to the barn can in any way be held responsible for its inefficiency to meet the needs of the School. I am satisfied in my own mind from what I have seen and heard that the engine is too small to meet the needs of this institution, and I trust that the remedial action suggested in my letter of the 17th instant may be undertaken.

Believe me,
Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

TERW/JP

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of April 28th in reply to my letter of April 21st, and note with some surprise and regret your decision not to meet the bill from the Lloydminster Co-operative Association for certain repairs and equipment required at our Onion Lake School, as the greater part of the bill represented expenditure incurred in connection with the lighting and water systems at this School and about which I wrote to the Deputy Superintendent General on the 17th of last November and again on Nov. 29th. The defects in the plant installed were chiefly responsible for that particular part of the expenditure in question and also for the consumption of not less than 2,550 gallons of gasoline between Jan. 1st and Oct. 1st of last year. The total cost of this to our Society including freight charges was $887.89. From the 1st of Oct. to the end of the year other bills for oil and gasoline amounted to not less than $443.60, making a total, at least of $1,321.49 which was paid out by our Society. This abnormally high amount was due to operating the unsuitable engine and generator installed by your Department in connection with the lighting and water systems. In my letter of Nov. 17th last, I made what seemed to me and to our Commission the very reasonable request that under the circumstances referred to above, your Department should share equally with our Society the heavy cost of the gasoline consumed. This request does not appear to have been granted, and in consequence our Society has been obliged to meet a much heavier cash expenditure than they could reasonably be expected to do. Our Commission have felt it keenly that their reasonable request for cooperation from your Department in the meeting of this abnormally heavy expenditure was not granted, and the further action now taken by your Department in declining to meet the bill for repairs has intensified...
This feeling, and they are beginning to wonder how it will be possible for them to maintain and operate this school without some further financial assistance. In preparing their estimates for next year they find that even with a slight increase in the per capita grant they will still have a heavy cash expenditure to make over and above all cash receipts including the per capita earnings. In endeavouring to discover a way whereby this condition of things could be remedied, they concluded that the best, if not the only course to pursue, was to have the enrollment increased from 80 to 100 pupils, and I was directed by them to refer this matter to you and ask that an enrollment of this number of pupils be sanctioned immediately. The building has a capacity of 100 pupils and the Principal is of the opinion that he will have no difficulty in securing this number. I respectfully beg to request, therefore, that you give this matter your most careful and favourable consideration, and furnish me with the authorization requested at your earliest convenience.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.O.C.

Dear Sir:

I presented your letter of May 17th (115-1-5) to our Commission at a meeting held on the 14th inst. and was instructed to inform you that in their opinion the only satisfactory way in which our Society could be provided with the financial assistance required to operate their Onion Lake School without embarrassing overdrafts, is through an increase in the capacity of the main School building. It stands at present at 80 pupils, and if increased to 125 pupils the annual increase in the per capita earnings would furnish the necessary financial relief. Our Commission realise that such increase may not be possible during the current fiscal year, but they can see no possibility of a satisfactory and permanent solution of the problem until such action has been taken. Our Society has been made well aware of the fact that Residential Schools with an enrolment of 100 pupils or less are practically incapable of being properly staffed and operated without a deficit, on the present per capita basis, and it is for this reason that they desire Schools with a capacity of not less than 125 pupils to be built in preference to any others. It is recommended and requested, therefore, that as a measure towards securing the permanent financial relief required for our Onion Lake School, the capacity of this school be increased, not later than during the next fiscal year, from 80 to 125 pupils.

As a measure towards providing the immediate relief required, our Commission instructed me to suggest the following:

1. To provide all the milk cows required instead of having half of these provided at the expense of our Society.

2. To meet the abnormal expenditure incurred through the installation of an unsuitable lighting system as set forth in my letter of Oct. 25th, 1926, addressed to Mr. Commissioner Graham, a copy of which is enclosed herewith.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your No. 11f-1-5 of the 25th ultimo in regard to furnishing you with a copy of the expert's report on the Onion Lake C. of R. Indian Residential School plant. I regret that this was overlooked but as a matter of fact I did not secure a report in writing but made a personal visit at the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company's office in Winnipeg and reviewed the situation with them. I had an earlier report from one of the Company's experts stating that the generator was of 5000 watt capacity and could thus take care of 125 -40 watt lamps or double that number of 20 watt lamps, but that the number of lights in use was 172 and it was clear, therefore, the 10 H.P. engine had not sufficient reserve to meet the requirements of the school. You will remember that the engine was previously installed at the Duck Lake School but exchanged for one of larger capacity. It was hoped that the smaller size would meet the requirements at Onion Lake, hence the reason for shipping it there.

In addition to the earlier report from the Company's expert which I wished to have verified, there were frequent complaints from the school and it seemed advisable to install a larger plant for which I secured authority under cover of a letter from the Secretary, dated the 19th October last. I regret I overlooked your request for the expert's report, but this as I state was a verbal one given to me at a personal interview in Winnipeg. The latest report I have had in regard to the new engine is that it is working satisfactorily.

In regard to the old 10 H.P. engine which was displaced, the Reverend Principal asked if he might keep it as the school propose to erect a power line to the pump house so as to dispense with the gas engine there during the cold winter months, and the old engine could be utilized in its place. He also intimated that it would act as an auxiliary when repairs were needed. He added that the engine could be re-erected without any further expense to the Department. I had intended and indeed had given instructions to have the engine shipped to Regina so that it might be on hand if needed elsewhere. Sir:

When at the Onion Lake Agency recently, Inspector W. Murison looked into several matters to which my attention had been drawn, and has submitted a report.

One matter was in reference to the ventilation of the barn which was erected last year, and the installation of the stanchions for the cattle. These matters Inspector Murison has satisfactorily adjusted.

A request was made by the Principal of the School to be supplied with granaries and these are no doubt required. The present requirements will be met by furnishing the School with one large permanent granary in which there will be sufficient room to enable the School to clean and pickle grain under cover. A building 20'x30' would satisfy this need. A smaller portable granary, 14'x16', might also be furnished. The mechanic at the School should be able to supervise their erection and the cost of the two will be approximately $100.00. Inspector Murison reports that a root house is needed and that the School has not as yet been provided with one. The cost of this would be approximately $600.00. Will you please advise me if the Department will provide funds for the erection of the buildings mentioned.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

It was reported to me
It was reported to me that the tubing running through the hot water tank at the School was very badly corroded. Inspector Morrison has verified this and reports that the piping will need to be renewed. Galvanized piping should be utilized and the cost of this, together with a pipe wrench, will approximate $40.00. I am advised by a responsible firm of plumbers here that the piping in use in this hot water boiler is likely to corrode very frequently owing to the hard nature of the water and renewals might be necessitated every year or two. Will you please advise me if the Department will provide the necessary funds to renew the piping referred to.

Inspector Morrison also enquired as to whether we could purchase suitable Holsteins and I understand that suitable grade Holstein cows can be bought for about $100.00 each, probably less. I am writing to the Agent to tell him that he may buy eight at a price not exceeding $800.00. I may say that Inspector Morrison saw one or two animals belonging to a small herd which is for sale, comprising ten females and one pure bred bull, at a price of $775.00. As Inspector Morrison thinks this would be a good purchase, I have told the Agent that if, after he has inspected the whole herd, he is of the opinion that it would be advisable to make the purchase, he may do so. I trust this arrangement will be satisfactory to the Department.

Dear Sir,

I enclose for your information a copy of a letter just received from the Principal of our Society's School at Onion Lake, Sask. From this you will see that he is very deeply concerned about a root-house and granaries to store this year's produce from the farm and garden. The situation appears to me to be so urgent that I feel it my duty to ask you to give it the earliest possible consideration.

In the list of requirements which our Society submitted to your Department for inclusion in your estimates for this year, contained, amongst others the following items:

A root-house, estimated cost $600.
A granary 30ft. x 18ft. estimated cost $250.

I am not unaware of the fact that a heavy expenditure has been incurred by your Department in connection with this school this year. At the same time you will recollect from recent correspondence namely my letter to you dated June 20 and your replies dated May 17 and July 11 (Nos 115-1-5) and Mr. Scott's letter dated June 24 (No. 115-1-5) that our Society has been obliged to meet an unexpectedly heavy expenditure at this school also and that we cannot by any means afford to run the risk of sustaining the heavy losses referred to by the Principal in his letter. I shall be obliged therefore if you will give this matter immediate attention and take steps to have the root-house and the granary erected in time to receive the season's crops.

I remain,
Your obedient servant,

Sir,

In response to a circular issued from this Office with reference to fire protection at our various Residential Schools I have received a letter from the Reverend Principal of the Church of England School at Onion Lake, pointing out that while the equipment provided is adequate the fire escapes are often rendered dangerous by the dropping thereon of icicles from the roof which freeze on the steps. This condition would be obviated if the building were provided with eavestroughing. I have pointed out this necessity before at some of our other Residential Schools. Eavestroughing is provided on all large buildings in this Western Country and should be provided for in all our buildings. I shall be glad if the Department would authorize the placing of eavestroughing at this School.

Statement of Gilbert Saskamoose, Age 17 years in connection with an outbreak of fire at the Anglican Indian School, Onion Lake, Sask., on Friday evening at 8 o'clock p.m. Feb. 10th. 1928.

First I went down to the Pump House
Then I went into the Engine Room
I sent George Peschow up to bed
After I put wood in the Furnace
I went up to ask Miss Williams for the keys to open the wash room. I was going to wash my face and hands before going to bed.
I took the gas in a jam tin and I went up to bed.
Miss Williams checked on the dormitory.
I put gasoline on the fire escape steps.
I went to George Peschows bed and I told him to go out of the window.
I went down to the fire escape to the bottom. I took the gas and went up to the little boys dormitory window.
I then went into the attic from the little boys dormitory. George came with me.
I put gasoline on the peak of the roof.
I then lit a match.
I came down the same way as I went up, i.e. through the little boys dormitory window, down the fire escape and into the big boys' dormitory through the window again.
George followed me all the time.
I went to bed and after I smelt smoke. I tried to open the big boys' dormitory. Miss Williams opened the door and I went down to see Mr. Howe.
I told Mr. Howe that there was a fire on top of the roof.

Questioned by the Principal why he did it.

George told me to do it. I had not thought of this before.

Signed:

Gilbert Saskamoose

Witness:

D. E. Spooner.
Statement of George Peechow, Age 17 years
in connection with an outbreak of fire at the
Anglican Indian School, Onion Lake, Sask., on
Friday evening at 8 o'clock p.m. Feb. 10th 1928.

I was in the Engine Room when Mr. Ellis went to
Onion Lake.
Gilbert then told me to go to bed.
I was outside the Engine Room when I suggested
to Gilbert to set fire to the school.
I asked Gilbert if he would say Yes.
He said Yes, i.e., Gilbert.
He told me to go to bed.
I went to bed. I looked through the window and
I saw Gilbert down at the bottom of the fire escape.
I asked him to get the gasoline. He had it already.
Gilbert then came up to bed. I went to my bed.
We went out then through the big boys' dormitory window
by the fire escape. We went through the window. Then
went up to the attic. I followed Gilbert. He put some
gasoline on the roof inside. Gilbert lit the match
and we came down. We went through the little boys
dormitory window and to the big boys dormitory the same
way as we went up.
We then got into bed. I did not go to sleep.
I took off my clothes off. After we lit the fire
I told all the big boys that we both had set fire to
the school. That is the reason why all the boys
were dressed when the alarm was given.

Sir,

I have to report about fires which have broken out at the Anglican Indian Residential School here during the past few days.

About 10 p.m. on the night of the 6th instant, I received word from the Rev. H. Ellis, principal at the school, that fire had broken out in the engine room there, but that it had been successfully put out. Early the next morning I drove to the school to inspect the damage caused by the fire, and to endeavour to find out its origin, and, after investigating I concluded that it had been caused by a short circuit in the wires in the battery room. With the exception of the destruction of the batteries, very little damage was done. This fire was reported to the Indian Commissioner and instructions received from him.

Just after the burning of the Roman Catholic School and I had returned home, about 11 p.m. last night, an alarm was received that the Anglican School was on fire. This school is about six miles from the Agency and, before we left to drive there, another message was received stating that the fire had been put out and that no help was needed. This morning I visited the school to see what damage had been done, and found that a small hole had been burned through the peak of the roof. I also discovered that two of the biggest boys, George Petchow and Gilbert Sackamoose, both aged 17 years, had deliberately set fire to the building. I enclose herewith statements made by them, taken down by the Rev. H. Ellis.

I questioned the youths and they both admitted their action, and added that they had been thinking and talking about setting fire to the school for some time. Although they both deny having started the fire in the engine room a few days previously, suspicion pointed towards them, as they both work in the engine room at times.

I explained to the lads the enormity of their offence, and asked Mr. Ellis to keep them under strict surveillance for the present, which he has consented to do. I am reluctant to hand them over to the police to be dealt with, without instructions from the Department to that effect; but they are almost men, and certainly should be punished. Kindly instruct me.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I beg to confirm my telegram of the 7th instant, reading as follows:

"Fire broke out in engine room at Anglican School last night. Was successfully put out and very little damage done excepting batteries completely destroyed. Please wire me authority to have engine room re-wired so as to restore light to basement."

and you reply:

"Re. fire damage you may have necessary wiring done in engine room. Will expect full report by mail."

About 10 p.m. on the night of the 6th instant, I received a telephone call from the Rev. Ellis Principal at the Anglican School, informing me that the engine room at the school had been on fire, and that they had managed to put it out. After ascertaining that I could do nothing for him that night, I promised to be at the school early the next morning. Accordingly, the next morning I drove to the school and inspected the damage caused by the fire and tried to find out its origin.

Nobody could tell me just how the fire started, but it is quite evident that it started in the battery room, probably from a short circuit, as the place where the fire shows evidence of having burnt the fiercest is in the middle of the shelves on which the batteries stand. It appears that Mr. Howe, the engineer, inspected the running of the plant immediately after supper at 6.0 p.m., and then went to the Principal's residence. Between 7.30 and 8.0 p.m. the farming

Instructor.
Instructor, Mr. Spooner, went to the engine room for the purpose of removing his farm clothing, and could not get in because the place was full of smoke; he then gave the alarm and Mr. Ellis attempted to ring the fire alarm, but could not do so as the wires were burnt. In the meantime a hose was being placed in readiness and the water turned on. By this time flames were seen to be issuing from the battery room, the window of which was taken out and the water projected through it to the flames which, after a short time, were successfully subdued.

Regarding the damage done. Most of the batteries, of which there are 56 in use, are either cracked or broken a lot of the wiring in both the battery and engine rooms is destroyed; the wood work in both places is charred, and the packing around a lot of the piping in the engine room is burnt off.

In my opinion the only thing that saved the whole building from going up is the fact that the spaces between the studdings on the lower floor are filled with concrete. The fire so scorched this studding in the chapel above the battery room, that a lot of the woodwork has been badly scorched there, had it been possible for a draft to carry the flames between these studdings the whole building would have gone.

I have had an electrician visit the school, to see that there were no dangerous short circuits left by the fire having broken the wires; and also to find out what he would require in the way of replacement material.

Yours truly,

REPORT re
George Peechowe - Indian School Boy,
Onion Lake, Sask.

While on patrol at Frog Lake Indian Reserve I communicated with Mr. L. Turner by telegraph at Onion Lake, and patrolled the same day to Onion Lake with police team.

Mr. Turner informed me that he was awaiting instructions from the Department of Indian Affairs as to certain boys at the Anglican Mission School at Harlan, who had confessed to setting fire to the school there.

On February 10th 1928 the Roman Catholic Mission was burned to the ground, together with the Church, and the same evening a fire was discovered in the roof of the new Anglican Mission six miles south, but this one was soon got under control.

Owing to suspicious circumstances, a confession was secured from a boy named George Peechowe, aged 16, who was working at the Mission, that he had set fire to the building.

Mr. Turner has written to the Department asking what action to take, stating that he would recommend that the boy be punished, but that he would not take any criminal action through the Police until the wishes of the Department were known.

He has instructed Mr. Ellis, the Principal of the School to keep the lad and another one concerned in it under strict control until such times as instructions are received from the Department.

A further report will be submitted whenever an investigation is made as to the various outbreaks of fire in the district. It is my opinion that there is some collusion between the boys who were concerned in the fire at the Anglican Mission and the boys at the Catholic Mission who more than likely started the fire there.

Dear Sir:

On the 7th ultimo a telegram was despatched to you from this office informing you that a fire had broken out on the previous evening in the battery room of the engine house at our Society's School at Onion Lake, when the batteries were completely destroyed, but no harm done to the main school building. As a full report in connection with this fire was submitted to your Department through Mr. Turner, the local Indian Agent, I do not consider it necessary to enter into any further details in connection with the same in this letter, except to state that in the opinion of the Principal the fire was caused by a short circuit of the wires, and to request that provision be made both in the battery room and the engine house for better ventilation, in order that all gas fumes may immediately escape. I am making this request as the Principal has given it as his opinion that the fire from the short circuit of the wires ignited the fumes which had collected, and is otherwise unable to explain how the fire could have spread so rapidly.

While writing in connection with this fire, I very much regret to have to report that a second fire broke out at this school on Friday, Feb. 10th. Upon investigation the Principal discovered that this fire had been started by two of the older boys, Gilbert Saskamoose, a boy age 17 years, and George Peechow, another boy of the same age. As a full report on the outbreak of this fire, including statements of the boys responsible for its origin, have already been forwarded to you through your local representative, it does not appear to me to be necessary to enter into further detail in this connection in this letter. On February 27th 1928, I received a telegram from Mr. L. Turner, Indian Agent at Onion Lake, making for my attendance at Onion Lake as soon as possible in the above connection; instructions having been received by Mr. Turner from the Department of Indian Affairs.

I patrolled the same day with Police team horse 2030 and hired team horse, from Lloydminster to Onion Lake Indian Reserve, and by request of the Indian Agent made preparations to prosecute the above named Indian Boy who had assisted another Indian Boy to set fire to the Anglican Indian Residential School near Onion Lake, on the 10th of February 1928.

I patrolled to Harlan and interviewed D.H. Cameron Esq., J.P., who refused to act on the preliminary hearing of a charge against this boy owing to the age of the boy, Gilbert Sacknosee, who is only 17; until the proper authority should be secured for him to assume the position of a Judge of a Juvenile Court.

Mr. Cameron consulted Chapter 108 of the R.S.eited as the Juvenile Delinquent's Act, 1906.C 40.§ 1, and as the definition of "child" is "a boy or girl apparently or actually under the age of eighteen years," he held that he could not act without further authority in the matter.

I returned to Lloydminster Detachment, and by telephone received instructions from the Officer Commanding "F" Division Prince Albert, to advise Mr. Cameron to state the difficulty by night letter to the Attorney General for Saskatchewan; which he refused to do, however; taking the attitude that this was the duty of the Prosecution; so, acting for the Indian Agent I sent a night letter to the Attorney General for his advice.

Mr. L. Turner, the Indian Agent received a reply from the Attorney General, stating that the boys, Gilbert Sacknosee and George Peechowe, his companion could be prosecuted in the ordinary way as they were over the age of 16 years; and this ruling being satisfactory to Mr. D.H. Cameron, J.P.; I patrolled again to Onion Lake and Harlan on the 5th instant to prosecute.

At the Anglican Indian Residential School, near Onion Lake, on the 5th instant, Mr. Turner, Indian Agent, representing the Department of Indian Affairs, laid an information against Gilbert Sacknosee, under Section 31 of the Criminal Code of Canada.
A warrant to apprehend the above named boy was handed to me, and acting in harmony with the wishes of the Department of Indian Affairs, I publicly arrested him.

On March 5th 1928, at Onion Lake Anglican Indian Residential School, Gilbert Sackmose, school boy aged 17 was charged that he did, on the 10th day of February 1928 at or near Onion Lake Saskatchewan, unlawfully, willfully, without legal justification or excuse, and without colour of right, set fire to a certain building, to wit; the Anglican Indian Residential School, there situate, the property of the Department of Indian Affairs, contrary to Section 511 of the Criminal Code of Canada.

Several School boys; Mr Frank Rowe, Engineer employed in the School; and Mr L. Turner, Indian Agent; gave evidence. The evidence showed that at about eight o'clock on the night of February 10th 1928, the junior boys including the accused were located in their Dormitory, in accordance with the rules of the Institution, for the night. The accused in company with another boy named George Pochowe, had used the fire escape from their window to make their way to the ground, secure gasoline, and a brass and hit, and by going through the junior boys' Dormitory reached the attic; bored a hole and poured gasoline out on to the roof, which they set fire to with a match.

Having warned the other boys that they were about to set fire to the building, they waited till the fire had gained dangerous headway and then had given the alarm to a matron in charge of the junior boys' dormitory who gave the general alarm and the boys had rushed the house to such good effect that in twenty minutes after the alarm sounded the fire was out; and subsequent examination disclosed about $15.00 damage to the roof.

Mr Turner's evidence included a voluntary statement from the boys, and when warned by the Court and asked if they wished to make a statement, said that all the evidence given, was true, and that they wished to have their trial as soon as possible.

The Accused who admitted actually starting the fire with the assistance and advice of George Pochowe was by the Court ordered committed to Jail to await trial at the next Court of competent jurisdiction.

I escorted the accused to Lloydminster on the 6th instant, and with a view to economy and in compliance with the wishes of the accused for a speedy trial, I communicated by telephone with F.G. Atkinson, Agent for the Attorney General at Battleford, who advised me that he would endeavour to arrange to have the accused appear before His Honour Judge Buckles as soon as possible for election as to trial.

I escorted the accused from Lloydminster by train to North Battleford on the 7th instant and in the afternoon to Battleford. The same afternoon the accused Gilbert Sackmose appeared before His Honour Judge Buckles at the District Court Judges' Original Court and elected for speedy trial.

Charged as above with setting fire to the School, the accused pleaded "Guilty" and when questioned by the Court stated that he had set fire to the school in order to obtain his liberty from the School.
His Honour inquired of me as to the previous character of the accused and his companion, their parents, and the view taken of the matter by the Department of Indian Affairs; and from information I was enabled to furnish, having made inquiries of the Rev. H. Ellis, the Principal of the School, as to their character, and of Mr. Turner, Indian Agent, as to the view taken of the matter by the Department, which was a serious one.

His Honour pointed out the very serious nature of the crime committed, stating that he would, on account of their youth give them a light sentence, but that owing to the very serious nature of the crime he did not think it would be in the interests of justice for him to give them a suspended sentence.

He therefore sentenced the accused Gilbert Sackmoose and his companion George Peschowe to five months imprisonment with hard labour; with the added requirement that they should report to the Lloydminster Detachment of the R.C.M.P. Police on release from Jail and at intervals of two months for one year thereafter.

I escorted the accused Gilbert Sackmoose and his companion (charged jointly) George Peschowe, to the Jail at Prince Albert, arriving there on the 8th instant in P.M., and returning to Lloydminster in the early morning of the 10th instant.

A further investigation may be made of the movements of the accused Gilbert Sackmoose and his companion George Peschowe, who may have been concerned in another outbreak of fire that occurred at the A.I.R. School a few days previous to the fire which was the subject of the charge in this report; and in the event of any connection being found a further report will be submitted.

Nothing in the evidence would indicate that there was any connection whatever with the cause of other fires in the same building or the other Schools in the district.

ONION LAKE C. of R. RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I visited this school on March the 16th and made a general inspection of the school buildings and equipment. I found the school buildings clean and tidy and the children presented a healthy appearance, with one exception, a girl who was under the care of the Doctor at the Infirmary. The building appeared quite comfortable and I am told that they have no difficulty in heating it during the coldest weather.

Fire Protection - There is a stand pipe at each end of the hall in the main building with hose connections on each floor. I tested the hose, by turning on the water and found it in good condition. There are also two fire extinguishers kept on each floor for emergency use. A large cement storage tank, which is kept full, insures a supply of water and in case of fire they do not depend entirely on the pumping system at the lake. An electric pump is used to fill the pressure tank and is working very satisfactorily. The engine, which was provided to pump water from the lake, is worn out and has been discarded and they are now using the farm engine for that purpose. I am informed that this engine, when supplied, was a second hand one and has never given satisfaction. The water system was put to a test twice during the month of February and stood up well. A fire broke out in the boiler room on February the 6th and did considerable damage to the roof, but was successfully put out. I made a close examination with a view to finding out the cause and think it quite possible that a short circuit in the wiring may have been responsible for it. A suspicion has since arisen that the fire may have been of an incendiary nature in as much as the school was deliberately set on fire on February the 10th by two boys who worked in the engine room. On the latter
occasion the boys climbed into the attic with a small tin of gasoline, which they threw on the interior of the roof and set fire to it. This fire was put out before it had gained much headway. The boys, namely, George Pechow and Joe Sacamoose, pleaded guilty and are now serving five months in the Prince Albert jail.

Fire Escapes - Iron stairs with landings at each floor are provided at the back of each wing. I noted that the means of access to these escapes are convenient and the windows, which are secured with hooks on the inside, can be quickly removed from the interior, while they cannot be opened from the outside. I tested the fire alarm and found it in good order. Regular fire drill has also been a feature at this school and the children, I am informed, were not excited when the fire broke out.

Staff - I noted that some changes in the staff had been made since my last visit. I was much more pleased with conditions at this school than I have been on former occasions. I was present at the children's evening meal and noted that they had an ample supply of good wholesome food. Meat is given to most of them twice a day and they are given all the milk they care to drink. They have nineteen milch cows and were milking eight at the time of my visit.

Farming - Their wheat crop, 40 acres which was sown on new land, was badly frozen and they only threshed 90 bushels. I saw a sample of this grain and it was really not good feed. They threshed 2,400 bushels of oats, which were a good sample from 72 acres and 360 bushels of barley from 14 acres. Their garden was a complete failure, owing to frost and their supply of potatoes have had to be purchased.

Outbuildings - The barn, about which some complaint was made last year regarding ventilation, has been very comfortable during the past winter. The suggestions,
which I made last year, have been partially carried out. The openings between the joist have been filled in and as a consequence steam has not collected to any extent on the roof. Material has been supplied to box in the ventilators to the roof and the Principal assured me that he will have this work done by his staff. I examined the hay carrier and found the trouble was not caused through the supporting brackets being nailed, as I found the supporting brackets all firmly in place. The difficulty was that the end pulley was attached to a 2 x 6, spiked to the studding. This should have been bolted, as it happened this 2 x 6 was wrenched from its place and the strain came directly on the track, one section of which was badly bent. In consequence, several of the cast iron clips were snapped off. These can easily be replaced and the track put in proper shape at very little expense. The stanchions, which were reported as practically useless by Canon Westgate, were not installed in accordance with specifications, being about five inches lower than called for in the plans. However, the remark that they were practically useless was absolutely unjustified by facts. I had the cows rounded into the stable and made a thorough and close examination and found that they were perfectly comfortable. The Principal had to agree with me in this connection. The stanchions have been in use for two years, however, instructions have been given to install them in accordance with plans. In my opinion, the expense is unnecessary at the present time. Two new granaries have been added since my last visit and a very fine cement root house has been provided. This root house, however, has not been used during the past winter, as they had nothing to put in it. A hen house and implement shed complete the outbuildings. They require a hog pen, I noted a big improvement in tidiness about the premises. I have already reported in connection with the drain from the Principal's house.

The Inspector assures me that the cattle have not been suffering any discomfort.

I then called upon the Manager of the Ontario Wind Engine & Pump Company, who was surprised to learn of this report and had no hesitation whatever in giving a Declaration, and Mr. Hamilton, Building Inspector, who was on the job, is satisfied that the engine was a new one. In the face of this we have a report from absolutely incompetent men to the effect that a second-hand engine was supplied. The trouble here is that—

Dear Sir:

I have to bring to your notice that the chemical action of the water pumped from the lake at Onion Lake is destroying the black iron piping in the water and heating systems. We can protect the boilers, no doubt, by using Soda Ash, (14lbs to a 1000 gallons of water) but unless a soft water system is installed very soon, I fear that many of the pipes on all the pressure lines will have to be changed.

Last summer it was necessary because of the chemical action to change the tubes in the hot water tank. We have now located three places where the iron piping has been eaten through.

By installing a soft water system now, will save a very heavy expenditure in changing other lines.

Will you kindly bring this to the notice of the Department in order that they consider the situation before it is too late.

Yours very truly,

Sir:-

With reference to Department No. 115-1-5, dated the 17th December last, on the subject of providing eavestroughing and down pipe at the Onion Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School, I have to advise you that I have been in correspondence with the Indian Agent and he informs me that two firms who have submitted prices both affirm that it would not be practicable to provide the outlet for the rain water into the present storage tank, which I at first supposed could be used for the purpose. One firm offers to provide eavestroughing and rain water tank complete for the sum of $3,441.00, but this sum appears to be excessive. The other firm offers to provide the eavestroughing and supply and install the drain from the building to the proposed site of a rain water tank for the sum of $866.25. Mr. Turner is of the opinion that, if this latter work were done, he could arrange to install a rain water tank 16' x 13' x 8' for an amount not exceeding $800.00, bringing the total cost to $1,666.25 approximately.

I think that the eavestroughing should be supplied, but I cannot at the present time recommend the added expenditure, and I think the question of the permanent disposal of the water should be left over until an Inspector next visits the Agency. For the present, therefore, I would recommend that the eavestroughing be supplied and installed at the price of $394.90, the figure given in my letter to you of the 10th December last.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

On your return to Ottawa, you promised me to look into the question of shelving and sewing machines to be supplied to the Onion Lake C.E. Indian Residential School.

Regarding the sewing machines, I am still at a loss to know why these should have been struck off the list by the Department, when they have been supplied to all other Indian Residential schools. These were included again in my list of requirements in the 1927 estimates, asking for two ordinary machines and one Jumbo tailor machine, but to date they have not been supplied.

Regarding the shelving, you will remember that I spoke about the meagre amount the Department allowed which was $250.00 to furnish the shelving when the school was first opened. The actual amount of shelving for this amount was 1500 ft. Speaking to Mr. Hamilton, the Inspector of Construction recently, he confirmed this amount, which left nothing for cupboards and the food store rooms. With your knowledge of Institutional life and the equipment required for the running of the same, I feel sure that you will agree that a serious inadvertence has been made.

On October 20th 1925 you instructed Mr. Commissioner Graham to arrange to have whatever shelving and cupboards built other than the plans indicated. The grant allowed by the Commissioner was so small that the shelving of two store rooms and cupboards for the sewing room and because the Infirmary was then occupied as a residence, these had to be left off the list.
I personally enquired at the new R.S. School at Onion Lake and find that the amount for shelving and cupboards put in at that Institution other than their plans specified exceeded the $2300.00 mark.

Comparing their grant allowed with the $250.00 we were allowed, you will readily see that there has been a mistake made in our requirements.

Cupboards and shelving for the Infirmary, Sewing room and the food store room are urgently required, and I would be obliged if you will grant this to be done with the least possible delay.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

P.S. Speaking to Mr. Indian Agent Turner today he states that the cupboards for the dormitories have been authorized and will commence this work as soon as possible.

When you have this information, please give it to Mr. Indian Agent Turner and ask him to forward it direct to the Department.

Two ordinary sewing machines and one tailoring machine are being ordered, and a letter in this connection will be directed to Mr. Indian Agent Turner.

Dear Sir:

I am obliged to direct your attention to the urgent need of a suitable engine for pumping the water at our Onion Lake School. It would appear from correspondence before me that Mr. Indian Agent Turner, acting on instructions received from Mr. Commissioner Graham, requested the Rev. Principal Ellis to have the engine at the pump-house on the lake's shore returned to the Ontario Wind Engine & Pump Co., Regina. This engine, which had never given satisfaction, had previously been removed from the engine house, and was used for cutting wood and crushing grain whenever a grain crusher could be borrowed. To take its place, for the time being, the Principal installed in the pump house the engine which he had been using for other purposes, such as cutting wood, etc. While this engine is made at present to furnish the school's supply of water, the Principal states that it is not sufficiently powerful for this purpose, and has to be kept working daily from 8 in the morning until 9 o'clock at night, with a correspondingly large consumption of gasoline. He was of the opinion, that the other engine was removed by order of the Commissioner, a better engine would have been supplied immediately to take its place. This action however, has not been taken, and I am obliged to submit the matter to you for your prompt and sympathetic consideration.

The Principal states that the engine required to furnish the school with a necessary supply of water should be one of not less than 6 H.P., or one that would pump at least from 2,500 to 3,000 gallons per hour. He also suggests that the new engine should have a better cooling system than the one removed, as that was one of the hopper type which may be suitable enough for outdoor work, but was by no means suitable
for indoor work in a small pump house only 9 ft. square, where the steam created affected the magneto.

He also states that the piping laid from the lake to the main school building is of 2½" dimensions and consequently an engine more powerful than the one first installed could easily deliver 3,000 gallons per hour without any fear of friction.

In commenting on the engine which you have removed, the Principal expresses some doubt as to whether it was new when it was installed. In support of this he states that the main drive shaft was bent when it arrived and that it was equipped with a Webster magneto, the kind which is easily put out of commission through the steam created in the small building.

I trust, therefore, that in view of the above considerations, you may be able to furnish a new engine at a very early date as the School Management are left without an engine for cutting wood, crushing grain, etc., and as our Society is faced with an unnecessary heavy expenditure on account of gasoline to keep the smaller engine temporarily installed in the pump house, in operation for thirteen hours daily.

- I have the honour to be, Sir,-

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.O.O.

Dear Mr. Scott,

You will note what Mr. Grevil, the Engineer at the Onion Lake C. of E. School asks for in the way of hose for fire protection. This might be authorized. You will also note what the Inspector says regarding the completion of the contract at the new R.C. Indian Residential School. He states that no provision was made for chimneys in the laundry and bake-oven. This may or may not have been an oversight, as they may have had some other scheme in view when the plans were drawn. He also complains about the manner in which the laundry floor has been built. I do not know whether this was in accordance with the details of the plans or not. Mr. Hamilton has gone to this school to make a final report and the Department will then be in a position to know just how the matter stands.

One matter, however, I think should not escape the attention of the Department and that is that the Inspector says he was not impressed with the Engineer. I do not know whether this man has the proper qualifications or not, but if he has not he should be replaced. It is absolutely wrong to have an incompetent man handling a plant of this kind, as he can do more damage in a few months that we should expect to occur in ten years. I would ask the Department to look carefully into this man's qualifications. The Inspector remarks that he has a great deal to say. I found this to be the case when I was at this school.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,

INSPECTION REPORT ON SCHOOLS ONION LAKE AGENCY.

Dear Mr. Graham,

ONION LAKE CHURCH OF ENGLAND RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I visited this school on October 24th, and made a careful inspection of the school and outbuildings. I found the school buildings in a well kept condition.

There are 60 pupils enrolled at this school; 77 were present on the day of my visit, 44 boys and 33 girls. The pupils were clean and tidy and had a healthy appearance. I am informed that there has been very little illness at this school during the past year.

I was present at the children's noon-day meal and noted that they had an ample supply of wholesome food. The children received all the milk that they care to drink. They were milking 5 cows at the time of my visit, which give them an ample supply for the children.

The Rev. H. Ellis, Principal, has as a staff 7 women, 1 of whom is a trained nurse and 2 are properly qualified teachers. The kitchen matron was absent on the day of my visit on account of sickness. Mr. D. Spooner, the farming instructor, appears to be a competent man. Mr. W. Gravil, the Engineer, impresses me as being a first class man for the position. He appears to thoroughly understand the operation of the plant and is quite capable of doing the necessary repair work. I found everything in the boiler and engine room in first class condition.

Mr. Gravil brought to my attention that the water system was not available for fire protection in the engine and boiler rooms and stated that if he was supplied with a 1½" hose connection and 50 ft. of fire hose, he could do the work himself and provide protection for that wing of the building. They have one large size extinguisher in the boiler room. He also pointed out that a ventilating fan installed in the chimney would carry off the battery and gas fumes from the engine room. He tells me that at times these are quite strong.

I examined the fire fighting equipment and found it to be in good working order. The plant appears to be operating satisfactorily. They are still using the farm engine to pump water from the lake.

OUTBUILDINGS.

Since my last visit, the stanchions in the cow barn have been raised and re-set in cement. The hay carrier track has also been repaired. I notice an improvement in the condition of the outbuildings and in the tidiness of the premises. A separate sewage disposal system has been installed in connection with the Principal's residence and is very much appreciated. It is working very satisfactorily.

Sir:—

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo, No. 115-1-5, with reference to the gasoline engine that was shipped from the Onion Lake C.E. Indian Residential School to Regina for examination. This engine was brought here at my request, as the Principal reported it to be useless to him. After it arrived here I had the Ontario Wind Engine & Pump Company, who had supplied it, make the examination and their statement was that the engine was practically a total wreck, owing to the rough usage it had received, and that it was absolutely shameful to have handled an engine in such a way. Mr. Paulin, who went up there at the time the engine was installed tells me that it is one of the best engines he knows, and that in proper hands it would be capable of doing even more than it is called upon to do at the School, so that there is no doubt at all in my mind that this machinery is in incompetent hands. This is what I have been complaining about all along, viz.—the way in which our machinery is handled, not only at this school, but at many others as well.

I note the Rev. Principal has reported to you that the engine should be not less than 6 h.p. It might be well to inform him that the one which he now has is 7 h.p.—1 h.p. more than he thinks he should have. This gives you an idea of his knowledge of engines. I cannot conscientiously recommend the buying of expensive machinery to be put into the hands of such men as we have at some of our schools, and Onion Lake is one.

Dear Sir:

I am obliged to you for your letter of Dec. 12, No. 115-146, informing me that you had received a report from Mr. Commissioner Graham advising you that the pump engine, which he had removed from our Onion Lake School, has "been thoroughly overhauled and returned to the school already."

Upon receipt of your letter, I requested the Principal to inform me if the engine had arrived in a satisfactory condition, and in his reply, dated Dec. 20, he states that the engine at that date, had not been returned to the School, nor had he himself, or Mr. Indian Agent Turner, received any word concerning it. He also states that the station agent at Lloydminster had received no advice in connection with it.

With regard to the report of the Ontario Wind Engine and Pump Company mentioned in your letter, "that the engine had received rough usage", the Principal remarks as follows:

"If the engine which was running the day before it was returned to Regina had received rough usage, it must have been before it was installed at the school. The Building Inspector and other workmen here were very much surprised that such an engine was installed here as new equipment. I can produce expert opinions that the engine was in better working shape when it left here than when it was first installed, as it was installed with a bent crank shaft which was afterwards changed by the Company that furnished the engine.

The engine is of an inferior make and is not capable of standing up to the daily running which a pump engine is required to do. These engines are installed with a Webster Oscillatory type magneto which are easily put out of action by the steam created in a pump house 9' x 9'. These engines..."
"are only suitable for occasional outdoor work, and that is why the engine had to be changed."

In the light of the above information, in addition to that set forth in my letter of Nov. 16, I am of the opinion, that the expenditure incurred in having the old engine removed and overhauled might better have been applied towards the purchase of a new engine. However, as the Commissioner decided to have the old engine overhauled, and as the School Management is subjected to much inconvenience owing to the shortage of an engine, I shall be obliged if you will endeavour to have this one returned at the earliest date possible.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

I herewith forward to you an invoice just received from the Ontario Wind Engine and Pump Co., of Regina for the actual repairs done amounting to $28.60. The Oil Cup must have been lost in transit, so the Company sent a supposed new one. The total account being $15.99.

The engine returned is practically the same as it left here, except that the bearings on the main drive shaft have been re-babbitied. As before stated, the engine for the present pump house is useless, as the globules of water caused through the condensation of the steam created from the hopper of the engine forms on the breaker points of the magneto and causes a short circuit. The engine cannot run more than thirty minutes at any time without stopping.

It will be necessary to build an addition to the present pump house which is 9' x 9' before the engine can again be permanently installed.

As the engine was returned to the Company by the Department and repaired by them I cannot see why the Commission should be held responsible for this account.

Yours very truly,

You will recall from your letter of December 12th, 1928, #15-1-5, that the pumping engine had been taken out by Mr. Commissioner Graham for repairs, and was returned to the school. In a letter dated May 13th, Mr. Ellis, the Principal of this school, states that this engine cannot be used for pumping purposes, and that he has been obliged to use for pumping the water required by the school, the engine that was supplied in 1921. He states, however, that it will be a matter of a few weeks before this engine will be used up, and he urges that a new and suitable engine be supplied forthwith.

In addition to the difficulty with the engine, he directs attention to the urgent need of a larger pump. He points out that the best result he can obtain with the present pump is only 450 gallons per hour and recommends that a pump be provided which has a capacity of at least 3,000 gallons per hour. The present pump has a capacity of 1,000 gallons per hour, but owing to the elevation between the lake and the school, this capacity is reduced to 450 gallons per hour. If a 3,000 gallon per hour pump were installed, the high elevation would reduce this capacity to 1,500 gallons per hour, and this is the minimum required to meet the school's needs, and to maintain a sufficient pressure to combat any outbreak of fire. He states that even with the two compression tanks full of water, and the engine pumping at the lake shore, it would not be possible with the present pump and engine to "keep one fire hose stream constantly working."
The necessity of these improvements in the water system at this school are very obvious to our Commission, on account of the abnormally heavy bills they have to meet on account of oil and gasoline. Your Department has recently authorized the erection of a larger pump-house and our Commission feel strongly that arrangements should be made for the whole water system to be placed on a satisfactory working basis at the same time, by the installation of a proper pump and pumping engine.

At the time that Mr. Ellis wrote his letter, he states that the pump had broken down and that the school management were forced to draw water from the lake by hand.

I expect to visit this institution early in June, and would like to be able at that time to inform the Principal and his staff that the unnecessary labour and anxiety which they have had to contend with for so long a time, in connection with the school's water system, was about to be eliminated. I shall be obliged, therefore, if you will give this important matter your very careful consideration and kindly undertake to supply the pump and engine recommended.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I received a letter from the Department dated the 4th instant, No. 115-1-5, enclosing for my information a copy of a communication received from the Rev. T.B.R. Westgate, Field Secretary, M.S.C.C., relative to the engine and pump in use at the Onion Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School. This matter is one that has caused me a great deal of anxiety, and a great deal of correspondence has passed between this office and the Department concerning it ever since the school was built. I took every precaution to see that the system was properly installed and abundantly able to do the work for which it was intended. You will, perhaps, recall that shortly after this system was installed it was reported on as being of little use, and it was said that the engine was defective. I sent a practical man from here, viz:- Mr. E. P. Paulin, who understands the business of installing systems of this kind, and he spent a great deal of time at the school putting everything in good shape. On his return he reported to me that he was of the opinion that no matter what kind of a system, or how good a pump and engine we put in there it would only be a short time until it was put out of business, owing to the utter inefficiency of the Principal and the man who was directly under him. Shortly afterwards Mr. Paulin's prediction came true, and the engine was put out of commission through inefficient handling. I then had this engine brought back to Regina, thoroughly overhauled, and tested in the presence of an expert. I also had an officer from this Department go over and see that it was in Al shape before it was shipped back to Onion Lake.

Duncan G. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
now being called upon to buy another engine to replace this one, and the result would have been the same had it been a brand new engine. I claim it is a waste of money to allow expensive machinery to be placed in the hands of inefficient men such as we have at this school. I have not seen the engine, but I have had reports from competent men to the effect that it has been abused, and how could it be otherwise when they take on men and pay them half, or probably less than half the wages that would be paid a man to run such machinery in any other institution.

I note that Dr. Westgate, in his letter to the Secretary, states that the best result which can be obtained with the present pump is 450 gallons per hour, and recommends that a pump be provided which has a capacity of at least 3,000 gallons per hour. He goes on to say that the present pump had a capacity of 1,000 gallons per hour, but owing to the elevation between the lake and the school, this capacity is reduced to 450 gallons per hour. There is something radically wrong here. I will admit that there is a certain loss of friction owing to the fact that the water has to be forced from the lake up a hill, but this loss does not and could not possibly reduce the capacity to 450 gallons if the engine and the pump were kept in the condition in which they should be kept. It might reduce the capacity a couple of hundred gallons, and if it did it would still provide all the water that was required. You will recall that at a great expense to the Department we had a large tank built just outside the building for the purpose of acting as a reservoir, and also so that the big pump, which I am speaking about, would not be called upon to force the water into the pressure tanks but only into this reservoir, and we have an electric pump for the purpose of pumping the water from this reservoir into the pressure tanks, so that the system was an ideal one had it been handled properly, and any practical man who understands this machinery will bear me out in this. It is just about one year since the overhauled engine was returned to the school and now we are asked to buy another engine and pump. Mr. Paulin, and others claim that a pump with a capacity of 3,000 gallons per hour is absolutely unnecessary, and that the purchase of such a large pump would be a useless waste of money. I am inclined to think-
think that if the present pump and engine were in the hands of competent men they might be put in shape without buying anything.

My advice to the Department is that they insist upon a properly qualified man being put in charge of this plant, otherwise we are just going to tear through and break up machinery at a great and unnecessary cost to the Government.

If it is your wish that I should buy a new engine and pump I should be glad to be advised, but I would strongly recommend that nothing be done until we have an Al man in charge. I would also recommend that the present pump and engine be returned to Regina to be overhauled again by the people who supplied them, and they will give us a report as to the cause of the defects if there are any. If it is found that they can be put in shape they can be returned to the school, but if on the other hand they are found to be beyond repair we can then buy a new outfit. In the event of a new outfit having to be provided we might buy a 10 h.p. instead of a 7 h.p. engine, but I believe it would be a mistake to buy a larger pump, and we certainly should not buy one with a 3,000 gallon per hour capacity. Mr. Paulin and others tell me that a pump the size of the one now in use if properly handled and kept in repair is capable of delivering 1,000 gallons per hour, which is ample when we take into consideration the system that we have at this school.

We have had a lot of correspondence about this matter and I should like to get it settled once and for all, but I cannot see any daylight until we know we are going to have this machinery handled by men who understand how to handle it properly.

Yours very truly,

W. H. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit (June 14-16) to our Society's School at Onion Lake, I made a careful examination of the difficulties which the management have experienced in connection with the water system, and greatly hope that Mr. Commissioner Graham may soon provide the new pump and engine requested in my letter of May 28th, and referred to in your reply on June 4th., No.115-1-5. Neither Mr. Indian Agent Turner, nor the Principal of the School had received any communication from him on this matter, at the time of my visit. Mr. Indian Agent Turner undertook to write to you in this connection, and also in connection with the question of some assistance towards building the new pump house authorized by your Department. I am aware that in a former communication I informed you the School management would erect this building if your Department provided the material. When I reached the School, however, and saw the heavy work which the management had already done in the way of excavating soil for the building, I felt that it was quite too much to expect them to undertake all the building work as well. Mr. Indian Agent Turner agreed with me in this opinion, and undertook to write to you accordingly. I trust, therefore, that your Department may relieve the School management of this labour, so that they may be able to devote their energies to the farming and gardening activities which press heavily at this time of year.

While dealing with the condition of the water system at this School, I beg to direct your attention to the need of a reducing valve. Approximately 1100 gallons of water are required daily in the operations of the School, and to maintain an adequate pressure for fire protection.
purposes. At present when this amount is pumped in the morning, only about 500 gallons are left by evening, and another 600 gallons must then be pumped to raise the pressure to the safety mark. The installation of the reducing valve which would reduce the house pressure from 60 lbs. to 35 lbs. would save a great deal of pumping, and a corresponding amount of gasoline and labour. The cost of a suitable valve, 1½" end weighing 30 lbs., would be $45.00. To install this valve, about 5 lengths (or 60') of standard piping would be required, and this would cost approximately $20.00.

I shall be obliged, therefore, if you will authorize the Principal, or Mr. Indian Agent Turner, to have the reducing valve installed, at a cost not exceeding $75.00.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

TBRW/EMW

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

I beg to enclose herewith a letter received from the Rev. H. Ellis, principal at the Onion Lake C.o.E. Indian Residential School, with reference to the water supply for the school.

On receipt of the letter, I visited the school for the purpose of ascertaining just what was required. The level of the lake, from which the school water supply is drawn, has dropped several feet, and, consequently, the pipe through which the water is drawn is within two feet of the surface, nearest the shore. When this pipeline was put in a pier was built over it, extending out into the lake, until the pipe was covered with about six feet of water, but as the level of the water has dropped, this pier should now be extended far enough, so that the pipe will be below frost level. I believe that by extending this pier about 15 feet the school water supply will be safe, but this should be done as soon as possible as the season is already quite late for this kind of work. Dear Sir:

We have gone very carefully over the details of the outfit supplied in connection with the pumping of water at Onion Lake with Mr. Paulin and we cannot see where any trouble should develop outside of the ordinary wear and tear that you might have on machinery.

Upon further investigation we find that this is the point where the 7 H.P. engine was shipped several years ago and over which considerable amount of trouble arose, finally resulting in having the engine sent back in here for inspection. You will remember that we had an expert examine the engine, you had an officer from your department come over and we showed him an engine which had been disgracefully used. We showed your officer where the operator of this engine apparently did not know, or if he did know, he did not feel that it was necessary to tighten up the main journals. We could actually move the crank shaft in the journals 3/8" of an inch, we are not exaggerating this because we took measurements.

We also found that the connecting rod journals were all loose, the mechanism re operating the valves was also at a point of falling off the engine for the want of being tightened up. During the twenty years that the writer has been with the Company he has not seen an engine come back into the warehouse in such a delapidated condition caused apparently from inefficient ability on the part of an operator.

While we like to have business, and have always enjoyed doing business with the Department of Indian Affairs, we feel that in justice to ourselves, and to our goods, we would prefer not sending any more machinery, pumps, etc., to Onion Lake unless there is a decided change in the system of looking after such machinery.

We hope that this letter will be received in the same friendly spirit that it is written in. We are endeavoring

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to report that I visited the Onion Lake Anglican Residential School on the 6th instant and made an examination of the pump house and pumping plant which is installed near the lake shore and furnishes the water supply for the main building.

This pump house has been in use since the school was built a little over four years ago and has been condemned by the school management; the main reason given was that water seeped through into the basement and flooded the pump and had to be pumped out by hand each morning. I may explain that the basement of this pump house is floored with concrete and the walls are lined with ten inches of concrete as well. I am satisfied, after taking rough levels, that the floor of the pump house basement is above the water level in the lake and it appeared strange to me that sufficient water would drain through ten inches of concrete in twenty-four hours to cause very much trouble.

I had the engine stopped and went down through the man-hole to the basement to examine the pump and found that as soon as the engine was stopped the water from the main pipe line leading up to the building immediately started draining back through the pump into the basement. I called down Mr. Erick Retherham, who went with me to examine the plant, and the present Engineer, Mr. Littlewood, and pointed

this out to them. They agreed with me that this back drainage was causing all the trouble in so far as the flooding of the basement was concerned. The seepage through the concrete walls in twenty-four hours would be negligible and by installing a shut-off valve in the pipe close to the pump it would be possible to stop this back drainage and, in our opinion, would solve the question of the flooding of the basement.

The engine house, which is situated over this basement, is in size 8 ft. X 8 ft. with an 8 ft. stud. The floor of this is re-inforced concrete slab, six inches in thickness. This building is provided with a brick chimney at one end. There is no ventilating shaft in the building, and, as the engine provided is hopper cooled, the result is that when the engine heats up steam is generated and there is no means provided for carrying it off. The result is that everything is wet. The engine does not get proper lubrication and the magneto has to be taken off and thoroughly dried very frequently. There is no doubt in my mind that if precaution had been taken to stop the back drainage and to have the steam carried off from the pump house, the plant would have worked satisfactorily, but the result of neglecting to remedy these defects has been that through improper lubrication we have a worn out pump and the engine has not given satisfactory service. It would, in my opinion, be perfectly feasible to install the present plant in this building, but it would mean that we have have to deprive the institution of a water supply during the period that would be taken up in making the new installation. I have made arrangements, subject to your approval, to add an addition 6 ft. X 8 ft. to the present pump house and will have the engine placed on a solid concrete base. A ventilator with a cowl to go over the hopper will be provided to carry off the steam. The new pump will be placed on a concrete slab at ground level in the existing building. This can be done at comparatively little cost. There
