Sir:

On November 2nd, I received a telegram from the Department instructing me to make immediate replacement of the pumping engine at the Onion Lake C. of E. School, and stating that later the Department would determine who should pay the expenses. In accordance with these instructions I purchased from the Fairbanks-Morse Company, Winnipeg, a new engine and pump costing $755.25, f.o.b. Winnipeg, and arranged with the Company to send a man to Onion Lake to install same.

In due course Mr. Pederson, the Fairbanks-Morse representative, went to Onion Lake, and on the day of his arrival he wired stating that it was impossible to install the pump until the new building was completed. As I had received no advice from the Department that the building of a new pump house was contemplated I wired Indian Agent Turner and informed him that he should not have allowed me to send Pederson from Winnipeg without first advising me that the Department had under consideration the erection of a new building. I then wired the Deputy Superintendent General, informing him of what had taken place, at the same time pointing out that the present pump house had only been built four years ago and that it was absolutely unnecessary to erect another building. To this I received a reply stating that if the present pump house were suitable the men from Winnipeg should make the installation of the pump. By the time I received this telegram Mr. Pederson had returned to Winnipeg without doing anything.

In due course I received a letter from Mr. Lang Turner explaining what had taken place between the Department and himself, of which correspondence I think he should have previously informed me, and I am inclined to believe that the Department had been entirely misled by Dr. Westgate or some other authority of the

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
School pointing out that there was a necessity for incurring the expense of erecting a new pump house.

After all the trouble and expense of sending a man from Winnipeg, I decided that the only thing to do was to send Inspector Murison up again to see what the situation really was, as I could not understand the request for a new pump house. He has now returned and from his report, which is attached hereto, you will see that all that was necessary to overcome the difficulty was a shut-off valve in the pipe close to the pump in order to stop the back drainage after the pump was stopped. It seems to me that a boy of fourteen years of age should have been able to solve this problem. You will also note what the Inspector states about the pump house having no outlet for the steam. These conditions have been allowed to exist until the outfit has been practically destroyed, although it should have lasted for another ten or fifteen years.

While on the ground the Inspector found a lot of material, probably $100.00 worth, the purchase of which had been authorized by the Department, and under instructions from me he arranged for the erection of a small leanto on the building, which would make a little more room, although, as he says, the pump could have been installed in the present building.

Might I ask that in future in matters of this kind I be informed, so that we can deal with them in the most economical way. I think now that if the Department has been misinformed by Dr. Westgate it should be up to the Church authorities to pay for this expense, as you suggested in your wire of November 2nd. that later on you would decide as to who should bear the expense. Dr. Westgate is not a practical man, nor is Mr. Ellis, the Principal of the School, and it seems to me that it is unsafe to act on any recommendations these gentlemen make without first having the matters thoroughly inquired into.

Your obedient servant,

W. H. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir:

On the 2nd inst., an important communication was addressed to you from this office pointing out the urgent need of a new pump house at our Society's Indian Residential School at Onion Lake, but up to date, no reply has been received to the same.

In your letter of November 22nd, you stated that the Dominion Water Power Branch had been requested to make a report concerning the water supply at this institution. From our letter of the 2nd inst., you will have learned that a Fairbanks-Morse expert had reached the school to install the new engine and pump, but that he did not advise the installation being made in the old pump house. There can be no question whatever about the urgent need of this building, and I trust that it may be provided with the least possible delay.

In the closing sentence of your letter of November 22nd, last #15-1-5, you stated that the Dominion Water Power Branch had been asked to ascertain if the engineer possessed the necessary qualifications, etc. In this connection, I beg to inform you that our Society takes the greatest possible care in the selection of their agents, and they feel assured, from the information before them that Mr. James Littlewood who is filling this position at present, is fully capable of handling all the mechanical equipment with which that school has been provided. I trust, therefore, that the provision of the pump house may at once be made, and the water system at this institution placed on a satisfactory basis for many years to come.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Dear Mr. Scott:

Referring to your telegram of the 3rd instant, stating that it had been reported that nothing had been done regarding the pumping plant at the Onion Lake C. of E. School, I wired you on the 4th instant stating that there had been no unnecessary delay, and that I had received no complaint regarding the matter from the Agent. At the same time I wired the Agent, making inquiry regarding the work, and his reply was that work had been commenced on installation December 30th and was proceeding satisfactorily. This information I passed on to you.

I may say that immediately on receiving your instructions that a new pumping and lighting system was to be installed at this school I took action and there was no delay whatever. It was necessary to send a new pump and engine from Winnipeg, and I also arranged to have a man go from the factory in Winnipeg to make the installation. On his arrival at the school he was told by the Principal that he was not to install the pump, as it was the intention of the Department to build a new pump house. This was the first intimation I had that the building of a new pump house was contemplated, and on December 3rd, I wired you stating that this was not necessary. When Inspector Murison went to Onion Lake to investigate the matter it was found that material for a new pump house had been on the ground for several months and that the engine had been neglected and had been working under water, which was not coming from the lake, nor was it seepage from the ground, but backwater from the pipe, and it was not until a layman went down from here that this was discovered.

II. The Onion Lake Indian Residential School

Matters arising from the report of the travelling nurse as a cut in Mr A.F. Mackenzie's letter, dated November 28th, 1929, serial number 115-1-13.

While we do not admit the existence of sufficient grounds for the statement concerning food, health of children, etc., contained in the report in question, we are unprepared to accept the visit of the travelling nurse in question, or any other travelling nurses, on the status of an inspectress. We accept and are prepared to co-operate with (1) the local medical officer of the Department (2) the local Indian Agent and (3) the inspector concerned of the Department at Ottawa. We further submit respectfully, that all matters falling under the general head of "Inspection" should be limited to the reports of one or other of these three officials; the visits of the District nurse being limited, strictly, to the purposes for which we understood such nurses were to be appointed i.e. the nursing care of such pupil, or pupils, as may require the same, particularly the additional nursing care required in the event of an epidemic occurring among them.

2. The installation of the new Pumping Equipment -

In this connection I quote from our correspondence the following statements made by the Principal of the School:

From a letter, dated December 26th, 1929 -

"Since May last we have been waiting for an inspector from the Dominion Water Power Branch, but to date no inspection has been made.

I wired to the Commissioner at Regina to the effect that the water system had broken down. He immediately shipped in a new engine and pump, instructing the Indian Agent not to allow any of the school officials to touch it, as an expert would be sent to make the installation. When the expert arrived, he found it was impossible to install the plant, and on receipt of a telegram from his Company, he left for the Peace River District.

Mr Graham immediately sent Inspector Muirson here, and after discussing the situation, recommended putting an extension 6' x 8' in size on the west end of the present house and installing the new pump and engine on the floor level, which is about 8' above the regular pipe line. Also, he recommended the placing of a cowl over the hopper of the engine to take off the steam vapour.

When this extension is done and the other necessary improvements made, personally, I believe, it will cost as much as the new pump house which was $400.00 including materials and labour."

Dear Mr Scott:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated the 16th inst. serial number 115-1-5, "relative to the Pumping equipment at the Onion Lake C.E. Indian Residential School."

I note, with regret, that the installation of the new plant is apparently being proceeded with in the position occupied by the old plant, with the operation of which this Society had such a trying and expensive experience. I respectfully submit that sufficient evidence, in fact none of an expert kind, has been submitted to the effect that the new installation will not be seriously affected, in the results given and in the life of the plant installed, by the stated disadvantages of the site occupied by the old plant.

I would, also, respectfully recall to your attention the fact that our claim "concerning a new engine for cutting wood at Onion Lake" is based upon the fact that on the breakdown, last May, of the water-pumping plant, the school authorities were obliged to take the engine for cutting wood and use it for pumping purposes—a purpose for which the engine was not built and which has practically, if not completely, worn it out. Our request, in this respect, is, therefore, based directly upon the results of the delay of the Department officials in failing to repair, through the installation of the new plant, a serious condition of affairs which was brought about as long ago as last May, by the final breakdown of the old engine.
I note that your "funds are completely assigned at the present time". This statement applies, I presume, to the Departmental financial provision for the current Parliamentary year ending on March 31st. May I renew the request in the following form:

That this Society purchase the needed engine for cutting wood, of a type and on the condition required by the Department, with the definite understanding that the cost of purchase will be refunded to the Society out of the Departmental Funds provided by Parliament for the year beginning April 1st. next.

Commending this request to your sympathetic consideration,

I remain,

Yours very faithfully,

Sir:-

I have had a lot of correspondence and trouble in connection with the way in which the lighting and pumping plant at the Onion Lake C. of E. School has been handled, and, as you know, I attribute a great deal of the difficulty to a lack of knowledge on the part of the Principal and his staff.

We have at this school a lighting plant with a capacity of 7,500 watts, and judging from the requirements at other schools it would appear that more lights are being used than are really necessary, and also that lights are left burning when not in use. The lights in the hall should be reduced to 20-watt lamps, and the same thing applies to the cellar and other parts of the building. The amount of wattage used in the dining-room is 21 - 40-watt lamps, a total of 840 watts. This is twice the amount of lamps required, and over twice as many as are used in the average school dining-room, where even more pupils are accommodated. The total capacity of this plant is, as I say, 7,500 watts, and this is ample to supply the lighting requirements of a school of this size if proper care is exercised. In the average school only 60% of the lights are used at any one time. This is the method used in basing current requirements. This would leave a load of 4944 watts, which indicates that the present equipment, if operating efficiently should meet the requirements.

-Mr. Ellis-

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Mr. Ellis has not shown good judgment, and with your approval I shall inform him that he is to reduce the size of the lamps in certain parts of the building where they should be reduced. You will recall that this gentleman was asking for a plant almost double the capacity of the one which he now has. This is absurd. I maintained that the plant which he had was all right.

I may say that I have written this letter after getting the opinion of experts in the matter.

Sir:

With further reference to my letter of the 16th ultimo in regard to the lighting plant at the Onion Lake C. of E. Indian Residential School, I beg to inform you that I have just received a final report from the Fairbanks-Morse Expert who was sent to Onion Lake to overhaul the engine of the plant.

As you know, I have always contended that this plant, as well as the plants that we have at various other schools, have been abused through having incompetent men operating them. The Expert has this to say in his report regarding this engine:

"Found this engine falling off in horse power owing to water getting into cylinder, and the governor sleeve pin worn out owing to lack of oil when engine was new; as these pins must be oiled when engine is first put in or they will begin to cut and wear down very rapidly. Also butterfly valve loose, and worn, owing to being left in this shape so long. These Type Z engines have a very sensitive governor and must be balanced properly with butterfly valve arm working over dead center. Exhaust valves were being eaten away by the chemical action of the water......Engine would not pull a 40 amp. load in that shape. Put on new Cylinder and piston wired to Regina for gov. sleeve pin #60A and #202A.C. butterfly valve assembly complete. Installed new 3" exhaust line throughout, tested engine pulling 70 amp. load, this being all they could scare up, and 58 amperes is their present peak load and engine only plays with that. No effort for it at all."

-This goes-

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

I may say that I have not yet had a reply to my letter of the 16th ultimo, in which I informed you of the extraordinary amount of lighting that Mr. Ellis, the Principal, expected this engine to do, and asked for an acknowledgment of my letter.

Re Anglican Indian Residential School

You will note that there are 3 halfbreed children in residence at this school who should never have been admitted. These children are classed as whites and should be discharged, but the Provincial Government will not take them in unless they are forced to do so.

I think Dr. Westgate went too far in this matter and should have consulted the proper authorities before taking them in.

I would particularly draw your attention to that portion of the report in which it is pointed out that the milk supply is inadequate. I would say that it is very inadequate. I do not think this matter should be passed over lightly. The Principal of this school is always ready to criticise the Department and call upon the Department to make right anything which is wrong in his opinion, and he was the means of officiating our Nurse who was to visit this school not long ago. Seven gallons of milk was delivered that contains 118 persons is also bad! The Inspector points out that they have 50 head of cattle and that the stable only contains 31 stalls. This is true, but if they had the right kind of cattle, as it was intended they should have when the buildings were erected, 31 stalls would have provided ample for the cows. The trouble here is that they have the wrong type of cattle, probably not milking strain.

There is an item in the Estimates for re-painting this school, which will be done as soon as proper authority is received.

Under the head of Fire Protection, I notice the Inspector says he examined the equipment and found 3 - 50 ft. lengths of linen hose in a leaking condition. This should not be. This hose should last for years; it is comparatively new. All linen hose leaks and sweats at times. I am going to take this matter up with the Inspector when he returns.

You will notice that the Inspector visited the Long Lake, Frog Lake, and Island Lake Day Schools.

I do not know what to recommend with regard to the teacher's residence at the Island Lake Day School. It seems to be a poor affair. Perhaps if we carry out the suggestion to have a Farming Instructor placed at these reserves, we might come to some better arrangement.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner
PART OF INSPECTOR MURISON'S REPORT, FORWARDED
UNDER COVER OF MR. COMMISSIONER GREGHAM'S 309-11
DATED MARCH 29, 1930.

ONION LAKE C. E. RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

ANGLICAN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I visited this school on the 7th instant,
and made a complete inspection of the building. There are 99
pupils enrolled, 48 boys and 51 girls. There are 3 half-
breed children in addition, about whom the Department are
already aware. Information has been given the police who
are endeavouring to locate the father of these children
so that they can be turned over to him. The children
presented a clean and healthy appearance. I saw them in
the school
ANGLICAN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

the school and at play, and was quite pleased with their happy appearance.

FARM

The crop, as already reported, was a complete failure at this institution last year, owing to lack of rainfall during the growing season. Their stock consists of 13 milk cows, 1 bull and 11 young stock. There are only 5 cows milking during the winter. In February, according to the record, these cows produced 2,210 lbs., which is equal to 231 gals. This is a very inadequate supply and it can readily be seen that they cannot provide the children with milk to drink. With the Principal's family and staff, there is an average of 118 persons to provide for.

If the stock are to be increased at this school, it will be necessary to increase the housing accommodation for cattle. They now have 30 head of cattle and there are 21 stalls in the barn.

BUILDING

The school building has not been re-painted since it was built, and an item appears in the Estimates this year for this work. The metal ceilings are becoming discoloured, and the walls, although not in bad shape, are getting dirty in spots. The school has been occupied for four years.

WATER SUPPLY

The new pumping unit is working very satisfactorily. They now have to pump 1½ hours per day and 2 hours on wash days to keep up the water supply. With the old unit they averaged 13 hours pumping per day and then could not keep up the supply. They now use 8 gals. of gasoline per week. They formerly used 13 gals. of gasoline.
ANGLICAN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

WATER SUPPLY (CONT'D.)

gasoline per day. The installation of the new outfit has materially reduced their expenses. A new cylinder has been put in the 15 H.P. engine which supplies power for generating electric light, etc. The installation has been changed by discarding the exhaust pot and having the exhaust carried straight to the open air through a 4" pipe. Since this installation was made, the engine develops full power at normal speed. Before the installation was changed, the engine would only develop 35 amperes, or half its rated power. I am satisfied that the trouble with this engine has been caused through faulty installation in the first place. There was a larger inlet to the exhaust pot than the outlet. The consequence was that back pressure was created which caused the engine to overheat with a consequent loss of power. With the new installation the cost per kilowatt is now 6.6¢ in place of 15¢ per kilowatt under the old conditions. Both these units are working very satisfactorily.

FIRE PROTECTION

The pupils are given practice at fire drill twice a week when they are not expecting it. The Principal informs me that he visits the school and makes a regular inspection each night after 10 o'clock. I had him sound the fire alarm while the children were at their classroom work. They evacuated the school in an orderly manner in less than two minutes. It could readily be seen that they knew exactly what to do. I examined the equipment and found 3 - 50 ft. lengths of the linen fire hose in a leaking condition. This should be replaced.
ANGLICAN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

FIRE PROTECTION (CONT'D.)

They are well equipped on each floor with 5 gal. chemical fire extinguishers. The fire escapes are easy of access and appear to be quite safe.

I examined the water storage tank while the pump was in operation and noted that the water pumped from the lake had a strong stagnant smell. Personally, I would not care to drink it. It is treated with chloride lime before being used.

GENERAL

I found the school building clean throughout. It was well ventilated, but I noticed a strong smell in the dormitories, which, I found, came from the beds. They have 74 straw ticks, and as the straw or hay is only changed once a year, the smell from these ticks is not pleasant at this time of the year.

Ice is put up for use during the summer months, but there is no refrigerator or adequate means for keeping fresh meat during the summer months.

OPINION Regina, May 10/30

This supply is quite unsatisfactory and in fact dangerous as a water supply for the Anglican Indian School. As was pointed out in a previous report all lakes and surface waters in this Province are unsuitable for domestic supplies unless they are treated by filtration or some other recognised process. The two examinations which have been made of the water from the lake at your school prove this statement to be true. Another source of supply should be sought or the water should be filtered, chlorinated or boiled before use. This matter is urgent and the school authorities must accept any responsibility for any outbreaks of disease which may occur if they continue to use the lake water in an untreated condition.

RHM/MC R. H. Murray, C.E.
Director, Division of Sanitation.

The statement on page 2 is part of this opinion.
The opinion given on page 1 is based upon the detailed information recently furnished regarding the source of supply and upon the foregoing laboratory findings.

If the source is satisfactory, care should be taken to protect it against future contamination.

If the source is doubtful, the improvements recommended should be given effect to at once.

If the source is unsafe, the supply should be abandoned, or the water boiled until such time as the suggested changes are made, and another opinion obtained from this Division.

INTERPRETATION OF LABORATORY FINDINGS.

TOTAL SOLIDS - Generally speaking, an ideal drinking water should contain not more than 50 grains per gallon of total solids. Wells on the prairie, however, usually show a much larger amount. The maximum amount of total solids permissible in a drinking water varies in accordance with the relative quantities of the constituents. For this reason a water containing several times the quantity names might be pronounced satisfactory. In certain circumstances the cumulative effect of drinking a hard water may affect the health of the consumer.

NITRITES - The presence of Nitrites ordinarily indicates contamination in the water from decaying animal matter or from animal excrement.

ORGANIC MATTER - Underground streams, unless very shallow, are filtered free of organic matter. The presence of organic matter in a well usually points to defects in the cover or cribbing.

BACTERIA - Drinking water should have a count of less than 200 bacteria per cubic centimeter. (A cubic centimeter is equal to about one third of a teaspoonful)

B. COLI - Is an organism or germ which comes from the intestinal tract of animals and human beings. Its presence in a water indicates that the sample is contaminated with waste matter of human or animal origin, and that dysentery, typhoid fever or other intestinal diseases may be transmitted by the water.

ONION LAKE CHURCH OF ENGLAND INDIAN SCHOOL.

Date of inspection: May 9, 1930.

Purpose of inspection: To inspect the water supply system of the school, and to ascertain "whether the engineer in charge of the system possesses the necessary qualifications for the proper operation of the aforementioned plant."

The Church of England Indian School at Onion Lake obtains its water supply from a lake known as Long lake, and is located on the banks of the aforesaid lake. A pumphouse is located on the lake shore with a 2½-inch inlet pipe, running into the lake some 90 feet, into a depth of water around six feet, with the stage of the lake as on May 9th, 1930. The pumphouse consists of a Fairbanks-Morse 6 H.P. engine, connected with a double action Fairbanks-Morse pump, with a rated capacity of 2000 gals. per hour, and has a 10-foot well. Water is forced up the hill some 25 feet into a concrete reservoir built below frost line, with the dimensions of 10x10x8 feet, or approximately 40,000 gals. The pumphouse is a small wooden building 18 by 10 feet in size, heated with a coal stove. The water is taken into the school by means of a one H.P. electric pump, which pumps directly out of the sunken reservoir into two pressure tanks of 2000 gals. each and the pressure is around 25 to 30 lbs in the tanks. The water line from the pumphouse to the reservoir is 2½" pipe.

The engineer in charge of the system is J. Littlewood, and he has been at this school since 14th October 1929. He is a Scotsman by birth and has had an extensive experience in plants of sundry description, such as, engineer in charge of electric supply for H.M. Office of Works, Messrs Vickers Ltd., together with a knowledge of generators, engines, fitting and machinist work. He stated that he was wounded in the war, and came out to this country to regain his health, which was very poor on his arrival in Canada, but he is in fair health now.

In my opinion he is well fitted for the operation of the system and is able to make running repairs to all parts of the system and thus enable the plant to keep going until new parts are brought in, and as this school is not located on a railway, his ability to repair various items is very valuable.

General Observations.

The water supply system of the school is operating fairly well but I would venture to suggest that the inlet pipe which is laid into the lake is not carried out far enough. By carrying out this pipe some further 100 feet, it would enter deep blue water, and the quality of the water would be increased, as there exists much vegetation and silt in the shallow water. A fine screen filter should be placed on the up-turn elbow, to eliminate the many small fish which run into the pump at present. The pumphouse is very small and a lean-to should be
built on to it so that the total floor area would be around 26' by 10'. The pumphouse is supplied with a coal-burning stove, whereas only wood is available which is not efficient for heating in the winter time, unless coal is brought in.

The sunken reservoir should be painted with a coat of concrete preparation to prevent hairchecking which is starting to make its appearance.

On the whole the plant is fulfilling the requirements of the school which consists of around 100 children at times and a staff of 10 teachers, but I would suggest that any requests for material asked for by the engineer in charge should be favourably considered, as the engineer is capable and has the successful operation of the plant at heart.

The boiler room and the storage room batteries are kept in a clean condition, together with the pumphouse, but in connection with the latter, there is no room to store wood in the winter time, or to enable one to work around the engine or pump without discomfort.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) W. G. Stuart.

Dear Sir:

I have to inform you that at 3:20 p.m. this afternoon, a serious fire broke out between the floors of the small boys' dormitory. The fire was caused by a faulty wire connection in the junction box where the light leads through the floor to the bath room on the second floor.

Miss Gillespie, the Boys' Supervisor stated that she had smelt smoke at 3 o'clock that afternoon in the bath room, but did not think anything was wrong because the small boiler was on to heat the water for bathing in the boiler house.

Soon afterwards, while talking to an Indian in the office, I heard Miss Mount, the Matron asking where the smoke was coming from, as she had smelt burnt rubber while working in the kitchen.

I immediately left the Indian and began to make an investigation. On the top floor, I saw smoke coming through in clouds. I went around and could not locate where the fire was on the second floor, having been watching the hospital department. Coming out from there, I looked in at the bath room and found that the paint on the tin ceiling around the light fixture in the bath room had the paint burnt off and was hot. I immediately came to the conclusion that the fire was in connection with the wires in the boys' dormitory. I asked Mr. Littlewood to cut out the main switch on the board in the engine room and start and operate all the water pumps. We then decided to cut through the floor in the dormitory and as soon as a hole was made, the flames burst through three or four inches high. I then thought the building would soon be raised to the ground. Having checked the fire with the hand extinguishers, this gave us the chance through the smoke to play on the water hose. Having put out the fire, I immediately asked Indian Agent Turner to come up and make his inspection and to see the rough flooring burnt through around the junction box.

The fire crept along the joists for about 10 feet which was badly charred. The rough flooring being burnt almost through, though the joists as before stated was charred.

Photos will be submitted as soon as I receive the same from the photographer.
CAUSE OF FIRE

Mr. Littlewood found two joints; one of two wires and one of three wires, totalling five wires in one junction box. The joints were made by simply twisting to secure the bare ends of the wires. These bare ends allowed corrosion to take place where the wires were making contact due to them not being soldered. The corrosion setting up a high resistance which caused heat, which eventually set fire to the insulation. The junction box containing the five wires was insecurely fastened to the conduit, having three pipes entering into the box. Two pipes were fastened with lock nuts inside the junction box, the other was left loose without a lock nut, thereby breaking the continuity, and rendering the ground wire ineffective. Had the conduit been making a good contact, the chances of fire would have been very remote because the fuse controlling the circuit would perhaps have been blown, thus breaking the circuit and cutting off the electric current.

RECOMMENDATIONS:

To have all junction boxes inspected to see that there are no loose wires and all tapes removed to see that all the joints are soldered. If found that the wires are the same as the enclosed sketch, (top) which caused the fire, then to re-wire the whole building because the same does not meet the requirements of the Fire Underwriters. The loop-in system being required.

No substitute "Guardene" Fire Extinguishers, the seven on hand did not meet with our requirements. Four on each floor including dormitories and landings are required. This must be treated as urgent.

To re-decorate the interior which has been damaged by smoke and water and to replace the flooring which was necessary to cut up.

Four Firemen's Axes - .5" cut -.4 to 5 lbs weight.

Signed: Henry Ellis
Principal.

Dear Sir,

I have to report an outbreak of fire at the Onion Lake (C.R.) Indian Residential School this afternoon, caused by a short circuit in the wiring of the building.

At about 3:30 o'clock this afternoon the school building was discovered to be full of smoke, but no fire could be located until it was seen that the paint, on the steel ceiling in the bathroom on the second floor, was scorched. The staff then went upstairs and tore up the flooring in the small boy's dormitory, which is immediately above the bathroom mentioned. It was then discovered that a large patch of the floor joists was on fire, and flames leaped out into the dormitory. This fire was quickly put out, as the hose was already in position to deal with it. In the meantime Mr. Ellis had phoned for me to go there as quickly as possible, and I arrived at the school just as the fire had been overcome. I should add that when the flooring in the dormitory was torn up it was seen that the fire had emanated from about 18 inches of the wire conduit, which was then glowing with heat, caused by a short circuit in the wiring inside. As soon as the fire was subdued this conduit was disconnected and the wiring made safe.

A good deal of damage had been done to the floor and plaster in the dormitory, and the paintwork has been scorched in places; and the whole line of wire should be overhauled and renewed where necessary. I would ask you to kindly wire me authority to have these repairs made. While I cannot give you any detailed estimate of the cost, I do not think it should exceed $150.00.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Graham:

You will perhaps recall how long ago it is that a new cylinder head was placed on the 15 h.p. engine Fairbanks engine that operates the lighting plant. I now have to inform you that the exhaust valve has burnt out and it is too badly damaged to be refaced. I cannot account for this burning out so soon - and as the valve was already placed in the new cylinder head when shipped and put on by the expert, I cannot say if it was seated properly or not. My own personal opinion is that it was installed satisfactory and was correct in all detail when put on. We are now using an old one for the present, but this will only last for a week or two. We would appreciate having another sent as soon as possible. I have kept the damaged one here for your inspection, if you so desire, which has been shown to Mr. Indian Agent Turner.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Henry Ellis
Principal.
St. Barnabas School,
Onion Lake, Sask.
July 16th, 1930

15 H.P. ZA

Took the train Sunday night for Lloydminster, had to wait one day there owing to mud and rain, got to Onion Lake School Tuesday night.

Mr. Ellis, the principal, was very much surprised at seeing me and wanted to know who sent me, as he said what was I doing there as everything was running beautiful and everybody happy every since I had been there last January. He said two months after I left they burnt out exhaust valves owing to letting cylinder head gasket shrink, allowing water to cut it out and burn, the engineer told me that was all that went wrong, and Mr. Ellis was so much difficulty to obtain the necessary repairs that he requires that he always sends the old parts to Mr. Graham, Indian Affairs Com., at Regina for him to forward the necessary parts back.

However, when I was out there last January to check over entire installation you can rely that I saw to it that the installation is all correct in every way, cooling system, timing, etc., therefore, you can rest assured you will have no more trouble on that score, and if anything should go wrong, as there is bound to do, if they write to us, we can certainly give them reasons why. Of course, any engine is liable to burn out valves unless touched up every two months or so that is at a point where they are running every day, like this instance after an exhaust valve is allowed to become pitted, it is liable to start and blow and burn out completely in two hours' time, but if you ever find an engine that burns out exhaust valves chronically, it is mostly due to exhaust valve seat becoming too deep, then the only thing to be done is put in a new seat or a new cylinder head. While at Onion Lake, I drew piston and reground valves, and left one new exhaust valve for a spare and engine O.K. I am also sending them three piston rings, as they will soon require them.

There is one more thing I might state, and that is I would recommend a suction fan to be put in engine room, as it gets terribly hot in summer months, owing to the design of the room, the air does not move and makes the place unbearable to work in, and is almost too hot for the batteries, which are fairly close to cooling tank, although the engine itself runs cool enough. However I would appreciate you recommending this to Mr. Graham, Regina— the cost is small, I presume the Dept. if Indian Affairs will pay for my trip, as there was no fault found in installation or defective engine parts.

Truly,

E. J. Leask.

Further, to my letters of the 23rd and 30th of August last with reference to the outbreak of fire at the school, I now have to report that the Indian Commissioner has sent us only three new fire extinguishers and four fire axes. The extinguishers were sent without any chemical. I can get three acid bottles and the Bi-carbonate of Soda from the Agency as they have the re-fills on hand. I do not think that the three extinguishers are sufficient. It takes fifteen minutes to get the water pressure up to the top floor which would have to be raised from 25 to 30 lbs. pressure in the day time to 50 to 80 lbs. pressure for fire fighting, hence the use of the extinguishers in the meantime. We cannot keep the full pressure up to eighty pounds in the day time as this pressure cuts through the faucets, the brass seatings. At nights we raise the pressure for fire purposes. General.

The Onion Lake Church of England School is a comparatively new structure, designed to accommodate some one hundred and ten pupils, situated on high land about eight hundred feet from the east shore of Onion Lake.

Onion lake is a lake of some 400 acres in extent located within high banks and is situated some thirty-five miles north of the town of Lloydminster and is somewhat isolated.

The lake has no inlet or outlet and is dependent on local precipitation with the possibility of some minor springs. For the most part it is some fifteen to eighteen feet deep but the water is of a greenish colour with minute but visible particles of vegetable matter in suspension; further to this, it has a very definite odour. Generally speaking, it would be described as stagnant.

Other than the possibility of deep wells there is no alternative supply in the neighbourhood from which the school could be supplied.

The pumping plant, the system and the management of the supply would appear to be of a high order, but an examination and study of the water demonstrates the necessity of treatment before the school may be regarded as safe or efficient.

On the representation of the Rev. H. Ellis, the Principal of the School, analysis of the lake water has been made from time to time by various authorities as a matter of policy and one and all agree that there is danger of pollution without adequate means of prevention inasmuch as the lake water is being used for domestic purposes practically untreated.

To date the only method of treatment attempted has been chlorination though to the credit of all concerned every effort has been made to keep the lake free from contamination in so far as possible. Needless to say, should contamination take place and Bacteria Coli, - traces of which have been found from time to time - become active, an enormous percentage of mortality would doubtless be the result.

A report
A report on six water samples taken from various parts of the lake and analysed by the Provincial Authorities at the University of Alberta, shows from 690 to 3000 colonies of bacteria per cubic centimeter as against 200 colonies or less in good drinking water, and in one case out of the six there was a positive return in regard to the presence of *Bacteri* Coli.

This sample was taken from a point a distance of half a mile from the inlet, but in view of this bacteria being directly responsible for typhoid dysentery and other intestinal diseases, its presence is sufficient to warrant anxiety.

Vegetable content is reported in each case as "Heavy".

A further report made by the Department of Public Health of the Province of Saskatchewan in 1926 gives a content of 2500 bacteria colonies per c.c., and also shows the presence of *Bacteri* Coli. This report continues:

"This is hard water but its use for drinking purposes should be quite suitable for persons enjoying normal health ...."

"All surface water supplies in Saskatchewan including rivers, lakes, streams, and sloughs are dangerous for domestic purposes and should not be used without some form of treatment."

"Water should be passed through a filter or chlorinated."

From the above facts and reports it would appear to be definitely established that some further effort is necessary before this supply can be regarded as suitable for the purpose for which it is being used and careful study has been made into the matter from all angles with the result that a combination of filtration and chlorination would appear to be advisable.

**Chlorination.**

Where vegetable matter is present, water if chlorinated becomes dark in colour, offensive in odour, and unusable in regard to taste. This is due to a direct chemical action on the vegetable content and cannot be avoided.

Since the water throughout Onion Lake carries a heavy content of vegetable matter, some form of filtration in addition, is necessary.

**Filtration.**

Filtration may be carried out by the installation of a mechanical filter or by the construction of a closed reservoir on the shore of the lake between the inlet and the present pumping plant.
The former of these proposals, with a mechanical filter as supplied by Francis Hankin & Co., may be installed at an estimated cost of $1700. This is a cost $400 in excess of the second proposal and in addition, there are several features such as maintenance charges, isolation, and inconvenience of periodical washing which render it less suitable than construction of a closed reservoir as outlined above, and herewith described.

It is proposed to sink a circular well on the shore of the lake, twenty feet in diameter and to a depth of ten feet below water level. The walls of this well would be raised to a height of three feet or more above the said water level and banked and ditched round, clean sand and gravel being used in all filtration areas. The said well or reservoir to be properly roofed and covered and provided with manhole and facilities for examination.

The reservoir would have a capacity of some 19,650 gallons at normal water height. Its advantages would be capacity, cost, simplicity of construction, convenience of construction inasmuch as the existing plant would not be disturbed, and the fact that it could at all times be readily pumped out and cleaned.

Filtration and Chlorination.

The chlorination of the water supply as outlined above could be carried out at any time with satisfactory results, inasmuch as the vegetable content would be removed and chloride could be applied.

Stocking the lake with suitable fish.

In addition to the matter of filtration, in order to keep down the growth of minute vegetable matter as shown in the water content together with insect life and leaches, it is strongly advised that the lake be stocked with perch and sucker. These species live entirely on the matter in question and, in the opinion of the Inspector of Fisheries, would greatly improve the existing conditions.

Recommendation.

It is recommended that a filtration plant consisting of a circular well as described above be constructed at Onion Lake Church of England Indian School in connection with the existing plant and that in regard to the matter of stocking the lake with suitable fish in an effort to improve preliminary conditions, further advice be obtained.

The cost of construction on the lines outlined and depicted on the accompanying plan is estimated at $1270.

(Sgd) David Whittaker
A.M.E.I.C.

Memorandum,

MR. FERRIER

Re Onion Lake School Water Supply.

May I advise as follows:

1. Unqualified approval cannot be given a water supply from a land locked lake of 400 acres, to which cattle and people have ready access, and from which the water is used untreated.

2. The scheme proposed by Mr. Whittaker seems good, but I should want to be assured that the filter well will not freeze.

3. Automatic chlorinating apparatus has not given good results in our institutions except where someone has been found to give it careful supervision; "someone" having invariably been a person who has a technical knowledge of such apparatus.

4. I think you should look forward to improving this supply in the near future, but, in the prevailing state of funds, it might be left off for another year. In the meantime I might suggest the following:

(a) Try to ensure that the lake is not obviously contaminated by water closets etc. or any preventable access by cattle or people.

(b) Try to devise some small and cheap experiment to see whether a well will fill at the edge of the lake, what sort of strata will be met with in digging, and whether it will freeze.
(c) Find out who is to be responsible for keeping the system in order.

I visited this school on May 5th, and made a complete inspection of the buildings and noted conditions generally. There are 99 pupils in residence; 4 were sick in bed on the day of my visit, 2 of whom appeared to be quite sick, their trouble being of a tubercular nature.

I visited the pupils in the classroom, and noted that they had a clean and healthy appearance, and they appeared to be making good progress in their classroom work. Some of the older pupils are given half day work on the farm and at domestic employments, and half day in the classroom. Two teachers are employed; Miss Boate has a second class permanent Manitoba certificate, and Miss Fairservice has a first class certificate from New Brunswick. She has had ten years experience in teaching, and appears to be well qualified.

I noted that they had an ample quantity of wholesome nourishing food for their lunch, consisting of pork, potatoes, turnips, bread, and sago pudding.

I found the school clean throughout. I may say that this school has not had any interior decoration since it was built over six years ago, and some of the rooms are beginning to look as though they require it. I may say that the plaster work in this school has stood up remarkably well and is in good condition.

It is noted that they are still using the hay mattresses in the dormitories. I did not need to have my attention drawn to this as I could smell them as soon as I entered the dormitory. This matter has been reported on before. In my opinion, it would be very desirable.
ONION LAKE C. of E. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

very desirable to have these mattresses replaced with woollen mattresses. They have a few on hand now, but would require 36 - 6 ft. and 35 - 5 ft. mattresses to meet their requirements.

With regard to the equipment, the pumping plant is giving splendid satisfaction and an hour's pumping each day gives them all the water they require. The fire hose and equipment I found in good shape.

Something appears to be the matter with the large engine used for generating electricity and for running the laundry machinery. The valves in this engine burn out regularly, and have to be replaced at least once a month. This may be the result of an overload.

The hot water boiler used in connection with the range for heating hot water for the kitchen will have to be replaced. There is some ingredient in the water which is hard on metal, and this boiler is eaten through in many places. It is an 82 gallon horizontal range boiler. I may say that this boiler should be replaced at once.

The water supply, as reported previously, is obtained from the lake. This water is hard, and a request has been made by the school authorities for a water softening plant. The school building is equipped with eavestroughing, but no storage facilities are provided for soft water, and all the rain water caught by the roof is allowed to go to waste.

The outbuildings are in a good state of repair. They have a large supply of firewood on hand, which has been sawn up and is very neatly piled. The premises
ONION LAKE C. OF E. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

premises have been cleaned up and presented a very creditable and neat appearance.

The farm last year produced 122 bus. of wheat, 607 bus. of oats, and 930 bus. of barley. They had 631 bus. of potatoes, and a large quantity of other roots and vegetables sufficient for their requirements. There is 110 acres of land under cultivation in connection with the school.

They have now 23 cattle, including 14 milk cows, 7 of which they are milking at present, and the other 7 are expected to freshen very soon. I took up the question of the girls receiving training in milking, and was assured that they were given an opportunity during the summer months. They have 5 brood sows and 10 other pigs, 25 turkeys, some geese, and about 60 hens. The farm work is in charge of a practical farmer.

Frequent practice at fire drill is given the pupils, and they are called up occasionally during the night at unexpected times, and I am informed that at the last midnight call the pupils evacuated the school in two minutes.

The Rev. H. Ellis is in charge as Principal. Mr. Littlewood, the engineer, is an expert in his line. Mr. Spooner, the Farming Instructor, appears to be a practical farmer. There are seven women members on the staff, including the two teachers.

Dear Sir:

Carrying out your instructions at the Anglican Indian School at Onion Lake, Viz. To repair the two pressure tanks of about sixteen thousand gallon capacity and to inspect the same as to their condition, and also re-placing the eighty-two gallon range boiler.

On October 18th, I made the necessary repairs to the tanks by welding three patches on the same. I took the man-hole covers off the tanks, cleaned them thoroughly, and made an inspection of the tanks. I found the material below the water of the tanks to be eaten away by the character of the water which is being used at the school. There are hundreds of places throughout the tank, where the material is already eaten away to a thin shell. The average size of these places are from three to four inches in diameter, and the action penetrates the material to a point where it fairly comes through to the outside of the tank, about one eighth of an inch, and continues to get larger. The tanks are absolutely ruined, and will require replacing. The galvanized range boiler which I replaced, I found to be the same, and was beyond repair. I also found the piping system being gradually eaten away, and, if allowed to continue, the whole system of piping will need replacing in the near future. Both the plumbing system as well as the heating system, especially the wet return piping.

Therefore I recommend the installation of two new 4 by 16 ft pressure tanks, as the present ones will be a source of continuous expense in repairs, and would possibly be out of order just when needed in case of fire. I also recommend the installation of a water softening system to avoid further trouble, and also for the protection of the health of the children and the staff, as the analysis of the water proves it to be very injurious to health as well as to the equipment.

Your's Truly,

R P Spies.

As he assured me that the engine had to be overhauled, there was no course open for me but to have him send it down here, which was done at a cost of $8.00. The return freight would also be $8.00. I sent it over to Fairbanks-Morse, and all they did was

by P.A. Fetterly, B.Sc., A.M.E.I.C.

Purpose of Report.

An inspection of the existing water supply system of St. Barnabas School was made on July 5th, 6th and 7th, 1932, instructions having been received from the Director in a letter dated June 10th, 1932. This was accompanied by a copy of a letter dated May 30th, 1932, from the Department of Indian Affairs, containing authorization for the inspection. The inspector was requested to report as to the advisability of installing a water softener in addition to the other improvements.

Reason for Inspection.

Complaints were received at the offices of the Indian Department in Ottawa that the water was injuriously affecting the plumbing and heating systems, including the pressure tanks, because of the presence of certain salts, causing the water to be very hard and corroding the metal. The presence of a large amount of vegetable matter was also potentially injurious hygienically. It is visible and is held in suspension.

Results of Former Inspections.

Many water samples have been analysed and the complaints were found to be justified. The results of analyses are on file. Officers of this Bureau reported on general conditions under date of May 9th, 1930 and also in 1931.

Results of Present Inspection.

Three principal subsystems were studied, all however, being related to the general water supply system. These will be dealt with in the order of importance, i.e. in the order in which repair or replacement should be carried out, in the opinion of the
Principal, the School Engineer, and also of the writer.

(a) Pressure Tanks.

These are also called pneumatic tanks. They are two in number and are 16 ft. long by 4 ft. in diameter. They lie horizontally and parallel to each other. The water in the lake can be pumped directly into them by the main pump at the lake, or they may be filled from the reservoir.

It was found that the corrosive action of the water due to possible chemical and (or) electrolytic action from the dissolved salts and decayed vegetable matter in the lake water, has badly injured the metal of the tanks. Certain areas are covered with blisters an inch or so in diameter. When broken open these blisters are found to be filled with a corrosive "pus" which apparently gradually corrodes the metal, causing holes to appear. The destroyed portion is cone-shaped with the base inside the tank. The sharp angle gradually spreads and touches the surface. These tanks will not stand the "hammer test", i.e., one dare not strike them with a hammer. The hammer is liable to break the metal. Several holes have already appeared which have been plugged by the Engineer. The portion mostly affected is naturally that below the water line, but turning them upside down would be ill-advised because the weakened portions now under water would not stand the air pressure or hold the air.

The Engineer is compelled to keep the air pressure below 20 pounds instead of at least 75 pounds which should be the working pressure.

It may be parenthetically noted that the boiler is in ever present danger of being similarly affected. It was, of course, impossible to examine the inside of the pipes, radiators, boiler, etc., to ascertain possible damage.

Any new pressure tanks provided should be painted on the inside with a coat of red lead and another of a bituminous paint, e.g., Dr. Smith's Solution.
Filter Tank at the Lake.

Water for the system is drawn from a lake 800 ft. to the south. This lake has neither inlet or outlet. The inlet valve for the pipe is about 100 ft. from the shore and 80 ft. below the School. The general layout is shown on the accompanying plan.

As before mentioned, the water is drawn directly into the pressure tanks or the reservoir at the School without treatment, except for Chloride of Lime which is added at the rate of one teaspoonful per 1,000 gals. The salts, vegetable matter, etc., are thus left in the water.

It is proposed to erect a sand and gravel timber filter at the edge of the lake to extract the major portion of obnoxious solid matter. The bottom of the lake consists of 3 or 4 ft. of muck overlying sand. The tank may be joined to the lake by an inclined filter bed of sand and gravel as shown on the plan, if the tank alone does not receive sufficient seepage water.

It may here be noted that the writer has been told that the Gordon Indian School at Punnichy, Sask., tried this alone without a water softener but was unsuccessful, and was compelled to add a softener in the School.

If it be decided to construct a trench also, the area to be excavated will have to be coffer-dammed.

Tests were made by the Chief Engineer of Fort Saskatchewan Jail near Edmonton as to the rate of seepage into a similar system well. He stated, under interview by the writer, that the water seeped at the rate of one half pint per minute per sq. ft. of surface. At this rate the proposed tank would receive 9,600 gals. per day. The requirements of the School are about 4,000 gals. per day of filtered and softened water.

It is to be remembered that this proposed filter is intended only to dispose of the coarser vegetable and other injurious matter, and does not affect the dissolved salt content. This coarser material would quickly choke up a proposed water softener.

This filter tank should be so connected with the main 2½ in. pipe line from the lake that gate valves can be installed in order...
that water may be drawn directly from the lake or filter tank at will, e.g., in case of fire.

The lower portion of the pipe, containing strainer and foot valve, should be surrounded with a perforated metal box 2'x2'x2' for protection from debris. The capacity of the tank to water level 11½' in diameter by 11' high, is about 6,500 gallons.

A surface ditch 2½' wide by 2' deep should surround the tank 2½' away to collect surface drainage.

Provision should be made to cover the tank and manhole with straw a least 6 ft. thick for frost protection.

Water Softener.

This machine consists of a mechanical filter connected with a brine tank which extracts the salt content from the hard water. The regular filter consisting of sand and gravel will not do this. The Zeolitic Water Softener manufactured by the Crane people performs this action. An installation by Crane's in Prince Albert City Waterworks Station was examined by the writer recently. It performs its work to the complete satisfaction of the City Engineer who described its action to the writer. It could be placed in the boiler room and connected with the existing system by pipe and gate valves as shown on the accompanying plan. An area 7 ft. long by 5 or 6 ft. wide is available.

The argument may be recapitulated by stating that a filter will remove solid matter but not salts. A softener will remove the salts. Both are present damaging the system.

Chlorination.

The filter (b) and water softener (c) dispose of the solid matter and the salts. Neither, however, take care of all of the germ impurities. The only known method for this is chlorine, usually administered in the form of chloride of lime. At Present this is added to the reservoir at the rate of one teaspoonful per 1,000 gallons. The Prince Albert authorities use chlorine gas administered by a rather expensive machine. In this case it can be added manually as at present.
Extension of the present Pump House and exchange of the coal stove for a wood stove.

The present coal stove should be exchanged for a wood stove as only wood is available for fuel.

The Pumphouse was originally 10' by 10'. An addition 6' by 10' was made on the west side. A similar extension should be made on the east side for storing wood fuel, making a building 22' by 10'.

Present Reservoir.

This reservoir should be painted on the inside with a waterproofing paint as checks are beginning to appear in the concrete which must in time cause leakage.

Extension of the Pipe Line.

The pipe line now extends into the lake about 100 feet. It might be extended another 100 feet, although one thinks that this is hardly necessary if the other improvements be made.

Vegetation.

OPINION.

Regina, June 16, 1926.

All surface water supplies in Saskatchewan including rivers, lakes, streams, and sloughs are dangerous for domestic purposes and should not be used without some form of treatment. Water should be passed through a filter or chlorinated.

R.H. Murray, C.E.
Director, Division of Sanitation.

The statements on the reverse side of this sheet are part of this opinion.
The opinion given overleaf is based upon the detailed information recently furnished regarding the source of supply and on the foregoing laboratory findings.

If the source is satisfactory, care should be taken to protect it against future contamination.

If the source is doubtful, the improvements recommended should be given effect to at once.

If the source is unsafe, the supply should be abandoned, or the water boiled until such time as the suggested changes are made, and another opinion obtained from this Division.

INTERPRETATION OF LABORATORY FINDINGS.

TOTAL SOLIDS - Generally speaking, an ideal drinking water should not contain more than 50 grains per gallon of total solids. Wells on the prairie, however, usually show a much larger amount. The maximum amount of total solids permissible in a drinking water varies in accordance with relative quantities of the constituents. For this reason a water containing several times the quantity named might be pronounced satisfactory. In certain circumstances the cumulative effect of drinking a hard water may affect the health of the consumer.

NITRITES - The presence of nitrites ordinarily indicates contamination in the water from decaying animal matter or from animal excrement.

ORGANIC MATTER - Underground streams, unless very shallow are filtered free of organic matter. The presence of organic matter in a well usually points to defects in the cover or cribbing.

BACTERIA - Drinking water should have a count of less than 100 bacteria per cubic centimeter. (A cubic centimeter is equal to about one-third of a teaspoonful.)

E. COLI - Is an organism or germ which comes from the intestinal tract of animals and human beings. Its presence in a water indicates that the same is contaminated with waste matter of human or animal origin, and that dysentery, typhoid fever or other intestinal diseases may be transmitted by the water.

Regina, Sask., 14th November, 1932

St. Barnabas C. of E. Residential School

I visited this school on the afternoon of October 20th last. The Reverend Henry Ellis is in charge as Principal and the school is operated under the auspices of the Church of England. The staff consists of a Farming Instructor, Engineer, Matron, three lady assistants, and two qualified teachers.

There are 102 pupils enrolled, all of whom were present at the time of my visit. The children presented a clean and healthy appearance and there was no sickness at that time. In addition to the classroom work, the girls are taught sewing, cooking, knitting, and laundry work, the boys feeding and care of stock, milking, and odd carpentry work. The Provincial School Inspector speaks favorably of conditions in the classroom and mentions that there is improvement in the methods used, although he found it necessary to make certain suggestions.

The main building was erected in 1924. It is a frame building and is standing up well. The workmanship appears to have...
appears to have been of a good class. I found the building well cared for and clean and tidy. It has electric lighting and running water throughout. It has outside fire escapes to which accessible outlets are provided on each floor. Two stand pipes with hose connections on each floor are connected with the pressure tanks. I examined the fire fighting equipment and found it all in good order. The children are given regular fire drill.

I may point out however that the pressure tanks will have to be renewed. There appears to be an ingredient in the lake water which eats into the iron and the bottoms of these tanks are now practically honey-combed. My attention was drawn to holes one half inch in diameter which had been stopped with wooden plugs. There is no possible way of repairing these tanks and in a short time they will be utterly useless, as they will not stand the pressure required to force the water throughout the building. As a measure of safety I would advise replacing them at once. The Boiler Inspector left a memorandum in connection with certain equipment including two globe valves and two check valves with the necessary unions and nipples to be installed in the boiler as a measure of safety. I have not obtained an estimate yet of the cost of this installation, but I would judge that it would probably amount to $15.00.

The pumping unit at the lake is giving good satisfaction. Water is pumped from the lake as distance of about 750 feet up a steep incline into a cement storage tank, from which it is pumped into the pressure tanks. I have obtained an analysis of the water with a view to finding out if some compound could not be used to counteract the effects of the ingredients in the water which destroy the boilers and water pipes.

- The outbuilding -
The outbuildings are in a good state of repair. They have a good frame building, 24' x 40', which could be made into a useful storage building if placed on a cement foundation. This could be done at little expense and would provide a great deal of useful storage space. The other buildings were in good shape.

The garden produced 370 bushels of potatoes and ample vegetables for their requirements.

One section of land is set aside for the use of this school. Their crop this year consisted of 16 acres of barley which yielded 414 bushels, 60 acres of oats yielded 1934 bushels, 45 acres of green feed, and 40 acres were summer-fallowed in preparation for next year's crop.

The live stock consist of 36 cattle, 96 hogs, about 300 hens, 100 turkeys, and four work horses. Twenty of the cattle are milk cows, 10 of which were milking at the time of my visit and 10 were due to freshen during the winter.

The foregoing report is respectfully submitted.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison,
Inspector,

Report on Locomotive Tye Heating Boiler.
This boiler was opened up and examined thoroughly washed out and found to be in good condition.

Tubes showed very little scale and shell of boiler is not pitted to any appreciable extent.

Improvements suggested check valve on water feed line and a Blow down valve at bottom of water column.

Hot Water tank and colorifer. This was opened and examined. The colorifer pipes had a heavy scale on and the shell of the tank was pitted in places to a depth of 3/16". The tank was washed out and the scale removed.

General Condition: poor.

Both Tubs and Tanks will have to be replaced at no distant date.

Condition of piping.

The piping of the heating and water systems have been inspected and are generally in a bad condition. The sections of pipe that have had to be taken out are very badly corroded and in many cases almost blocked up with (Scale) a deposit of the consistency of hard lime also the metal is in many places through with corrosion. Up to the present several of the pipes have had to be replaced due to this fault.

Samples of pipe that I have taken out will be kept for your inspection.

(sd) William A. Thibault.
(for Harold Dye).

Sir,-

With further reference to my letter of 20th ultimo, regarding the repair of the Water Supply System at St. Barnabas (C. of E.) Indian School, Onion Lake, Sask., I can now send all of the invoices to date.

The two new pressure tanks, water softener, and all repairs to the system which are at present necessary, have been installed.

The only portion not finished is the filter tank at the lake. The temperature in this area during most of the time of installation was 20 to 30 below zero. The excavation for the tank continued favourably until Christmas. The excavators, however, struck three large veins of water at 7 feet. They could not control the water with the available equipment. (The school is 40 miles north of Lloydminster, in the woods). Consequently they requested Mr. Fetterly to go to the scene with a proper pump. He went to Onion Lake with a centrifugal pump and attempts were made to clear the excavation of water. After 28 days of useless endeavour, because of the extreme cold and freezing up of equipment, it was decided to temporarily abandon the filter tank until milder weather ensued. The work could have eventually been finished at the time but the appropriation would have entirely disappeared as money was being expended with nothing accomplished. It was then decided to install the pressure tanks and water softener immediately. The filter tank can be finished towards the end of March just before the ice goes out, and when the weather is milder. At that time the necessary clearing of earth in the bottom of the lake in front of the filter trench can also be finished. Meanwhile, the water being used is taken directly from the lake as before. The principal reported on January 26th as follows:- "I am pleased to report that the system is working very satisfactory and the water softener has made a wonderful change in the water."

Because of the severe weather and deep snow, extra materials were difficult to obtain. The steamfitter was not called to the job until the inside equipment was ready for installation. As a consequence the condition of the old installations could not be known until he had disassembled the plant. This is the reason for the invoices from various firms in Lloydminster. In order to save the time of the men, extra material was ordered from that point by the ordinary supply team or the mail carrier. I am sending the following invoices, the payment of which is to be made direct by the Department of Indian Affairs:-

The Director,
Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
Department of the Interior,
Ottawa.
1. Harold Dye, Steamfitter, North Battleford, Sask.

This man had to be transported from and to North Battleford, 79 miles, by train; and 40 miles through deep snow to Onion Lake. His travelling expenses were paid. $147.00.

2. Electrical Engineers Limited, Calgary, Alberta.

This account is for the centrifugal pump which was taken by Mr. Fetterly to clear the excavation of water, including rental and freight Calgary to Lloydminster, $14.22.

3. Electrical Engineers Limited, Calgary, Alberta.

This account is for freight, returning pump to Calgary, $3.98.

4. Geo. Devlin, 1172, Yorke St. North Battleford, Sask.

Mr. Devlin, the carpenter, transported the three laborers from North Battleford to Onion Lake, 130 miles in his car, the school being isolated in the woods. He paid their expenses on the trip. He also had to purchase several tools and telegrams. $33.45.

5. R.P. Spies, Lloydminster.

Extra supplies for repairing hot water tank and connections, caused by previous erosion, by hard water. Not found until dismantled. $28.22.

6. Miller Hardware, Lloydminster.

Extra supplies as above $10.20.

7. L.W. Hewitt, Ashley, P.O., via Lloydminster.

Dye and Devlin for work performed on the Water Supply at St. Barnabas School, Onion Lake, Sask., I immediately communicated with these men, requesting vouchers in triplicate for various items in the accounts as mentioned by you.

Mr. Devlin lives in North Battleford but was expected to be on his way to Onion Lake, 140 miles away, to finish the filter tank. As a consequence my letter may have to follow him and thus cause delay. At any rate I have not heard from him.

In your original letter of March lst you only marked one item in Mr. Devlin's account, viz:- telegram 65¢ as requiring vouchers. I obtained vouchers, in triplicate, for this account and sent it to you. That is the reason for lack of vouchers for the other items.

I received a letter today from Mr. Dye, who is in North Battleford. In order to prevent further misunderstanding, I will describe the matter in detail.

Referring to the copy of the letter from N.C. Allen, Representative of the Treasury, dated March 30, he states as follows:

"Mr. Dye's accounts (C.N.R. freight) amount respectively to $2.22 and $1.30, add to $3.52, not $3.86". Mr. Allen has apparently overlooked the voucher for $1.64 for freight from Lloydminster to North Battleford.

However, in order to clear matters I requested Mr. Dye to obtain triplicate vouchers for $1.30 with a notation on it to the effect that $0.74 of this amount was applicable to the freight bill between North Battleford and Lloydminster. He replied to-day to the effect that he did not understand my request but that he had obtained two new vouchers for $1.30. I came to the conclusion that it would be better to explain the matter to you.

The explanation is as follows:

Mr. Dye obtained two freight vouchers for $2.22 and $1.64 respectively; and an express voucher for $1.30 for a belated shipment of tools from North Battleford.

Sir,

Re St. Barnabas Indian School,

With further reference to your letter of the 1st ultimo regarding the accounts of George Devlin and Harold Dye I beg to report that those of the latter were returned to you on the 15th ultimo, duly corrected. Those of Mr. Devlin were obtained with more difficulty owing to his departure for Onion Lake to complete the installation of the filter tank, and the absence of Mr. Fetterly for three weeks ending May 15th on regular water power activities.

I am enclosing the accounts of Geo. Devlin with sub-vouchers attached. The total amount is $33.45.

I have also received a letter from Rev. H. Ellis, Principal, to the effect that the work has now been finally completed. Mr. Fetterly was unable to visit the school during his three weeks' absence in the north country, the roads being impassable. He will inspect the finished work on his next trip and will then submit a report. Mr. Littlewood, School Engineer, who is also a civil engineer, is satisfied with the installation. A copy of Mr. Ellis' letter is enclosed.

Three springs were intercepted at a depth of seven feet when excavating for the filter tank. One of these is nearly 2" in diameter and they will provide an unlimited supply of good water which will not be from the lake. The school is very fortunate in obtaining this supply.

I am also enclosing the wage account for the carpenter and two laborers in connection with the construction of the filter tank from April 14 to May 13 as certified by Rev. H. Ellis and Mr. Littlewood, School Engineer. These are as follows:

A letter dated January 24, 1933, was received from Dr. J.T. Hill, Indian Agent at Onion Lake, Sask., regarding wages due Geo. Devlin and his co-workers. This read as follows:

"$248.90 will be required to complete payment of wages for work done to date on the C. of E. Indian School Water-softening plant."

From the cheques Nos. 226 and 3361 for $300 each received from the Department for this purpose, we have disbursed $597.40 and have a balance of $2.60.

A summary of the payments made are as follows:

"Geo. Devlin $184.63, Tom Turner $147.02, J. Smith $124.74, Frank Longhorn $106.51, and to Indians supplying stone, gravel and sand $34.50."

In a letter dated February 13, page 3, I copied this letter in part and requested that cheque for $248.90 be sent to Dr. Hill for this purpose.

We have no means in this office of knowing whether this cheque was sent or disbursed.

At a later date Mr. Devlin stated by letter that he had not received it so I conclude that as the men had departed for their home in North Battleford, Dr. Hill was unable to pay them personally as the points are 150 miles apart with no complete rail connection.

Owing to the physical difficulties encountered in excavation for the filter tank I could not recommend any stated sum for transmission to Dr. Hill for payment of wages in order that he should have it on hand at the time of completion.

Although no communication has been received from Dr. Hill I would conclude that he has been able to pay them for the former work (previous to January 24) while they were busy in Onion Lake, in April and May, and that the total amount due them at present is $315.65 as detailed earlier in this letter.

This matter of payment of wages through Dr. Hill has been a difficult matter because of the distance between the points and their remoteness from Calgary (500 miles), and because, apparently, Dr. Hill has to pay them personally. All have been in immediate need of the wages, Frank Longhorn particularly, having existed all winter on $1.50 per week relief payment. I considered that Dr. Hill would send it by mail but he apparently cannot do this.

Three methods are available for the payment of the wages now due, viz: $315.65.

1. Send it to Dr. Hill for disbursement. The present disadvantages of this are mentioned above. It was mentioned as an alternative in your original letter of instructions dated October 19, 1932, and at the time was considered to be advantageous to the work of this office. Dr. Hill is at Onion Lake, while Geo. Devlin and Frank Longhorn are at North Battleford, although Alf. Blower resides at Onion Lake.
2. Send it to this office for disbursement by Mr. Fetterly on his next trip northward.

3. Send it direct to the three men at their various addresses.

The second method would apparently be the best to use in this case. I would therefore recommend that the following payments be made:

Geo. Devlin $33.45 for expenses of his trip in January, according to account and vouchers enclosed.

Geo. Devlin wages for April and May $153.04

Frank Longhorn wages for April and May $66.29

Alf. Blower " " " " " $22.80

Accounts outstanding consist of a small bill for fittings and for telegrams due Rev. H. Ellis; the further travelling account of Geo. Devlin for April and May, and one or two other small items. These are not yet to hand but will be attended to when received.

Your obedient servant,
