Sir,

Re St. Barnabas Indian School.

Please find enclosed the accounts remaining unpaid in connection with the Water Supply System in St. Barnabas Indian School, Lloydminster, Saskatchewan.

These accounts were principally due to the necessary renewing of certain parts of the plumbing system in the boiler and engine rooms caused from disintegration from the hard water formerly pumped from the lake. The necessity for these renewals could not be known or suspected until the pipes connected with the pressure tanks were dismantled during the new installation.

I might mention that the system cost slightly more than was expected because of this fact and because of the difficulties encountered in sinking the filter tank. Three springs were unexpectedly found at a depth of 7 feet which were very difficult to control. These springs, however, preclude the necessity of using water from the lake itself. They produce very pure water.

With the present installation, however, if the springs should fail the filter tank has direct connection with the lake through the filter trough. In other words, the school is now assured of an inexhaustible supply of pure water and may be considered to be as fortunate as any school in the West as far as water supply is concerned.

Exchange on cheques $18. File 4811.

This was incurred in connection with the repair of the Septic Tank at Blue Quills Indian School. The Indian Department were indebted to Joe Hamlin of St. Paul, Alberta, for clearing the tank, $125.00; and to the Standard Iron Works of Edmonton for repair of motor, $66.40. FINAL REPORT
ON
WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM
AT
ST. BARNABAS INDIAN SCHOOL,
Onion Lake, Sask.
by P.A. Fetterly
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

PURPOSE OF REPORT

This Report describes the installation and behaviour of the re-habilitated water supply system at St. Barnabas Indian School, Onion Lake, Saskatchewan. The final inspection was made by the writer on July 19, 1933.

FILTER TANK

This tank, which is 12 feet diameter by 14 feet deep, is sunk into the ground at the edge of the lake to a depth of about 11 feet. The water has a depth of over 8 feet and is clear and cold and pure except for the salts, the excavation having intercepted three springs.

At present no water comes from the lake through the trench as the springs possess abundant supply for all purposes, including the fire hazard. However, if more were needed it would come through the trench or the main pipe, both of which are directly connected with the lake. These inlets are kept closed at present. The tank is well built. Difficulty was encountered in excavating for the tank because of quicksand. The source of the supply should not need attention for many years. The tank will be protected from frost by means of straw cover.

The tank is lowered 3 feet by 1½ hours pumping and again fills up in 1 or 2 hours.
WATER SOFTENER

The installed Westaway Water Softener (of Canadian manufacture) is working excellently. The full supply for the school, 2400 gallons for ordinary days and 2800 gallons for wash days, passes through the machine, as measured by water meter. A total of 130 people occupy the buildings. The needed supply is never less than 1800 gallons. The average per day over one month is about 2400 gallons, or 20 gallons per capita. This is the first authentic data of school requirements known to the writer.

According to rated capacity, the softener clarifies 1400 gallons per regeneration. However, the school is using 50 lbs. of salt to regenerate 2000 gallons or more because of the expense. This is done five times per week. An average of 250 lbs. of salt is used per week. More could be used but Mr. Littlewood, the school Engineer, states that this amount gives satisfactory results.

A regeneration was performed while the writer was present. It is a simple operation.

According to the chart which is being kept, 9 sacks of 50 lbs. of salt each, were used to regenerate the 45,500 gallons of water used from July 1 to 19 or 100 gallons per pound of salt. This was done in the absence of the school Engineer and many of the staff and students on vacation. The machine does not plug. When regeneration begins the regenerating water is soapy in appearance, but it soon clears.

PRESSURE TANKS

Two new pressure tanks were installed and new
connections made where the old pipe was corroded. The work was well done and according to specifications.

A section of one of the old pipe connections, 8 inches in length and 1\(\frac{3}{4}\)" inside diameter was obtained and is in the possession of the writer. The outside of the section is coated with a yellowish-grey salt \(1/8\) thick or more. The inside is lined with salt to such an extent that the orifice is only \(5/8\) in diameter. It is quite probable that coating would be found inside most of the water pipe in the building but it would be obviously impossible to ascertain the extent. However, this possible condition will not be increased as the salts are now being removed by the softener.

**CONCLUSION**

Good material was used and the work was well done.

Referring to Mr. Mackenzie's letter of July 11, file 115-1-5 and 128247-W., last paragraph, there should be no further expenditure at this school on water supply.

---

P. A. Fetterly  
Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

Engineer-In-Charge.

Sir,

I enclose account of Mr. P.A. Fetterly for Department of Indian Affairs for $10.53. This account is in connection with Blue Quills Indian School and is chargeable to the general standing advance account.

Your letter dated July 11, 1933, No. 115-1-5, Ref. 128247 W, last paragraph, suggested that there would be no further expenditure at this school.

However, I received a letter from Rev. Jos. Angin, Principal, on September 1, as follows:

"I have not yet received any communication about the payment for the board of Mr. Fredrickson during his stay and work at School". "Could you give me any information about this?"

I therefore considered it necessary that Mr. Fetterly interview the Principal and Mr. Fredrickson on the matter, and so instructed him as follows:

"If necessary you see Fredrickson (and the Principal) and have this matter positively settled on your present trip".

As a consequence Mr. Fetterly, on his last trip from Edmonton to Prince Albert proceeded to St. Paul on September 10 and interviewed these gentlemen. He ascertained, and so reported to me, that all cheques had been received subsequent to transmission of Father Angin's letter of September 1. I had not been advised of this fact before instructing Mr. Fetterly. I hope this explanation will be satisfactory to the Department of Indian Affairs.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) O. H. Hoover,
Engineer-In-Charge.

Dear Sir:

The stock barn at our Onion Lake School has accommodation for twenty animals only, and as the horses and cows have to be housed in this building it is altogether too small for the purpose. Twelve horses are required to handle the farm work, and the Principal finds that twenty milk cows are necessary to provide an adequate supply of milk. Under existing circumstances a number of the cows have no shelter during the winter, and our Commission are keenly desirous of having the situation remedied. The Principal recommends the immediate erection of an additional barn for the cows and their offspring, and estimates the cost, including the Beatty fixtures, at approximately $3500.00. In the comprehensive list of requirements forwarded to your Department last October, to be provided this year, this additional barn was included, as well as an implement shed ($300.00), and a cottage for the Engineer or Farmer ($500.00), and if you are unable to provide all of these buildings, our Commission would recommend that the additional stock barn be given priority of claim.

Your careful and sympathetic consideration of this urgent need will be highly appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Ellis:

This letter is in confirmation of the conversation we had with you on Wednesday last, with reference to your refrigeration problem at the Indian School at Onion Lake.

As you know, in company with Mr. Leonard, we checked over your present arrangement for handling your meats and food, and, as intimated to you during our conversation, your present system may have answered your purpose in the past, but in view of the fact that it is possible for you to install a proper refrigerator in the basement of your school and operate same electrically at the cost of a few hundred dollars, we have no hesitation in saying to you definitely that you will be able to save the price of your equipment in two years time. Where you are serving the number of meals you are per day, approximately 450 meals a day, it is just impossible for you to handle your food supplies economically with your present equipment.

With Genuine Frigidaire Equipment we can guarantee to you a constant temperature. This temperature will be controlled by your requirements and you will readily appreciate that where you are buying food supplies to feed as many people as you are at your school, it is absolutely imperative that proper refrigeration be used if you are to have economical results. With proper refrigeration all trimming of meats is eliminated; you can purchase in larger quantities and hold satisfactorily for a period of three to four weeks. Further, when you place anything in your refrigerator you are assured that you will find it in a satisfactory condition when required and we know that you will heartily agree with us that your present arrangement does not give you this service. Furthermore, the great advantage of Frigidaire equipment which is seldom appreciated until used is the fact that we give you a positive control of the humidity of your refrigerator. This point is absolutely impossible with any other make of refrigerator and you thoroughly appreciate that humidity is a great essential in the proper handling of meats and other food stuffs. The humidity in refrigerators cooled by W.K. Frigidaire Diamond Fin cooling coils is handled automatically.

After discussing your requirements with you and checking over the conditions under which your installation will be made, we submit herewith the following specifications:
QUOTATION:

We will supply and install the following equipment:

1 only Walkin Refrigerator 5½' wide, 9' long, 8' high, outside measurements.

The insulation of this job will be: 2" of corkboard set in hydroline with wax paper on both sides.

The Walkin refrigerator will be built in sections so that it is portable. In other words, this refrigerator will be supplied in nine sections and if at any future time you should wish to change the location it can be taken down the same as any other portable piece of equipment that you may have.

In the 5½' end of this refrigerator will be:
one only Walkin Refrigerator Door, size 24" wide x 6' high.
This door will be equipped with brass roller bearing hinges and automatic hasp refrigerator door will be equipped with Wirt gaskets and a workmenlike job will be done in every respect.

The interior of this walkin refrigerator will be thoroughly shellacked, making it impervious to moisture.

After the walkin refrigerator is erected we will install therein:
1 only WX476 Frigidaire Diamond Fin Cooling Coil.
This coil will be 78" long, 14" wide and 7" high.
This coil will be installed to control the temperature.

1 only TS Automatic Expansion Valve.

Outside of your refrigerator will be installed:
1 only Frigidaire Flowing Cold Air Compressor model 20,
21½" wide, 28" long, 16-1/8" high, 1/5 H.P., direct current.

We will supply the above Refrigerator and Frigidaire Equipment and install same complete for the sum of $732.50. This price includes the freight to Lloydminster, but does not include the cartage from Lloydminster to Onion Lake, as we understand that you have private ways of carting your supplies from Lloydminster to Onion Lake.

In submitting the above quotation to you for your consideration, we have included a properly constructed walkin refrigerator suitable for your purpose and you will specially note that we have specified 2" of corkboard set in hydroline and covered with wax paper. In constructing a Frigidaire in this manner it enables us to reduce the heat leakage to a minimum. By doing this we are assuring you at all times of a constant even temperature, as you may desire, and to do this with minimum operating time, consequently less cost of operation and less depreciation.

Under separate cover we are mailing you a descriptive catalogue and we are marking on this catalogue specific specifications that we wish you would take the time to study and if you do this we feel that you will agree with us that considerable care and precision is exerted in the manufacture of Genuine Frigidaire Equipment.
As you already know, we have many commercial installations consisting of institutional work, restaurants and hotels throughout the province of Saskatchewan, and as far as we know, they are all giving satisfaction. We have no hesitation in saying that we can promise you the same satisfactory performance with this equipment.

In concluding permit us to point out to you the fact that Mr. H. Leonard of Lloydminster, is one of the best Frigidaire engineers in Western Canada. When he was at our factory attending school training him for Frigidaire work he passed all examinations with an average of 98%. Following this he served six years in practical experience and at all times his judgment and method of installation has met with the hearty approval of factory inspectors, and we have no hesitation in assuring you of a workmanlike job in every respect. Mr. Leonard is thoroughly competent in every way and you are particularly fortunate in having him located at Lloydminster.

Concluding, if there is any further information we can give you concerning the above equipment, do not hesitate to get in touch with us and at this time we wish to extend to you our appreciation of your courteous treatment when visiting you a few days ago.

Yours truly,

THE J. H. ASHDOWN HARDWARE CO., Limited,

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 20th instant, I would say that it is expected that residential school authorities will be responsible for minor replacements and small repairs in connection with boilers, engines and electric systems, and for the supplying of all electric light bulbs required at the school.

It is considered that the school should have on their staff a competent engineer or handyman who would be able to make small repairs to the equipment. The Department will provide the cost, if funds permit, of any extensive replacements or repairs.

In many cases, principals of residential schools seem to rely on the Department to carry out minor repairs and replacements which are properly the responsibility of the school management and which should be paid from the per capita allowance or other receipts of the school.

Dear Sir:

The Rev. Principal Ellis of our Onion Lake School, has directed the attention of our Commission to the need of a new engine to operate the lighting plant at his school. He states that the engine now in use (this is a 15 h.p. Fairbanks-Morse, horizontal oil engine Z type, with high tension rotary magneto) "has never carried a full load during the winter season", and recommends that a 25 h.p. Diesel engine, either Lister or Fairbanks-Morse be secured.

As there is a 25 h.p. Fairbanks-Morse "Y" horizontal engine, style H. No. C27732 not in use in the power house at our Elkhorn School, it has occurred to me that it might meet the needs of our Onion Lake School, and I am writing for the specific purpose of recommending that you instruct your Inspector Hamilton of Winnipeg to have the Elkhorn engine carefully examined and furnish you with a recommendation as to the advisability of having it utilized in the way I have suggested.

Sir:-

I visited the St. Barnabas C/E Indian Residential School on the 9th instant and met the Provincial School Inspector, Mr. Hicks.

I found the school building in excellent condition throughout. The premises also presented a neat and tidy appearance. The hot water boiler should be replaced at once. This boiler is badly pitted and the holes are breaking through. There is some agency in the water at this school which is hard on boiler plate. I think that the damage was largely done before the water softener was installed. The boiler in use now was made by the Vulcan Iron Works, 48" x 10' in size with a man-hole in the head. The cost of the boiler F.O.B. Lloydminster is $356.10. The 15 H.P. engine which is used for generating light and running the laundry and pumping machinery is done. It is impossible to generate more than 30 amperes and it pounds badly when generating that amount. Sixty amperes are required for the full load. I have several times reported on this engine in the past as being too small for the work it is called upon to do. It has been working since its installation with an over-load, with the result that it has been continually burning out valves and has not been very satisfactory. I have in mind that it might be possible to pick up a good engine from some town where their power unit has been discontinued and power is being supplied by one of the Power Companies. I am making enquiry with a view to locating such an engine should it be authorized. There is no doubt that this engine is getting to the point where it will have to be

- replaced -

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
replaced.

The water supply system appeared to be in good working order, also the fire equipment. The pupils are given fire drill regularly twice a month. A night watchman has been engaged for duty during the period that the furnaces will be in operation.

There are 97 pupils enrolled, 50 boys and 47 girls. The Principal informed me that it was his desire to obtain authorization to admit 10 more children, as he has accommodation for them. The health of the children appeared to be very good and they presented a bright and well nourished appearance. When visiting the dormitories I examined the mattresses and found that they were not in good condition. They have been using straw mattresses and even with frequent changes they are not satisfactory. I noticed a strong smell from them and they did not appear to be very comfortable. I mentioned this condition in my report on this school dated May 14th, 1931, and understood at that time that the Agent was asked to include them in his Estimates. Apparently the matter has not received attention. They require 40 mattresses 5 ft. long and 36 mattresses 6 ft. long.

Farm

The farm crop was light owing to insufficient moisture in the early part of the season. The soil at this farm is very light and early maturing. They threshed 359 bus. of No. 2 Nor. wheat, 316 bus. of oats, 119 bus. of barley, and 96 acres in green feed. Their potatoe and vegetable crop was very good and they have procured 822 bus. of potatoes, 200 lbs. cabbage, 105 lbs. carrots, 70 lbs. beets, 90 lbs. parsnips, and over 200 lbs. turnips. They will be well supplied with roots and vegetables.

The stock comprises 40 head of cattle, 14 milk cows, 7 work horses, 80 hogs, 80 turkeys, and 163 hens.

The foregoing is respectfully submitted.

Your obedient servant,

I would request that, at your early convenience, you will have the engine referred to, at the Elkhorn School, examined, and, if you consider it is in fair condition, you might have any necessary repairs made and arrange to ship the engine, addressed to Rev. Ottawa, April 14th, 1936.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your 99-16 of the 31st ultimo, enclosing sketch and estimated cost of a proposed new engine room and heated garage for the Onion Lake C. E. Indian Residential School.

No funds have been specifically provided for this purpose in our appropriation for the current fiscal year. The Department has, however, provided $400 for alterations to the barn and $300 for miscellaneous repairs, or a total of $700. Owing to the reduction in our appropriation, this is the only amount that can be allowed for the Onion Lake C. E. Residential School this year. If the Principal would prefer to erect the proposed addition at a cost of $590., the Department is prepared to consider this matter favourably on the understanding that its cost would be taken out of the $700 provided in the current year's Estimates.

Please discuss the matter further with him and advise me in order that the Principal's request may receive further consideration.

Would the expenditure be less if an addition was built sufficient to enlarge the engine room but without providing a heated garage? The Department doubts the necessity of building the latter.

You should direct the attention of the Principal to the fact that the Department's appropriation has been reduced and, consequently, only expenditures that are absolutely necessary can be considered.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I have Mr. Pratt's memorandum of the first instant, requesting information regarding the Onion Lake R.C. (St. Anthony's) and the Onion Lake Church of England Indian Residential Schools.

The Department owns both these schools. The St. Anthony's (R.C.) School was erected during the fiscal year 1927-28. The Church of England School was erected during the fiscal year 1925-26.

These schools are located on reserves, and the Church Authorities did not possess ownership in the buildings that were in use previous to the erection of the new schools.

Attached hereto are statements, showing the total cost of buildings and the furnishings, equipment, and repairs carried out during each fiscal year since these schools were erected.

No painting has been done to the exterior of the St. Anthony's (R.C.) School since the building was erected. Funds were provided to have the exterior of the school painted in the summer of 1936, but the Principal of the School and the Church Authorities requested that the funds be utilized, instead, in repairing water and fire protection services.

The exterior of the Church of England School building and the outbuildings were painted during the summer of 1930 and in the summer of 1936.

Encl.

Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following with reference to the semi-Deisel engine that was shipped from the Makhorn Indian Residential School, Manitoba, to the C. of R. Indian Residential School, Onion Lake. The engine is now installed in its new building in Onion Lake, but it arrived in bad condition and the following repairs are needed: The head of combustion chamber is cracked and should be replaced by a new one together with a new gasket. The air suction valve also needs replacement. The relief valve requires grinding. The stuffing box on the water pump should be welded, and the cooling tanks need repairs. In addition the following parts are missing: exhaust pipe, 10', burner bracket, burner bracket support, burner shield, heating torch, thermometer and the fittings for connecting cooling tanks. A new pulley will be required to adapt generator speed to the speed of engine installed. It is estimated that the cost of replacing the missing parts, making the necessary repairs, purchasing the new pulley, together with the labour involved in overhauling and fitting parts, would be approximately $150.00. I would be pleased to receive authority to purchase the pieces referred to and to make the necessary repairs. Apart from the above the engine is in good condition and should give complete satisfaction.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Hill,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have the honour to refer to your 116-1-5, of July 24th, which authorized the expenditure of $976.35, for the erection of a building and the installing of an engine and generator at the C. of R. Indian Residential School. The above amount proved to be more than enough for the purposes for which it was intended, but not sufficient for the extra voucher, No. 100, of Oct. 7, for $24.00 made against it for repairs to generator. The generator in use at this school had suddenly ceased to function early in September and I had it repaired immediately, and assuming that the $976.35 would take care of the work with the other work to be done, I put through a voucher on the above authority. In this I was mistaken and in my explanation for exceeding the amount by $65.42.

The authority asked for on November 8th for $160.00 and conceded in your 116-1-5, of the 19th instant, for supplying missing and extra parts for the semi-Diesel engine is proving insufficient as the last purchase from Messrs Fairbanks-Morse Co., cost us $60.00 more than we had anticipated. Consequently the total cost of this will be $120.00. The installation of this engine is now completed. It is running perfectly and giving complete satisfaction.

Hot Water Boiler. A new hot water boiler to replace an old one at this school was forwarded by Inspector Murison and had to be installed, as it was beyond the capabilities of the school staff. I got the crew working on the new building to do the work. The old boiler had to be taken out, and, owing to its weight, 600 pounds, and location in the building, proved a difficult and expensive operation. It was situated close to and parallel with the outer wall, at an elevation of eight feet, and was supported by vertical gas piping. A strong scaffold had to be built on which to turn it, and two windows with their frames had to be removed to permit its exit, and replaced after the new boiler was placed in position. In addition, the fittings and connections on the new boiler were different from those on the old, and some expense was involved in procuring the extra fitting, etc. The cost for this work was $47.15, and I would be pleased to receive authority to issue vouchers for this amount.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Hill,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, December 9th, 1936.

Regarding the installing of the hot water boiler, it is noted that it was necessary to obtain some extra fittings and connections and that other expense was involved in installation, to a cost of $47.15. You may forward vouchers in triplicate, properly certified, covering this expenditure, when payment will be made. If there are any charges for freight or express, you should see that proper receipts accompany the vouchers.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie.

Dear Mr. Ellis:

At the request of our Mr. Harry Leonard of the Electric Shop of Lloydminster, I am submitting herewith a quotation on a Walk-In Refrigerator complete with Frigidaire equipment suitable for your school at Onion Lake.

You will possibly recall that Mr. Leonard and I visited your school some two years ago, and discussed with you at that time, suitable frigidaire equipment for your requirements, but recommended the operation of this equipment by Electric power only. Since that time, however, in conjunction with the manufacturers of Gasoline engines, we have developed a Gasoline Engine that is specially adapted for working such as you have, and in the quotation that we are submitting for your consideration you will note we are recommending the substitution of a Gasoline Engine as Motive power, replacing the Electric motor. Our reason for doing this is that we appreciate the fact that you are compelled to develop your Electric energy by an isolated plant and employ Storage Batteries as an auxiliary. Therefore, employing the Gasoline Engine that we are recommending to you and knowing its efficiency as we do, we believe that you can attain a highly satisfactory and economical performance.

With this information before us, we are submitting here with a quotation, namely:

We will supply you with one only Walk-in Refrigerator, 5½ feet wide, 9 feet long and 8 feet high, outside measurements. The insulation to be used would be 2 inches of Cork Board set in hot hydroline and faced with wax treated insulating paper. The Refrigerator, as on our former quotation will be in sections making a portable. This Refrigerator is to have one Walk-in Door, 24" wide x 72" high. The door is to be equipped with Refrigerator hardware of sufficient strength to carry this door for a

long period of time and also offset. The door will be equipped with Wire Gaskets. In our former quotation, we did not specify Service doors, but these will be included if you so desire.

To refrigerate this job, we would employ the use of one only WX 1476 Diamond Fin Cooling coil. The coil would be 78" long, 14" wide and 7" high, complete with one only TS Automatic expansion valve. The compressor that would be used is one only Model 2C genuine Frigidaire Compressor 21½" wide, 28" long and 19-1/8" high. This compressor is one of our latest models and has given sufficient economical service on the field for the past three or four years that we have no hesitation in guaranteeing results to you.

Re Gas Engine Drive. We would supply you with one only Villiers Century Gasoline Engine, two cycle with a speed range from 12 to 1800 R.P.M., and as stated previously this would be used as Motive power in replacing the Electric Motor.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

The Principal of our Onion Lake School has written to our Commission pointing out the need of Frigidaire equipment for this institution. He states that this equipment "is absolutely essential where quantities of beef have to be kept frozen during the warm and hot months of the year. We have never been able to keep food in proper condition as soon as spring comes, even though we put up over forty tons of ice. The building is too warm to keep meat over three days."

In your letter to me on September 4th, 1934, No.115-1-5 you stated that when the estimates for the next fiscal year were being prepared, consideration would be given to this need. Apparently the matter received your careful consideration, for you wrote to me on March 21st, 1935 (No.115-1-5) and stated that no funds were provided to cover the cost of this equipment. You also stated that it was not the policy of the Department to install electric refrigeration in schools where electric power for the operation of the same was not obtained from the power companies' lines.

The Rev. Principal Ellis has furnished our Commission with the enclosed quotation from the J. H. Ashdown Hardware Co. of Saskatoon, and it will be appreciated by our Commission if you will again give further consideration to this important need, and take whatever steps you may be able to supply the same.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa, February 8th, 1937.

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, pointing out the need of refrigeration equipment at the Onion Lake C. E. Indian Residential School.

Recently, we received a report indicating that it will probably be necessary to supply a new set of batteries at this school in the near future. Inspector Robertson has been directed to make a special report regarding the batteries and, on receipt of his reply, the Department will know definitely whether or not new batteries are needed.

Our appropriation for the current fiscal year is assigned and, at the present time, we are not in a position to state what funds will be available for repairs and equipment at residential schools during the next fiscal year. In view of these circumstances and the further fact that it will probably be necessary to supply batteries, the question of purchasing a Frigidaire for this school will have to remain in abeyance. However, your request for this equipment will be kept in mind when funds are available.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

**The Secret**

of the success of Lister Diesel Engines (apart from the general excellence of design and construction) is to be found in the unique patented Fuel Combustion Chamber with the Compression Ratio Changeover Valve which enables the engine to be started by hand from cold as easily as a petrol engine of equal horse-power, without any pre-heating or external ignition device whatsoever.

The advantage of having a variable combustion chamber is obvious when one bears in mind the necessity of securing sufficient heat to cause spontaneous combustion of the gases. The question of the necessary heat for ignition is a comparatively small one after the engine has been running for a while as the successive explosions create considerable heat in the castings. At the start however, this heat has to be supplied, and it is supplied in a Lister engine by cutting off the small auxiliary chamber, thus reducing the total size of the combustion chamber, and very greatly increasing the degree of compression of the gases in the cylinder head to a point where the heat thus generated is sufficient to cause combustion. After starting, a turn of the hand-wheel removes the plug from the aperture, and the size of the combustion chamber is increased by opening up the auxiliary chambers. The pressure is thus reduced to that necessary for maximum efficiency and maximum fuel economy when running under load.

The engines operate on the 4-stroke cycle principle, are totally enclosed, and are normally supplied for hand-starting, but can be supplied, if required, at an extra price for compressed air starting, electric starting, or remote

Our representative in Regina, Mr. E. C. Medland, has wired us that Dr. Robinson of the Anglican School at Onion Lake, may be interested in the purchase of a Battery for his lighting system.

We have taken the liberty of wiring you as per copy of telegram attached hereto, and we hope that we may have an opportunity of submitting prices.

We supply and service LISTER Lighting Plants both Gasoline and Diesel.

We are sending you under separate cover literature describing our Diesel Engined Plants, and suggest and recommend that in schools where you have an operation of four to five hours per day, you explore the possibilities of changing your Gasoline Plants for Diesel Engine Plants.

The cost of operating one of these Diesel Plants for fuel and lubricating oil, at Winnipeg prices, is not over $1-1/2¢ per kilowatt. The same capacity operated by gasoline engine would cost from five to eight cents per kilowatt; therefore you can see how quickly a Diesel Engined Plant would pay for itself.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In a letter just received from the Rev. H. Ellis, Principal of our Onion Lake School, he earnestly requests that the attention of your Department be directed to the urgent need of a frigidaire system for this School.

You will recall that this need was the subject of correspondence at the beginning of last year (see your letter, Feb. 8, 1937, No. 115-1-5). At that time, however, the need of new batteries for the lighting plant at this School was considered of greater urgency, and as funds were not available to meet both needs, the batteries were provided.

Along with my letter to you on Feb. 5th, 1937, I sent a quotation from the J.H. Ashdown Hardware Co.; Ltd., Saskatoon, and the Rev. Principal Ellis recommends that their quotation be accepted. The size of the Walk-In Refrigerator recommended is 5½ feet wide, 9 feet long, and 8 feet high, and the cost f.o.b. Lloydminster is estimated at approximately $800.00.

While the School has put up approximately 50 tons of ice for summer use, the Principal states that it is impossible, even with this, to keep meat from getting tainted.

I commend this urgent need to your early and sympathetic consideration.

Yours very truly,

Our Commission has received a request from the Principal of our Onion Lake School that the electric light generator formerly in use at our Elkhorn School be transferred to his School to serve as a motor to operate the laundry equipment there.

In support of this request he states that the "present gas engine is so worn, that the cylinder walls are now oval, thus, the back pressure causes fumes to penetrate through the main school building on wash days, leaving the same in a haze of smoke—burnt oil".

I wrote to the Principal of the Elkhorn School in the matter and he states that the generator is not likely to be needed at his School again, as the light and power required is now provided by the Manitoba Power Commission.

For your information I may say that this generator was manufactured by the Triumph Electric Company, Cincinnati, Ohio, and the Principal of our Elkhorn School has furnished the following detailed information concerning the same;

I am unable to give you an estimate of the total expenditure involved, but from the information I have received, am inclined to think that it will not exceed $50.00.

Report on the Fire at the Pump House
at the Onion Lake C.E. Indian Residential School - February 6th, 1939.

I have to report that on Monday the 6th inst., the pump house 10' x 16' on the lake shore was demolished by fire, caused, I believe, through an overheated stove.

The night-watchman visited this building at 5:30 a.m. and before leaving placed a small quantity of coal in the stove.

At 7:45 a.m. Mr. Stoddart went down to the pump house in order to start the pump for the use of the Laundry. Owing to the intense heat and smoke he was not able to get into the building.

The alarm was immediately raised by Mr. Stoddart and eight hand extinguishers were taken down. Three of these, however, failed to fully work. Had we had more extinguishers we might have been able to have saved the building, as it appeared at one time that we had the fire under control. Not being able to obtain water, in spite of throwing snow inside and on to the roof, the fire made headway. We then started to save the machinery. Snow was thrown into the building two to three feet high to cover the pump and the gasoline engine.

We then began to tear the building down to prevent the intense heat from damaging the equipment.

Having cleared the debris away, a tent was placed over the machinery and a stove was put in, thus saving the water system from freezing up.

All night a special attendant was detailed to start the engine every thirty minutes.

Today arrangements are being made to erect a temporary single ply building to take the place of the one lost.

It was a wretched day, being about 14 degrees below zero with a strong north-west wind blowing.

This morning it was 40 degrees below zero. This intensive cold slows up considerably the work of getting things into running order again.

(sgd) Henry Ellis,
Principal.

In a letter written at a later date, Feb. 15th, the Reverend Principal Mills reports that failure of the three fire extinguishers to function might have been due to the contents being spilled on the way from the School to the Lake-shore, where the pump house was located, a distance of some two to three hundred yards. He further reports that a shiplap building $10' \times 15' \times 8'$ was being put up around the tent which had been erected over the engine and pump, but that, owing to the severity of the weather—40 to 50 below zero—the work of building was very difficult.

Ottawa,
September 16, 1939.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

Re: Gasoline engine, Onion Lake school

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 14th instant and also copy of a letter received by you from the Principal of the above-noted school enclosed therewith.

The records here indicate that a requisition for a 22½ H.P. gasoline engine for the Onion Lake school was sent forward to the Purchasing Division on August 16. I have been in touch with this Division this morning and they have given me assurance that steps will be taken to purchase the engine immediately.

A number of reports have reached me recently in respect to the delay in securing supplies for residential schools. This delay, in my humble judgment, is due to the new purchasing regulations which are somewhat unwieldy. When repairs or supplies are needed at an Indian residential school a request is usually sent to the Indian Agent who in turn sends it forward to his Inspector. The Inspector sends it forward to Ottawa with certain comments thereon. The requests are then carefully reviewed by the officials of this Division and sent forward to the Purchasing Division at the head office, the officers of which call for tenders and make the actual purchases. It has been my experience, however, that in most cases additional information is nearly always required by the Purchasing Division. This, of necessity, involves delay and causes a great deal of inconvenience. If it is the intention of the Churches to meet the Minister at any time in the immediate future this is one of the matters that might be very carefully reviewed.

Rev. T.B.R. Westgate,
Secretary, Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission,
38-43 The Bible House,
184 Alexander Ave. East,
Winnipeg, Man.
If it is not the intention of the Churches to interview the Minister at any time in the immediate future it might be well, perhaps, for you to take the matter up with him yourself, bringing to his attention certain specific cases where delays have occurred in securing supplies.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

November 7, 1939

Hon. T.A. Crerar,
Minister of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Crerar:

While I am deeply sensible of the heavy duties and equally heavy responsibilities resting on you at all times, and especially during the present critical period in the history of Canada and the Empire, there is one important matter which I feel strongly should have any personal consideration you may be able to give it.

This matter is the delay created through the new purchasing regulations in securing some very essential repairs or supplies for the Indian Residential Schools.

As one instance out of many which I might quote you, I may say that an engine was required at our Union Lake School to operate the laundry and bread-making equipment to take the place of the old engine, which had previously been used to operate the lighting plant, but was found not to have sufficient power for that purpose. The Principal forwarded his request for this item of equipment to the local Indian Agent on May 15th last and hoped to have it installed and working when the School reopened after the summer holidays. He wrote to me again in the matter on July 29th, on August 3rd, and on Sept. 11th, and I find from my files that the matter was duly referred to the officers of your Department and that they in turn had communicated with the Purchasing Division.

As the engine had not reached the School when the Principal wrote to me on Sept. 11th, and by which time
the School had reopened after the summer holidays, you will be able to understand the inconvenience to which the School management was being subjected through this delay.

So far as I am able to understand the situation all Principals submit their requests to the local Indian Agent, the Indian Agent forwards the same to the Inspector, and he in turn sends them on to the officials concerned at Ottawa. After the officials have carefully considered them, all requests accepted are sent forward to the head office of the Purchasing Division. If the process ended there, and I myself can see no reason why it should not end there, many delays might be avoided, but, it would appear that the Purchasing Division does not always accept the endorsement of a Departmental official and the matter is referred back for further information, which means that the whole lengthy process has to be repeated, with inevitable delays, similar to the one I have mentioned.

As my purpose in writing this letter is not one of criticism but rather as a means of having some improvement effected in this department of Government service, I will be very grateful for any consideration you may be able to find time to give to the same.

Yours very truly,

Secretary of the Commission.
Ottawa,
November 15, 1939.

Dear Dr. Westgate,

In the absence in England of my Minister, Mr. Crerar, I am replying to your letter of the 7th instant. You expressed the view that the departmental purchasing regulations are somewhat cumbersome and cited the case of an order for an engine required at the Onion Lake School. I don't believe you are in possession of full details of this transaction. The department at Ottawa did not hear anything about this until July 11th when the Agent's letter of the 3rd idem was received. He did not furnish sufficient information on which to place an order and was asked on the 22nd of the same month to supply it. His reply dated August 1st was received on the 15th of the month and a requisition forwarded to the Purchasing Agent on the 17th. Tenders were invited and the order placed on September 26th.

Competition is necessary in connection with the placing of government orders and it is certainly most advisable that competitive bids be obtained.

You will see that the delay in this instance might be placed in a small degree only on the Purchasing Division, and delays of this kind will be reduced as departmental agents are educated to the necessity of supplying full details. The department must be able to determine the necessity for an article ordered, whether it is the most suitable for the work to be performed, and whether others handling or manufacturing similar goods are entitled to compete for the business. An extra man was placed on Indian Affairs purchasing late in the summer and this should help to cut down the time necessary to deal with requisitions submitted by that branch.

Reverend T.B.R. Westgate, D.D.,
Secretary,
Indian & Eskimo Residential School Commission,
The Bible House,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
The purchasing regulations were not established until the necessity for exercising a greater measure of central control became apparent, and it is believed they are serving reasonably well the purpose for which they were set up.

I might add that we were pleased to receive your letter and will welcome constructive criticism at any time. We are all working to the same end in the Indian work. We do, however, have to be careful in government purchases perhaps a good deal more than people not in the Service realize. If any other case comes to your attention where you consider there has been undue delay in making purchases we will be pleased to hear from you. I feel, however, that there should be no cause for delay now, provided full information is furnished when the request for a purchase is made.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) W.J.F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

However, when I received the information I visited the school, inspected the engine, which I found beyond repair, and took immediate action as I considered it an emergency.

Sir,

I have the honour to report that the small pump which supplies the C. of R. School with its water requirements from a nearby lake, is gradually giving out.

It was in the building that was destroyed by fire last spring and suffered some damage then. Normally its capacity is 2500 gallons per hour, and two hours pumping gave a daily supply, but since the fire the time required for pumping has increased monthly until now, when thirteen hours pumping are required for a day's supply, and it is likely to quit entirely in the near future.

It is a Fairbanks-Morse production and apparently they do not stock repairs for it. Even if repairs were available I think it would be more economical to purchase a new pump (which I understand would cost approximately $60.00) as the main portion of pump is quite seriously damaged.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant regarding the pump purchased for the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School.

Our funds are so limited that it will not be possible to consider paying a larger amount than that authorized; namely, $60.00. The balance of the cost of the pump will have to be paid by the school management from their funds.

I cannot understand why you did not purchase the pump yourself. In that event you would have been advised of its cost before it was placed in the school and you could have written to the Department for further authority. As you can understand it is impossible for the Department to administer funds if a greater amount is expended than the amount authorized. This is especially true at the present time when owing to conditions our appropriations are considerably reduced.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In connexion with the enclosed account from the Canadian Fairbanks Morse Co. Ltd., of Winnipeg, for a pump for our Colon Lake Residential School, I trust that the copies or telegrams attached to the same may furnish all the assurance you require that the pump was ordered by our Commission on the understanding that payment for the same would be made by your Department.

On the same day (Dec. 11, 1939) that the Rev. Principal Ellis sent his first telegram, he wrote a letter which reads as follows:

"Anglican Indian Residential School,
Lloydminster, Sask.
Dec. 11, 1939."

The Secretary,
Indian & Eskimo Residential School Commission,
43 The Bible House,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Sir:

I have telegraphed to you this morning asking that we be supplied immediately with a Canadian Fairbanks-Morse 2500 gallon capacity self-oiling Typhoon pump.
"I have taken up the matter with the local Indian Agent who will request authority from the Department at Ottawa to supply the same.

As we are without the facility of pumping water from the lake to the main school building for domestic purposes or for adequate fire protection, I have asked that the pump be sent to Lloydminster at once.

We intend to meet the train at Midnight tomorrow (Tuesday) and will install the pump as soon as it reaches here, thus preventing any further inconvenience at the school.

The old pump went through the fire last year, and though we have changed the gaskets and rubbers on the pistons, of late it has caused considerable inconvenience, hardly pumping 250 gals. per hour, until Saturday last it would not operate any more. Yesterday after pumping all day there was hardly 50 gallons that reached the main compression tank."

Yours very truly,

(sgd) Henry Ellis

Principal.

In view of the urgent need of adequate fire protection, in addition to the water required for domestic purposes, our Commission feel justified in taking the action they did.

It was, however, their understanding that the authorization required was being secured through your representative, and I sincerely trust that the Departmental cheque may be issued with as little delay as possible to cover the enclosed bill from the Company which supplied the pump.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

Encs.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 24th instant with reference to the pump purchased for use at the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School.

In a letter dated December 15, 1939, Indian Agent Dr. Hill reported to the Department that a new pump was required and could be secured at a cost of approximately $60.00. Authorization was given for this expenditure.

Dr. Hill wrote to the Department again in a letter dated January 15 stating that the Principal of the Onion Lake C.E. School had arranged for the purchase of the pump at a cost of $191.64, although Mr. Ellis had previously informed Dr. Hill that the pump would not cost more than $60.00.

We are prepared to pay the amount of $60.00 toward the cost of the pump but, as you can understand, it is impossible for the officials of the Department to administer funds if expenditures are incurred in an amount so greatly in excess of that requested. This is especially true at the present time when due to conditions of which you are aware it is quite likely that the amount available for repairs and improvements at Indian schools will be curtailed.

Yours truly,

If you will kindly furnish our Commission with the Department's cheque for the $60.00 you are willing to contribute towards the cost of this item of equipment, I will ask the members to contribute the balance of $131.64, and thus complete the payment of the bill in full.

Memorandum:

MR. BAILEY

In December last the Principal of the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School advised the Department that it was necessary to secure a new pump immediately. This was required to pump water to the school and he stated that the pump then in use was apt to break down at any time. He estimated the cost of the new pump at $60.00.

In view of the emergency authority was given for local purchase of the pump and later the attached account amounting to $191.64 was submitted for our consideration. We advised the Principal that we could only consider payment of an amount of $60.00 and a letter recently received from the Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada stated that the school management would provide from their funds the balance of the cost of the pump.

It would, therefore, be appreciated if you would arrange for issuing a purchase order for the amount of $60.00 in order that we can pay our share of the cost of the pump.

R. A. Hoey,

In December last the Principal of the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School advised the Department that it was necessary to secure a new pump immediately. This was required to pump water to the school and he stated that the pump then in use was apt to break down at any time. He estimated the cost of the new pump at $60.00.

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir:-

Re: Need of Laundry Washer Onion Lake C.E. School

In the list of the requirements at our Society's Schools forwarded to you on Oct. 2nd last, a Globe Laundry washer was included for the above Residential School at an estimated cost of $375.00.

I have recently received from the Principal of this School an urgent request that this item of equipment be supplied immediately, as the present washer, after many years of service, is now practically worn-out and is no longer safe to operate.

In the list of grants available for this School for the current fiscal year as given in Departmental letter of the 30th ult., No. 160-2, I note that the sum of $400.00 is available (for repairs and painting) and I will be glad to know if this amount could be applied towards the purchase of a new washer, (and the repairs and painting allowed to stand over for another year).

The Reverend Principal Willis has been in communication with Stanley Brook, Ltd., Winnipeg, and in a letter to him on the 19th inst. they make him the following offer:-

"One only 36" x 54" Canadian Globe Wood Washer, with new inside wooden cylinder and new outside wooden case; Belt-Driven; elevated header.

This washer is thoroughly rebuilt and in excellent shape, guaranteed free from workmanship defects for six months the same as a new machine. On this we quote you a price of $475.00, and we would allow you $25.00 for your old machine."
In the same letter Stanley Brock Ltd. mentioned that the above washer had been seen by Mr. C.W. Jackson, of your Department, and that he had made a memo of it as suitable for our Onion Lake School.

I will be obliged if you will let me know by telegram or at your very earliest convenience, if you will authorize our Commission to purchase the above washer at a net cost of $450.00, on the understanding that our Commission will pay the carrying charges from Winnipeg to the School.

You will note that the old washer is to become the property of Stanley Brock Ltd., and they will be responsible for its removal from the School.

Your obedient servant,

Gentlemen:

Your letter of July 20 addressed to St. Barnabas' School, Diocese of Saskatchewan, Lloydminster, Sask., Attention: Rev. H. Ellis, has been forwarded to this office. Certain statements made in your letter to the Principal do not correspond with the information that we have on file. You state in your letter that the battery at present in the school was bought more than five years ago. As a matter of fact the invoice covering this battery was dated November 29, 1937, and consequently the battery has been in use less than five years. Your letter also suggests that a 210 A.H. battery be installed and you further state that the last battery was a 180 A.H. In order to keep the records clear I may say that the account we received stated that the battery at present in the school was a 168 A.H.

The previous set of batteries at this school had served for nine years. It would, therefore, appear that the battery at present in the school has not lasted as long as could reasonably be expected. Our experience is that Principals are, in many cases, more anxious to get new batteries than they are to devote time and effort to properly caring for the batteries they have.

Yours truly,

Globelite Batteries Limited,
Winnipeg, Man.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to official letter of the 24th ultimo, with reference to the request for a new battery at the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School. For your information I am enclosing a copy of a letter which is being forwarded, today, to the Globelite Battery Company.

You will note from this that the battery at present in the school has been in use for less than five years, whereas the previous set had been used for nine. It is generally understood that these batteries should last at least seven years, if they are properly handled. As the present battery has apparently not lasted as long as we expect, it will be necessary, when replying to official letter of July 24, to state exactly why this condition has arisen.

An early reply to my letter of July 24 as well as this one would be appreciated.

Attention: Mr. R. A. Hoey.

Dear Sir:

Ref. File 115-1-5.

We have your letter of August 7th in connection with the battery at St. Barnabas School, Diocese of Saskatchewan. Our Detail Man, who visited the School on September 29, 1941, reported that the battery would be five years old in December, which is the reason for us stating that the battery was more than five years old.

We have since consulted our records and find that the battery was purchased November 29, 1937 and will be five years old this November.

At the time this battery was purchased it was known as our Type GD-15 168 Ampere Hours, guaranteed five years. This battery was replaced in 1939 and is now known as our Type GD-15 180 Ampere Hours. We have since adopted the new Dual Insulation consisting of Genuine Port Orford Cedar Separators and Multi-Life Woven Glass Mats which justifies the longer guarantee.

We would recommend and consider the proper installation our Type W-15 270 Ampere Hours Battery. However, the space that has been provided for the battery is not large enough to handle our W-15 Jars, hence the reason for recommending our Type GD-15 210 Ampere Hours which can be installed in the space provided.

We pointed out before that in order to take advantage of the Guarantee it is absolutely essential to buy a battery large enough to carry the load and complete information about selecting the proper size battery is shown on Page Three of our Price List enclosed.

Now that so many of the Schools and Agencies are using Globelite Batteries we are endeavouring to inspect each installation at least once a year and help the operator in every way to get the maximum in life and service from the battery.

Mr. Cameron,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Present bank of batteries are 168 ampere hours, old style Cedar Separators.

Installed November 1937 and guaranteed for five years.

Present condition:
Sulphated paste has reached bottom of plates, consequently, it is difficult for the batteries to hold the charge. The plates would crumble to pieces if battery is dismantled to be rebuilt. If batteries are allowed to operate in present condition there is a danger of the batteries short circuiting and perhaps explosion.

Recommendation:

The 168 ampere hour capacity is not considered heavy enough for Institutional work, and fortunate if they outlive the full guaranteed length of time. A heavier bank would give better service and last longer. Batteries made today have undergone a change and improvement. The cedar separators and glass mats give the new style batteries a dual insulation. Thus the plates do not powder so readily.

Principal.

Dear Sir:

With a view to providing space for vocational training at our St. Barnabas' School at Onion Lake, the Rev. Principal Ellis has recommended that the "machinery for the lighting plant" be taken out of the main school building, and placed in a separate house close by, this house to be 22' x 26', and the underground walls to be made of cement. He estimates the cost of completing the cement walls which would be 10' high, at $80.00 for the cement and $150.00 for the labour.

Principal Ellis further states that if granted this money now, he could have the work taken in hand at once, and carried forward sufficiently to house the lighting plant during the winter. In the spring, the upper part of the building including a frame or brick wall, with shingled roof, doors and windows, etc., could be completed. The Principal estimates the cost of this superstructure at $245.00, making the total cost amount to $475.00. As some allowance should be made for increases in cost of labour and materials I think an estimate of $600.00 would be safer.

As the arrangement suggested would not only add to the safety of the school, but provide quite good and suitable space for vocational training at a very moderate cost, our Commission recommend that it be accepted, and that we be authorized to proceed with the work at once. A prompt reply will oblige.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Church of England Indian Residential School,
Onion Lake Agency, Saskatchewan

With reference to your notation dated the 5th instant on Dr. McGill's memorandum to you of November 2nd, 1942, and attached correspondence from Church officers regarding the above, I may say that the matter to which Dr. McGill refers was discussed verbally by Mr. Doucet of the Training Division, Indian Affairs Branch, with our Architect on the 28th ultimo.

At that time Mr. Doucet was advised that in our opinion the basement room in question was at present only suitable for accommodating the lighting plant and pumping equipment, and that the necessary alterations to convert it to suitable manual training quarters would be of considerable extent.

The plans of the school do not show the equipment which was specified to be installed by the Department after completion of the building by contract in 1934; but on the plans the area is designated "Lighting Plant, Pumps, etc.," and the specification states that these units would be installed as above.

While Indian Affairs officers had no definite information regarding whether the original plans and specifications were followed, Mr. Doucet was of the opinion that as well as the lighting plant with its 25 H.P. gasoline engine generator, wet storage batteries, distribution and control equipment, etc., the pumping equipment in connection with the domestic and fire protection water supply system would be involved.

The cost of disconnecting these services and extending them to the proposed new location, as well as installing additional windows, could only be determined on the job.

Correspondence from the Church officers, forwarded with Dr. McGill's memorandum, requests the provision of funds for a building 22'0" x 26'0", having concrete basement walls 10'0" high.

It is proposed to build the basement now, and add a frame or masonry superstructure next Spring.

No information...

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
No information is provided, however, regarding the use for which the superstructure is being considered.

Their estimate for the completed work is in the neighbourhood of $600.00, of which $250.00 would be required for the basement walls.

In this connection I may say that the immediate cost of the basement portion of such a building, apart from the cost entailed in moving equipment, would be approximately $500.00, while the superstructure would cost approximately $1200.00 if built of frame, or $2000.00 if brick walls are provided. The total cost would therefore be either $1700.00 or $2500.00, depending on materials, rather than the $600.00 estimate of the Church officers. These figures are based on the use of first class materials and labour.

We have noted the reference of the Church officers and Dr. McGill to fire hazard. In this connection I may say that where lighting plants or other mechanical equipment are operated by gasoline or oil operated engines in a non-fireproof building, fire hazard is always present to a considerable degree, and can only be eliminated by installing such plant in fireproof accommodation isolated from principal structures.

In the present instance, the fire hazard would be reduced by removing the lighting plant to a separate building of fireproof construction, but until a complete report on the examination made on the existing lighting plant is available, and until we are advised of the site of the proposed new building, no opinion regarding its ability to overcome an added loss in transmission due to the new location can be advanced.

If manual training accommodation at the school is not satisfactory, it is recommended that the Indian Affairs Branch should give consideration to providing a new building of simple construction adapted to the purpose, if and when funds are available.

Respectfully submitted,

Chief Engineer.

Only a small quantity of gasoline and oil should be kept in the room where the lighting plant is situated, and great care should be taken against spilling gasoline or oil. No oily rags or other inflammable material should be left in the lighting plant room, smoking therein at any time should be strictly prohibited, and all electric wiring or fixtures should be kept in good condition. Memorandum:

Re: Church of England Indian Residential School,
Onion Lake, Saskatchewan.

In further reference to your notation on Dr. McGill's memorandum of November 2nd last regarding the provision of space for vocational training and the fire hazard existing in connection with the lighting plant, an inspection was made by Mr. Cornish in the latter part of May and the following extract from his report is quoted hereunder:

"The Church of England School was inspected with special attention being paid to the proposal by school authorities to change the housing of the lighting plant. The lighting plant is a Fairbanks Morse 25 H.P. semi-diesel engine, Style H, No. C-21832 R.P.M., with a belt drive to a Fairbanks Morse D.C. generator, compound wound, 7½ K.W., 125 volts, 6 amps., 1950 R.P.M. The room now occupied by the plant is a 16' by 25' frame addition to the rear of the room designated in the original plans for lighting plant and pump. The addition has a concrete floor at ground level but is otherwise of wooden construction.

"The room originally intended for the lighting plant is occupied by an International Harvester engine, Model P.15 Serial No. 2641, used on a belt drive to operate the washer, extractor and dough mixer in the adjoining laundry. This unit may also be connected by belt to an auxiliary 5 K.W. generator, lacking a name plate, for use in the event of the main power unit being out of commission. The original lighting plant room has concrete walls for a height of two feet above the floor, the balance of the walls and the roof being of wood framing. The floor has a concrete strip four feet wide, on which the engine rests, running the length of the room against the inside wall. The rest of the floor is of wooden construction and is dirty with some patches soaked with oil. Two fire extinguishers are kept near the boiler room entrance to this room and all engine fuel is stored in an underground tank outside the lighting plant room.

"The school principal, Rev. H. Ellis, explained that his plan was to build a 24-foot by 26-foot building to house the lighting plant and the auxiliary. The building would be located opposite and some 120 feet to the west of the present engine room. It would have a concrete floor and concrete walls faced with local stone similar to the gate post work shown in one of the accompanying photographs. The roof would be of shingles on wooden rafters. Mr. Ellis has obtained an estimate of

(over)

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6322, file 658-5, part 8)
$500.00 for erection of this structure. The present lighting plant room would be used for vocational training and the room housing the secondary power unit would be used as a workshop.

"Changing the location of the secondary power unit would, of course, require that the laundry equipment and dough mixer be motorized either individually or by one motor using the existing belt drives and shifting. It would be possible to convert the 5 kw. generator to a motor for this purpose as this was proposed by Mr. Ellis, who said that he also had available a 10 kw. generator which I did not see. This would mean that the 7½ kw. generator be used as an auxiliary with the secondary power unit and the 10 kw. generator put into service with the lighting plant. The scheme would involve moving and resetting the two power units, converting the 5 kw. dynamo to a motor, providing new switches and panels and a considerable amount of wiring work and material. This in addition to the cost of erecting a rather expensive building. The benefits obtained would be the acquisition of a room for vocational training, another room as a workshop (for which purpose it is partly used now) and the reduction of fire hazard.

"Since the Department does not approve the construction of a building for vocational training purposes, the reduction of fire hazard is the governing factor. In this connection, I do not consider that a fire hazard exists other than would be found in any engine room of wooden construction. The room now housing the lighting plant is somewhat isolated from the main building and the fire hazard small. In the room housing the secondary unit, there is greater fire hazard as it is more closely connected to the main building and has a wooden floor for the greater part of its area. However, fire would only be likely to start here by carelessness in operating the unit and the wood flooring could be covered by sheet iron to reduce the hazard. Generally, I consider the cost of the proposed change to be out of all proportion to the benefit resulting and would recommend against it.

"There is a frame building 40 feet by 18 feet on log sills near the proposed site of the engine room building, that was previously used as a laundry and which was considered by the Indian Agent as a vocational training shop. However, the building is over 25 years old and in such poor condition that I would not recommend its use. If any machine work is contemplated in the vocational training, it would be necessary to provide a floor strong enough to allow a firm tractor or other machinery to be run inside. The floor should preferably be of planks rather than concrete as the latter would cause considerable damage when edged tools were dropped."

It will be noted that Mr. Cornish does not consider the present fire hazard to be any greater than ordinarily exists where gasoline engines are operated, but that in the room occupied by the auxiliary unit it could be reduced by covering the wooden floor with sheet iron.
Regarding the proposal to erect a new building to house the lighting plant and auxiliary unit, Mr. Cornish points out that in addition to the cost of the building and moving the two units to it, there would be costs for new switching equipment, wiring and converting the generator to a motor and drive the dough mixer and laundry equipment. He does not consider that the resulting benefits would justify the cost.

In this connection please refer also to our memorandum of November 13th last.

On examining the sewage disposal system it was found that some minor repairs were needed and that the septic tank should be cleaned out. The Principal assured Mr. Cornish that these conditions would be remedied.

AIR MAIL

Reverend Sir:

The Department would appreciate it if you would make immediate arrangements to supervise the repairs that are required to St. Alban's College, Prince Albert.

According to a report received from Mr. Christianson the necessary repairs are as follows:

(a) Some of the plaster is broken and will have to be patched. The plaster in the top story might have to be replaced on account of the frost getting into the building, but in the other rooms only a patch here and there will be necessary.

(b) All the walls should be kalsomined.

(c) Replace broken glass in all windows.

(d) Repair some of the storm windows which have been broken.

With the exception of the purchase of glass, most of the repairs will only mean engaging labour and the supervision of their work. The glass required can no doubt be secured in Prince Albert and, if so, this will permit the repairs to be made at as early a date as possible. As soon as you advise me that you are ready to proceed to Prince Albert to supervise this work an accountable cheque will be forwarded to you.

Yours truly,

Rev. Henry Ellis,
Principal,
Union Lake C.E. Residential School,
Lloydminster, Sask.

AIR MAIL

Reverend Sir:

Your letter of December 31 reached me today and we have carefully studied your list of furnishings. Further information is required immediately regarding the following:

1. (a) Washing machine
   (b) Extractor
   (c) Dryer
   (d) Box stove

All of these items are apparently required for the laundry and more details will be required at once regarding the size and type that you consider most suitable. If possible, give a catalogue number for each of these items. With regard to the washing machine, you should state the size of the cylinder and the capacity per load. In connection with the box stove, it will be necessary to state whether you intend to burn wood or coal and the size of this stove, with a catalogue number, should also be given.

2. Galley stove for kitchen

In this instance you should state whether it is your intention to burn wood or coal and you should also give a catalogue number, in order that we may know exactly the size of the stove required.

3. You quote prices of $28.00 and $32.50 each for tables 8' and 10' long respectively for the children's dining room. You also quote prices of $9.50 and $11.00 each for benches 6' and 10' long respectively. Please let me know the name and address of the firm from whom these quotations were received.

Prince Albert, Sask.

Regina, January 11th, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to inform you that I had a letter from Mr. A. Colleaux of Prince Albert, inquiring about the disposal of the salvage from the Onion Lake Anglican Indian Residential School that recently burned down. I also had a letter from Mr. H.J. Fraser, Barrister and Solicitor of Prince Albert who is also the Provincial Member for Prince Albert, strongly recommending that Mr. Colleaux be given first opportunity in this regard.

Upon receipt of the above mentioned letters I immediately got in touch with the Reverend Mr. Ellis and am now in receipt of a letter from him stating the heating boiler, compression tanks, hot water boiler, and the high pressure boiler have not been damaged in any way. They were drained by the staff immediately after the building collapsed. The sewage system is also intact. The only things to salvage then are the radiators, fire escapes, beds that went through the fire, etc. Mr. Ellis points out there are iron pipes, nipples and unions that could be salvaged together with fire escapes which are badly twisted. I do not know whether our Branch want to salvage the radiators or not. The Reverend Mr. Ellis puts a value of $20,000.00 on the boilers and tanks which were undamaged.

I just thought I would bring this matter to your attention in case you might want to do something about it. In the meantime I have informed Mr. Colleaux that he will have to wait until he hears from me again and that I have written to you in this regard.

M. Christiansen,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
St. Alban's Indian Residential School,

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR
Surveys & Engineering Branch

The Onion Lake Church of England Indian Residential School was destroyed by fire on December 1, 1945. I am advised by Mr. Christianson that the heating boiler, compression tanks, hot water boiler and the high pressure boiler have not been damaged in any way. They were drained by the staff immediately after the building collapsed.

Mr. Christianson also states that we could sell the radiators, fire escapes, beds that went through the fire, iron pipes, nipples etc.

It would be appreciated if you could arrange to have one of your officers visit the site of this school at the earliest possible date, in order to examine the equipment that Mr. Christianson states has not been damaged. If your officer finds these items in sufficiently good condition to use again, he will no doubt recommend the best manner in which to preserve them.

At the same time we would like him to state what could be sold, in order that we can bring the matter to the attention of the Salvage Officer at the earliest possible date.

If your official gets in touch with Mr. D.H. Cameron, Indian Agent, Onion Lake, Saskatchewan, arrangements can be made to proceed to the school.

Director.

CONFIRMATION OF MY TELEGRAM DATED JAN 31/44.

As instructed in your night letter of the 28th inst. I proceeded to Halifax on the afternoon of the 29th but was unable to contact the officer commanding. On Monday the 31st I again returned there and inspected the material.

I found that only three of the five tables had tops, the legs of all were bent and warped and I considered them all almost worthless. The stove was a very old one, the fire-box linings had been burned and a few bricks placed in. The top was warped, the legs spread out and it too was nothing but junk.

The Officer Commanding intimated very strongly that if the material was worth having they could quite easily put it to good use. I assure you that, judging from the clothing and shoes sent here by this force, anything condemned by their interior economy officer, is not much good. This material belonged to the Halifax hotel which was taken over by this force as their new headquarters in Halifax.

I regret my oversight in sending the telegraphic report collect. It never occurred to me until the wire had gone that I was requested on Nov. 2/43 to discontinue this practise.

H. C. Rice,
Ind. Agent
