I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 115-1-1 of the 31st ultimo by Air Mail.

Immediately upon receipt of this I wrote to the Reverend Mr. Ellis, at Prince Albert, informing him that he may take the high pressure boiler and transport it to the school in Prince Albert.

With respect to the copy of the letter attached received by our Branch from Mr. T.S. Mills, Chief Engineer, Surveys and Engineering Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, I might say that the Reverend Mr. Ellis was down here last week and while he was in Regina he came to the office a couple of times. I knew that we would have to hire some men to get rid of the refuse so that we could get at the material that was worth salvaging. However, I did not want to suggest anything to make an expense and I thought in all probability you would get one of the engineers to go out there and attend to this, and naturally he would have to hire some Indians up there to do the work.

I am writing to the Indian Agent, Mr. Cameron, to see if he can have his farming instructor look after this. Mr. Lockhart is capable of carrying this out because anything of this nature is right in his line. I am also sending the letter to Mr. Cameron with instructions that after he goes over the situation there he wire me an estimate of the cost because of the poor mail service between here and Onion Lake. This would also furnish a little employment to the Indians of that band.

As soon as I get this information from Mr. Cameron I shall advise you.

M. Christenson,

(b) Fittings for the high pressure boiler and cementing the laundry floor and placing the drain pipes for the laundry machinery.

I have a letter from Mr. Cameron, Indian Agent, Onion Lake Agency, with respect to the Church of England Residential School that was burned down last Fall.

Mr. Cameron had a meeting with the Chief and Council of the Onion Lake Band on May 9th and the Indians seemed to be very much concerned about rebuilding the school on the same site on their reserve, in fact they are very anxious that this school be rebuilt there. They pointed out to the Agent that the Reverend H. Ellis, Principal of the School, met them on Sunday, May 7th, and had given them to understand that the school would be rebuilt but that it would be erected on another reserve and they were lead to believe the site for the re-building of the school has already been donated. In view of this they have asked the Agent to make strong representations on their behalf to our Branch to use all their influence in seeing that this school is re-established on their reserve. The Chief, while at the meeting, pointed out the school had been a source of great assistance to the Indians there in many ways. The children received a good education and the influence of the school carried that to the Indian homes. He also pointed out that the land, fences, and all the out buildings which are necessary for the school are still there and the Indians could not understand why the Department is contemplating building the school at some other place. Putting it in Mr. Cameron's words "They would indeed be very sorry if this should happen and strongly urge..." that the Agent and myself mediate on their behalf with respect to this matter.

Re: Rebuilding Onion Lake Residential School.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of May 15, in which you discuss the subject matter of a letter received by you from Indian Agent Cameron.

No consideration has been given by the Department to the rebuilding of the Onion Lake School. Temporary provision, as you are fully aware, has been made for the pupils of this school at St. Alban's College, Prince Albert. No provision has been made for the construction of Indian day or residential schools in our estimates during the last four year period, despite the fact that during this period a large number of schools have been destroyed by fire. It is our hope that, when funds are available, we shall be able to proceed with our construction program by recognizing the claims of the districts where in our judgment the need is most urgent.

The following schools have been destroyed by fire and should be rebuilt by the Department: the senior school at Caughnawaga, the File Hills Residential School classroom, the Alberni Residential School classroom, the Carcross Residential School, and the Back Settlement Day School, Caradoc Agency, Ontario. In addition to these, it will be necessary to build two consolidated schools at Shubenacadie and Eskasoni, in Nova Scotia, to complete the consolidation of the agencies in that province. In view of these facts, it is not likely that we shall be in a position to proceed with the construction of the Onion Lake School at any time in the
immediate future. In the meantime, the officials here would welcome any information that can be supplied us with respect to the type of school that should be built at Onion Lake. If you feel that an educational survey of the reserve should be made, the Department would be glad to employ the public school inspector for this purpose.

Dear Mr. Ellis:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, with reference to securing a refrigeration system for the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School now located at Prince Albert. I note you suggest that a couple of refrigerators might be secured from one of the military schools that are now being closed.

We readily realize that there is a general impression throughout the country that surplus equipment at military camps, air force stations and other such establishments will be available for distribution to other Government projects. This idea, however, is definitely contrary to fact. There have recently been set up two organizations known as the Crown Assets Allocation Committee and the War Assets Committee. Our understanding is that these two organizations will take over all surplus equipment from any of the war camps or departments and will arrange for their disposal in the open market. Due to the great scarcity of consumer goods at the present time there is very little doubt that they will be able to dispose of all surplus equipment in a manner which will reimburse the Government to a great extent for the expenditure previously incurred. If we endeavour to secure any of this equipment for our residential schools or agencies we will be obliged to compete with others endeavouring to secure the same articles. You will readily see that there is no

The Indians have requested me to write you with reference to the unsightly and dangerous condition in which the old Anglican Residential School here at Onion Lake was left after it had been pulled down by wreckers to whom it had been sold.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your Letter No. 115-1-5, of the 26th ultimo, with reference to the "Old Anglican Residential School".

The site referred to is that of the "old school" which was abandoned about 18 years ago when the new school was built. The old site is right here at Onion Lake whereas the new site is located some 6 miles away. There is no reference to the School which was destroyed by fire last December and where the Church of England is still operating the farm with Mr. H. Calrow as supervisor.

The old school building was pulled down a year ago and left in something of a mess. It is dangerous for stock on account of the old cellar and also on account of nails left in boards. There are no walls standing. The Church authorities sold the building to a "wrecker" and I presume he was supposed to have left the premises in better condition.

Dear Dr. McGill:

When our school at Onion Lake was destroyed by fire last December we continued to operate the farm until there was some indication as to the measures that would be taken to continue the work of the school. We hoped, and continue to hope, that sooner or later the school will be rebuilt at this site. There is evidence that there are more Anglican children anxious to attend than we have ever been able to accommodate. The site is excellent and a good farm of 640 acres has been in process of development. The Principal's residence, barn and other outbuildings remain in good order and we earnestly hope that when it becomes possible a new school will be built and the work will go forward with this favourable start.

When the work of the school was transferred to St. Alban's at Prince Albert, our Commission decided to continue the farm at Onion Lake. We felt that it was necessary to do this to keep the buildings and fences in good order and the land under cultivation. We hoped that some plan might be worked out whereby our older boys could take their turn in working on the farm and so be given the training for which this school has been noted. We also hoped that the farm could produce vegetables for use in the school. Accordingly we transferred one of our most trusted Farm Instructors and made him Superintendent of this farm in the hope that the advantages suggested above might be gained. We also have cherished the hope that an early end of the war might mean that before long the school might be rebuilt, and that the present building in Prince Albert might be used by the Department as a kind of Indian College, a centre to which the more advanced pupils from a number of the schools on the Prairies might be sent to continue their high school work under favourable conditions.

I regret to say that our experience during the past summer has led us to doubt the wisdom of these conclusions. We have been given to understand by officials of the Department that there is little likelihood of any school being built at Onion Lake for some years to come. We have found it impracticable by reason of distances and bad roads to use the older boys on the farm and to supply the school with produce. Our Superintendent has found it impossible to get farm help except at prohibitive costs, and reports that much of the machinery is in poor condition and that considerable expenditures are required at the present time if the farm is to be...
operated without heavy loss. In these circumstances our Commission has had to give serious consideration to the matter and has concluded that it is not our responsibility to continue to operate this farm. We feel that it will be better for us to aim at securing land within reach of the Prince Albert School where the boys and girls can receive their training and vegetables can be produced economically. As the Onion Lake farm is the property of the Department, is located on the Reserve, and adjoins the Agency farm it seemed to us possible that arrangements might be made through the Indian Agent to continue in operation so that the work already done might be made good and the farm and buildings kept in good order.

I shall be grateful if you will kindly consider this matter and let me know your decision. We have several vacancies for a Farm Instructor at this moment and are anxious to place our Superintendent in one of them as he has strongly expressed his desire to return to one of the schools.

With kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

J.A. Alderwood
Secretary.

Attention Dr. H.W. McGill

Department of Mines & Resources,

Dear Dr. McGill:

Further to my letter of yesterday's date, we have just heard from the Bishop of Saskatchewan who desires that action be deferred in regard to this matter until he has been able to discuss it further with our Commission.

May I therefore, ask you to be good enough to withhold consideration of my letter until we have met with the Bishop and are in a position to write further.

Thanking you, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H.A. Alderwood

Indian Affairs Branch - Ottawa.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 115-1-5, of the 26th ultimo, enclosing a letter from Mr. E. E. Mapletoft, Fort Pitt, Sask., re salvage material and equipment at the C. E. Indian Residential School here.

According to my information the Surveys and Engineering Branch were asked by the Director last January (1944) to have an officer visit the site to examine undamaged articles and recommend the best manner in which to preserve them; and at the same time to state what could be sold in order that the matter could be brought to the attention of the Salvage Officer.

The inspection was made in July, 1944, by J. H. Mitchell, Esq., Assistant Engineer, Department of Mines and Resources, Banff, Alberta. No doubt Mr. Mitchell's report is available and I think his is the report you require.

I enclose a copy of an inventory which I made and forwarded to Mr. Christianson's office in duplicate, under date of April 10th, 1944. The high pressure boiler referred to in the list has been removed to Prince Albert by Mr. Ellis, Principal of the C. E. School there, and one of the compression tanks is in use at the Principal's house at the School site, Onion Lake.

Although I am not qualified to pronounce on the condition and value of the articles I am of the opinion there is a lot of valuable equipment and salvage material to be disposed of in some manner. However, we are of the opinion that if this equipment and material are to be disposed of locally, a sale should be called in order to give equal opportunity to all interested parties and avoid public criticism and hard feelings, and at the same time realize the true value of the articles sold. I would not give young Mr. Mapletoft's letter very serious consideration.

Donald H. Cameron,
Indian Agent.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING MARCH, 1945, ON ONION LAKE AGENCY

Education:

I visited the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School on January 25, February 27 and March 27, Frog Lake Indian Day School on January 12 and March 9, and Long Lake Day School on March 7. The building to be used as a class room for the proposed Day School on Onion Lake Reserve, is being repaired and will be in readiness for school to open May 15th or when the teacher gets here. The C.E. Residential School Farm will be operated by P. Waskawitch, an Indian, this year, who will sow all tillable land to barley and keep the fences in repair. This is considered the best program possible to control the weeds this year. The whole of the cultivated land must be summer fallowed next year. The work this summer will be done with a tractor as P. Waskawitch has just recently acquired one.

Donald H. Cameron,
Indian Agent.
